PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The purpose of this statement is to announce the Government's migration program for 1986-87. In doing so, I would first like to draw the attention of honourable members to the demographic and economic issues relevant to Australia's population and immigration policies in the longer term. While current economic and social circumstances are important in setting immigration programs, the Government is conscious of the importance of the questions of the longer term benefits and costs which must be addressed if Australia is to exploit its full potential.

SPEECH.PARA: Immigration intakes of recent years have combined with decreasing natural increase to produce population growth rates well below historical experience. Since 1946 the average annual population growth rate has been 1.85 per cent; as recently as 1983-84 it fell to as low as 1.15 per cent. About half of post-World War II population growth has been due to natural increase and the other half directly the result of migration. However, immigration has had a significant indirect stimulus through natural increase.

Although Australia's population is still slowly increasing by virtue of natural increase alone, this will persist only while the age structure of our population remains relatively young. The level of Australian fertility is currently 10 per cent below the long term population replacement level and there is little chance of a recovery. Although Australia's level of mortality is low, still declining, and satisfactory by global comparisons, the crude death rate will rise as the population progressively ages. With a continuation of these trends in births and deaths, Australia's population would begin to decline half way through the next century, in the absence of immigration.

While still relatively young, the Australian population is also ageing progressively. Honourable members will be aware that this development has significant welfare, taxation, labour market and economic consequences. Short of substantial increases in recent levels of immigration, the ageing of the population will accelerate sharply early in the next century. If current levels of immigration are retained, the aged dependency ratio would increase by 58 per cent by the year 2021. This ratio broadly relates those in retirement age to those available to the labour market. A 58 per cent increase in this ratio would have dramatic and far-reaching social and economic consequences. No society and no government can responsibly ignore these trends.

Immigration cannot reverse ageing of the population but it can retard the process. Over the last decade or so, the average age of new settlers has been some five years younger than the average age of the resident population. To retard the ageing process significantly will require a sustained return to more traditional, historical levels of immigration programs.

Population is not merely a question of numbers, growth rates or age profiles. The distributional impact of migration, both international and internal, cannot be ignored. The Government is conscious of the propensity of migrants to settle in existing urban communities, but it does not regard this as an issue which can be properly addressed in a migration context alone, given that people in Australia are free to choose the place in which they will live and work. Recent research demonstrates that migrants are at least as mobile and flexible as their Australian-born counterparts, particularly in the early years of settlement. Equally, proper concerns about environmental issues are relevant to population growth and immigration programs. Ultimately, however, the capacity of a nation to address environmental concerns largely resides in areas other than immigration, including capacity to generate economic wealth, a sufficient tax base and technological sophistication.

Immigration levels cannot be determined in isolation from permanent and long term departures. In recent years permanent departures have fluctuated from a low of 19,500 in 1980-81 to a high of 25,000 in 1982-83. They have resulted in substantial losses of skilled workers. Accordingly, the contribution of net permanent migration to the Australian labour market has been substantially less than the contribution of permanent settlers alone.

I turn now to the economic implications of immigration. Recent research undertaken by the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia, CEDA, and my Department is relevant to our understanding of the role of immigration in the Australian economy. It is generally accepted that research of this kind is complex and based in part on econometric models, and that the findings have to be seen in that light. However, the more significant research findings are sufficiently important to include in this statement. Until recently, many Australians, and not least Australian opinion leaders, have subscribed to the populist view that during periods of high unemployment or economic downturn immigration is disadvantageous to the employment prospects of Australians seeking to enter the labour market. These mistaken perceptions need serious attention. I draw the attention of honourable members to three of the CEDA research findings. The first is that immigration has contributed positively to economic growth and development. The second is that immigration, even in the very short term, does not adversely affect the employment prospects of the Australian resident population, with few localised and particular exceptions. The third is that the skill, education, age and self-sufficiency profiles of a particular intake are perhaps more important than the overall scale of any one intake.

In relation to this question of education and skills, the Government has noted the call for higher levels of skilled labour and business migration. The Economic Planning Advisory Council, EPAC, suggested that the skill composition and base of the Australian labour force could be enhanced in the medium term from increases in these programs. Whilst agreeing with these views, the Government is equally committed to upgrading the skill base of the Australian community by appropriate education, training and retraining policies and programs.

In the long term, population policy objectives and economic rationality will be best served by a progressive return to more traditional levels of immigration. This return must be gradual, in part because the lead times in immigration are significant. Australia faces as much international competition for people with positive economic attributes as it does for commodity and capital markets. If anything, the level of competition is likely to sharpen in the medium to longer term. The Government sees properly managed population growth and immigration as an important strategy for economic policy options. All economic policy instruments involve short and long term benefits and costs, and immigration is no exception.

In looking at the long term future the Government is concerned to awaken Australia's interest in, and appreciation of, the population dimension. The appendices to this statement, which I shall table at the end of my speech, underpin the statement and provide a basis for an informed understanding of where we are and where we are headed. I recently asked the National Population Council to develop and advise me on long term population options for Australia. I expect that the Council's advice and the statement I have made will both serve to elicit public comment on these longer term population and immigration issues.

It should be noted that, if it were decided that Australia's population by the year 2000 should be about 19 million, then that outcome would be achieved by an average annual immigration program of 120,000. If it were decided that there should be a population target of some 30 million by the year 2038, the 250th year of European settlement of this continent, then such an outcome would be reached with an average annual migrant intake of 160,000. Both outcomes would be more likely were fertility rates to recover to higher levels. In either event, both could be achieved by manageable progressive increases in recent levels of immigration to intakes comparable to those experienced in the 1940s and 1960s when the population base and Australia's absorption capacity were substantially less then they are now or will be in the future.

Australia's aim should be to see its immigration program in the context both of humane and community concerns and of population and economic development needs. Our understanding must be that immigrants, carefully selected, create more jobs than they take. It is against this philosophical and factual background that the Government has considered the migration program for 1986-87 and indicative planning levels for the subsequent two years. In developing the program the Government has had the benefit of formal advice from employers, trade unions, community groups, State governments, local government representatives, academics and the National Population Council. We propose a program of 95,000 visa issues and change of status approvals in 1986-87. This compares with an expected outcome of 89,000 in the current year and a planning level of 84,000. It represents a modest initial increase, and one I expect will be achieved.

For the two subsequent years the Government has set indicative planning levels of 110,000 and 125,000, respectively. These levels are no more than indicative for planning purposes. They could represent the beginnings of a possible gradual increase in immigration which may thereby, subject to community support following from consultation on resources and needs, return by managed steps to historical intake levels of 160,000 to 170,000 or about 1 per cent of population at that time. These are decisions for the future-but the foundations are being laid.

I announce one major change and initiative to the structure of the migration program of interest to all honourable members. The Government has decided to develop the concept of an independent and concessional migration category to attract a wider and more numerous number of people with the potential to contribute to Australia's economic and social needs. This category is based on the principles of the current extended family (category C) program, which as honourable members would know, covers sponsored adult siblings and non-dependant children. Applicants will be required to achieve a pass mark of 70 points on the existing points system which relates to the age, employability, education and skill characteristics of the potential migrant. In recognition of the economic support that family in Australia can provide, concessionary points will be given to adult brothers and sisters and non-dependent children (10 points out of 70) and nephews and nieces (5 points).

In summary, the new independent and concessionary migration category brings benefits from the economic gains to Australia from the people likely to succeed in their migration applications, whilst recognising at the same time the economic and social advantages of the extended family nexus. This category is not one of entitlements but one of optimising human and economic realities. Effectively, the Government is concerned here with attracting people Australia needs, motivationally, economically and in terms of population building and the retardation of aging. Would-be independent migrants with no family ties but who adequately meet the criteria of employability, self-sufficiency, youth, skills and/or education will still be eligible to be included in our expanding migration program.

At the same time, I emphasise the Government maintains its commitment to reunion of immediate family. The family unit for us is the Australian family unit based on husband, wife, dependent children and retired parents. For aged parents of independent means, spouses and dependent children, entry is virtually automatic. On present levels of demand, I estimate a program of 26,000 visas in 1986-87 compared with an estimated outcome of 25,000 in 1985-86. A sensitive element has been the Vietnam family migration program, which relies on the continued co-operation of the Vietnamese Government. It needs to be understood that in return for their responsibility to integrate into and contribute to Australian society, one of the rights given to migrants is to be reunited with immediate family. But this right does not flow over to the extended family. Extended family members are given preference for migration, more so in Australia than in the United States or Canada, but they must qualify for migration on the basis of the potential contribution they can make to Australian society.

Skilled migration will continue to play a vital role in filling specific labour market needs. We propose 16,000 visa issues compared to a planning level of 14,000 in the current year. In an increasingly competitive environment, greater efforts will be made to attract business migrants and talented entrepreneurs with a target of 2,500 visa issues, some two-thirds higher than the expected 1985-86 outcome. I shall seek leave to table a summary of the compositional elements of the 1985-86 and 1986-87 migration programs at the end of this statement.

The Government reaffirms its commitment to its refugee and special humanitarian programs which will remain for planning purposes at their 1985-86 levels, namely, 12,000 plus a contingency reserve of 2,000. This reflects a balance between a minor decrease in need for the re- settlement of Indo-Chinese, particularly Vietnamese, a minor increase in East European caseloads and a largely stable level of need in other areas. In line with our desire to increase community involvement in humanitarian resettlement and to recognise the resource implications of funding refugee travel to an extent not undertaken by comparable migrant intake countries such as the United States of America and Canada, there will be a change in the balance between persons receiving passage assistance and those responsible for funding their own travel to Australia. Fewer refugee travel costs will be funded by the Australian taxpayer.

This Government reaffirms its commitment to immigration as a positive, needs-based, economically desirable and socially advantageous instrument of economic, population and social policy. It reaffirms Australia's sovereignty by maintaining non-discriminatory, but selective, universal selection principles. I reiterate that the Australian Government alone decides and will continue to decide who can enter and stay in Australia. It affirms its vision for the future, one of managed, gradual expansion of the migration program. It wants a better society for all Australians and sees immigration, properly controlled, as a powerful weapon in achieving that objective. This Government emphasises the balance that is required between choosing those who will make the biggest contribution to Australia and those admitted on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, in particular immediate family and refugees. In this context, both the program that I have announced and the longer term thinking and debate about our future, which I encourage, continue to reflect the principles of immigration which my predecessors, of all political persuasions, have firmly embraced. I table a fuller statement from which I have drawn in making these remarks and which includes the appendices to which I have referred. I present the following paper:
Migration Program 1986-87-Ministerial Statement, 10 April 1986.
Motion (by Mr Cohen) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I respond to the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), I would like to make a few remarks on the consultation between the Government and the Opposition. For some time now the Opposition has been complaining about the Government's lack of consultation on immigration matters. The Minister and I had a discussion yesterday and I wish to inform the House that the Minister indicated his regret that the Opposition has not been consulted about this announcement and the details of the forthcoming year's immigration program. This is a matter of great regret to the Opposition. The Minister indicated that he will be doing everything possible to improve the level of consultation. The Minister claimed that a substantial sector of the Australian community has been consulted, but the Opposition has not participated. Nevertheless, because of the Opposition's wide contacts and well informed attitudes, the lack of consultation has been no impairment to our capacity to participate in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has just presented an economic rationale for increasing immigration to Australia by 11,000 to 14,000 for the forthcoming year. The Minister stated that the Australian economy will benefit greatly from this increase because it is based on young people with skills and knowledge who will be self-sufficient and who will create jobs for themselves and for others. In fact, the program of 95,000 immigrants for 1986-87 will not be 11,000 to 14,000 above last year's targeted program. There was a considerable overrun in family unions during this year of 12,000, and a shortfall in skilled immigrants. The increase this year above the targeted program was approximately 6,000, and the forthcoming year proposes a further increase on the actual intake of this year of 6,000. Some of the projected increase is anticipated to come from the occupational share system and the employer nomination system.

Questions need to be asked. Can it be done? Is it realistic? Will it be good for Australia? The Opposition believes that a well planned, well executed immigration program is essential. We have argued for some time that any increase in the level of immigration should be based on the selection criteria which favour young, skilled educated employable people as well as those who can make a financial investment in Australia.

The Government has accepted our basis in arguing its case. However, it has not applied these factors with the degree of confidence needed for a successful program, nor has it realised the widest implications of its announced program base.

The Government in its immigration program, has been completely controlled and shackled until now by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade unions, and by its demonstrated ineptitude to administer the current program. There is no doubt about that-I invite honourable members opposite to read the record. The three years of Australian Labor Party administration of this portfolio has produced wild swings in philosophies, attitudes and administration. There seems at last to be an understanding that our immigration program must be good for Australia as well as for those who come here. Recent studies have demonstrated the economic benefits of increased immigration provided that the balance and mix of the program is taken fully into account. These studies have endorsed the policies of the Fraser Government and the long history of immigration and population growth administered by the coalition. At last we see some glimmer of understanding and comprehensive, sound goals and sound planning. Some of the economic benefits which accrue to Australia from a substantial immigration intake are obvious if Australia's great periods of growth are looked at in terms of standards of living and capacity for development in competitive industries. The domestic and international advantages of the program are supported by statistics which indicate that jobs are created if skilled people are brought into Australia.

What have been the effects on our economy of the Labor Party's concept of immigration and why has it introduced programs that are skills, knowledge and investment oriented? First, we need to go to the basis of the Labor Party's policy, linked with the wages and incomes accord. When one compares the statistics for the last year of the Fraser Government with those for the first year of the current Government's administration one can see that the previous Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, now the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), caused a complete breakdown in communications and some misunderstandings in the processes he was using. However, subsequently there have been changes in policy and, despite many comments from the previous and the present Ministers, the program has been changed.

Whilst Australia has been generous to the families of migrants in allowing them to come to Australia, the unbalancing effect of the previous decisions imposed upon us some difficulties that can be easily assessed if one looks at the different levels of skill based and family reunion based immigration. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard tables which I will now show to the Minister. They are extracts of departmental figures of the expectations and outcomes of programs for immigration in the various categories. This historical record clearly shows that in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Administration, family reunion immigration was running at a level of about 20,000 persons a year. The present Government has increased family reunion immigration in the various categories to an average of about 40,000 persons a year. At the same time, the number of people entering Australia in the skilled and business investment categories has dropped off from the level that obtained under the previous Government-an average of around 45,000 a year-to around 12,500 for the current year. In fact, the number of people in these categories was at a level of 8,000 a year in the first two years of the Labor Party Administration. It is opportune that we have a Minister who is seeking to give more emphasis to the skills, knowledge and investment categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It is sad to see the results of the Minister's efforts in comparison with those being made by the Government to support our young people in their wish to gain a job. These, of course, are connected. Extravagant statements, which are familiar to the House, were made in June and October when the Government proposed an increase in training opportunities for young people. These increases, in fact, have not been realised, and there is concern in the community that if the Government moves to improve, increase and expand an immigration program it will do so without providing effective training programs and opportunities for our young people.
—I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. I do not see what our programs for young people in Australia have to do with the matter before the House.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—That just demonstrates the concern of the honourable member for Melbourne about these programs. The House will know that the promised 10,000 traineeships by 1 July just will not eventuate. There is no chance that they will eventuate. Therefore I appeal to the Government to adopt a program for immigration and the training of our young people which is mutually compatible. That can be done. There would be no problems. At the very time at which the Labor Party was proclaiming its great economic recovery-that was brought about by the breaking of the drought and the winning of the America's Cup-it actually deleted the most important immigration factor for economic development. When we climbed to the summit to sign the prices and incomes accord, the ALP pushed skilled immigration over the edge. As I have said, it reduced the program to 8,000 a year. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs at that time did not do a great deal for Australia's manpower requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Close family ties have always been acknowledged in Australia's immigration program. We admire the family values expressed by so many migrants. These are values which Australians would do well to emulate if they are really looking for stability and an environment suitable for the successful nurturing of children. The fact is, however, that a strong family reunion program unsupported by a strong skills and investment category of migrants will result in real risks for Australian employment potential. This difficulty can be further exacerbated in a time of economic downturn. We must recognise that 52 percent of family reunion arrivals are semi-skilled or unskilled.

It is essential that a balanced approach to immigration be achieved. Let us see what the Labor Party has done. I have spoken about the changes in the average level of family migration and the changes the Government has introduced in the business and skills program. Dislocation of the labour force was a concern of the Labor Party when coming into office. The Opposition feels that a sound economic policy must be linked with a strong and balanced immigration program. Despite a failure to attract skilled migrants during this year, the Government has set even higher targets for the skilled workers in the coming year. Unless there is reduced control of these categories of the program by the union movement the target will not be reached. The target for this year was a total of 14,000 migrants. The estimated result for the year is 11,000.

Business immigration also suffered a major restriction. A target of 4,500 entrepreneurs yielded only 1,800. The Business Review Weekly of 6 December clearly states that in a survey of vacancy levels, of the 108 companies that responded, 69 per cent said that they had vacancies; 33 per cent said that they were seeking both skilled and unskilled workers; 30 per cent wanted only unskilled workers; and 6 per cent were offering jobs only to skilled people. Surveys across various industries conducted by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the National Australia Bank Ltd confirmed the Business Review Weekly statements. A call by Mr George Schaffer, the Chairman of Calsil Ltd, recently indicated his concern about the level of skilled migration. One has only to read our foreign language newspapers to understand the difficulties that have been experienced by skilled and semi-skilled workers in getting into Australia. La Fiamma of 17 March 1986 stated:

As regards immigration from Italy the Department of Immigration says `that there is no interest'. This flies in the face of allegations that the Australian authorities contribute to the apathy by discouraging potential candidates.

I leave that for the House's judgment, but the Opposition believes that an increase in immigration in the forthcoming year should be for employable and self-employed people. It is misleading and irresponsible to do otherwise. The so-called independent and concessional category has every appearance of being very difficult. Previously this category was confined to the reunion of brothers and sisters of Australian residents. There was a sharp increase from a projected 16,000 to an estimated 28,000 this year. It is now intended that the eligibility be widened but to decrease slightly the number and to increase the difficulty of gaining entry.

I believe that the overseas offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will be flooded by the applications which will come forward and the Government's short term political traction of putting down this program will, in the long term, be damaged because I do not believe that the Government will gain either the skills or the family. I think it will fall between the two and many people will be disappointed. I think that it is a good idea, but I do not think that the Government can administer it. I think that it needs further refinement and I look forward to those refinements. I need to comment on the refugee program, because I am concerned that the Government appears to be combing the world to fill our refugee program, but we are not giving sufficient attention to the very difficult circumstances applying to families in Australia who are separated from families in refugee camps in Thailand and in Vietnam.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Mr Hawke:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to participate in the second reading debate on this measure and to say a number of wide ranging things on this issue on behalf of the Opposition. The Government's Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 is a prime example of symbolic politics. The reality is that this legislation will not do a great deal to meet the real needs of Australian women in the 1980s and yet it is being proclaimed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a major social advance. The Opposition totally supports the concept of equal opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The record of Australian Liberalism in the area of female advancement surpasses that of any political party in this country. The Liberal Party of Australia and its predecessors can boast that this record includes the first woman elected to a State parliament, the first woman appointed to the Federal Ministry and the first woman to become a State President of a major political party. Given the philosophical antecedents of the Liberal Party, this record is not surprising. In 1861 John Stuart Mill argued that society should offer equal opportunities for all its members. Mill argued for `a principle of perfect equality admitting no power or privilege on the one side nor disability on the other side'. The central tenets of this early liberal thinking-equality of opportunity and greater freedom of choice for women-remain central to the goals of the Liberal Party and its policy formulation. The National Party of Australia, our coalition partner, has likewise a strong and unambiguous commitment to equal opportunity and like the Liberal Party, has a very proud record in this area. For example, Mrs Shirley McKerrow is the first woman to head the national organisation of any major political party in Australia.

This commitment merely recognises the enormous contribution of women to the development of Australia. On any analysis the contribution of Australian women to the development of this nation has been quite remarkable. From the very earliest of times a prime example emerges. Although much has been written, for example, of the role of John Macarthur in developing the primitive wool industry that came to be the underpinning of the Australian economy, it is often forgotten that for many years his wife Elizabeth was the driving inspiration behind the development of this industry, and not only during the lengthy periods when John Macarthur was in effective exile.

As is inevitably the case, it is only the famous who are remembered. These range across an enormous field of individual contribution and achievement. Many Australian women have made most important contributions to our society and to activities around the world. If one goes across the whole span, in literature there are people such as Christina Stead, Ruth Park, Joan Lindsay and Colleen McCullough. In the arts there is Judy Cassab. In films there are many actresses such as Judy Davis, Judith Anderson and Anne Lambert. Of course, in sport names such as Betty Cuthbert, Dawn Fraser, Evonne Cawley and Margaret Court come very readily to mind. But the naming of the few only underlines the contribution of the many and the role that they have played in the formation of one of the most remarkably successful and stable nations in the world.

The Liberal and National parties, when last in government, demonstrated a commitment to equal employment opportunity for women. Under the Fraser Government the Equal Employment Opportunity Bureau within the Public Service prospered. In 1981 the Public Service Board instituted a three-stage program designed to introduce voluntary equal employment opportunity for women in departments and authorities. The Board then established two goals for those programs: To increase the number of women in senior management; and to increase the number of women in jobs not traditionally done by women. Moreover, the Fraser Government made a number of important appointments of women to senior positions. It is appropriate to recall that Professor Dame Leonie Kramer was made Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and fulfilled that role with great success and distinction until her totally unjustified removal by the Hawke Government amid much personal vilification in 1983. Yet we hear nothing from the Government about the appointment and the deeds of women of her stamp and calibre. It appears that on occasions the rhetoric of the Hawke Government is not about women in general, but about particular women holding particular attitudes.

The legislation being debated today does not encompass affirmative action. In essence, affirmative action denotes prescriptive, positive discrimination. This Bill, as stated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), does not set quotas; rather, it purports to enshrine the principle of merit for employment or promotion. This Bill in that sense is a welcome step back from the Australian Labor Party's historical predilection for the concept of mandatory prescriptive affirmative action. In Senator Ryan's original 1981 proposal, affirmative action plans would have been required of private corporations with a minimum of 100 employees or those parties to a contract with the Commonwealth to provide goods and services over the value of $50,000. Under Senator Ryan's proposal, those concerned would have had 12 months to develop their plans, and unsatisfactory progress would have attracted a direction from the Commonwealth Government to comply. Failure to comply would have led to a court order. Breach of such an order would have attracted penalties such as fines and prison sentences and, where applicable, termination of Commonwealth contracts and blacklisting for a number of years.

Similarly, the first draft of the Hawke Government's Green Paper, `Affirmative Action for Women', also called for penalties where companies failed to comply with legal requirements under affirmative action legislation. But now the Hawke Government has retreated significantly from its earlier advocacy of prescriptive affirmative action legislation. This retreat has been so marked that the Opposition believes that this Bill has been inappropriately named. Therefore, we will move an amendment to rename this legislation an `equal opportunity in employment Bill'. The coalition is, and will remain, totally opposed to affirmative action legislation, because it implies an enormous bureaucratic interference in the lives of ordinary Australians.

The Opposition fully and unambiguously supports the objective of equal opportunity of employment, and although the Opposition has reservations about the methodology and many of the features of this Bill we have decided not to oppose it because of our deep commitment to the concept of equal opportunity in employment. In reaching this decision the coalition took into account a wide range of views on the legislation. The Opposition recognises that strong and legitimately held views exist in the community about the legislation, particularly in sections of women's groups and organisations. As an example, I note that the Country Women's Association looked at the Bill in detail and it has a number of basic and legitimate concerns about it. In our proposed amendments we have particularly tried to respond to the concerns of organisations such as the CWA.

While the coalition welcomes the fact that this legislation is not as draconian as originally proposed and does not contain sanctions; nevertheless, it does impose a number of regulatory obligations and additional costs and burdens on the business community. The Opposition is concerned at the ever increasing amount of social legislation and regulation, which is particularly hitting hard at small business and farmers. We want to make it emphatically clear that, had we been in government, we would not have introduced this Bill.

In the Senate, the coalition will move a second reading amendment which sets out our general attitudes and reservations about the legislation. The Liberal and National parties fully recognise that many women in society believe, and have reason to believe, that they are discriminated against, and research undertaken both here and overseas clearly indicates that. For example, in an article recently published in the United States of America entitled `What the Republicans have learned about women' it was noted that four out of 10 American women believed that their opportunities had been limited. The study demonstrated that single women were more likely to feel this than were married women. The coalition believes that equal employment opportunity is best achieved through government leadership rather than through prescriptive mandatory legislation. We prefer programs based upon facilitation rather than coercion.

The coalition also believes that in the achievement of equal opportunity in employment more should be made of encouraging voluntary co-operation amongst employers. In our opinion the experience of the voluntary pilot program provided an insight into the way ongoing change is best handled by governments; that is, through the encouragement of voluntary participation, the recognition of effort and the opportunity provided to employers to enjoy the benefits of equal employment opportunities.

This is an appropriate occasion to say a few things about the debate on equal rights and equality of opportunity. The Liberal and National parties' commitment to these goals and concepts is unambiguous. However, the debate on these issues is often characterised by great prejudice and illusory assertions. Fundamental changes in the attitudes of Australian women have occurred, particularly over the past decade. Some of these changes have been accompanied by excessive rhetoric from radical feminist groups, which has done great damage to the cause of successfully achieving the removal of barriers and discrimination which have existed for women. By promoting reverse discrimination and advocating the establishment of barriers for others, many of these groups have given the cause of equality of status a bad name and have produced responses from others in the community which are unnecessarily suspicious in character. Similarly, the excessive zeal shown by some in attempting to change our common and beautiful language usage has led to resentment in wide sections of the community. There can be no equality of opportunity unless chance exists. Real equality opportunity depends upon the availability of choice. Without choice, equality of opportunity is illusory.

The goal of the Liberal and National parties is to provide Australian women with an effective choice in their way of life. It is not and never will be our desire to dictate a stereotype of one kind or another. The question of whether or not a woman or a man is a full time home maker or combines the duties of parenthood with a career ought to be a matter of individual choice. However, it is important to recognise that such choice is totally illusory if the family in question can survive financially only if both parents go out to work. For this reason the Liberal and National parties strongly support income splitting, which will make it easier for low income families to exercise the choice-which is the stated goal of both parties-of one parent remaining at home full time while children are young.

For too long the tax system has discriminated against single income families. This is one of the reasons why the number of married women in the work force who have dependent children has increased. However, I emphasise that that is not the only reason. There has also been a marked change in attitudes as more and more women are properly and effectively exercising a conscious choice to undertake full time careers. A coalition government would also introduce tax deductions for child care expenses. This would recognise the reality that in today's world about 50 per cent of married women with dependent children are part of the work force.

There have been permanent shifts in the way of life of many Australian families. The number of Australian women wanting to combine the responsibilities of parenthood with resuming a career is increasing. The coalition recognises this and has adjusted its policies accordingly. Likewise, the coalition recognises that many women wish to exercise the choice not to undertake full time paid employment while they have young dependent children. Through a commitment to both income splitting and tax deductibility for child care expenses the coalition would facilitate choice and establish the basis for real equality of opportunity. To make this choice effective not only should barriers to advancement of employment be reduced but also the existing rigidity in our market, which makes it so difficult for married women to enter our work force, should be eliminated.

I can think of a few things which would more greatly assist in a practical sense the desire of women to match their parental responsibilities with their desire to re-enter the work force than to have a greater availability of part time work. However, the unpalatable fact is that the trade union movement has persistently held a trog- lodytal attitude towards the achievement of permanent part time work. There is some sign of change in attitude of some trade unions. However, it is too little and, for many Australian women, it is far too late.

The coalition believes that the practical desire of many Australian women to gain greater access to permanent part time work should be facilitated. At present this desire is being thwarted by Australia's rigid and inflexible industrial relations system. The existing centralised industrial relations system penalises individual enterprises which want to make agreements to stagger their working hours to make them more acceptable to female and male employers who have family responsibilities or other interests. Let me give honourable members an example of this. A large number of female employees in a factory in an inner Sydney suburb, all with young children, petitioned management to alter their working hours. Their proposal was that by starting 30 minutes earlier and having only half an hour for lunch they could be at home when their children returned from school-a not unreasonable aspiration. The employer obviously agreed to the proposal. However, the firm was soon informed by the Arbitration Inspectorate that it was in breach of the standard working hours provision of the relevant award and warned that it would be penalised if that common-sense arrangement were allowed to continue. The net result was that they had to go back to the arrangement, which from a common-sense point of view they obviously desired to change. As a result the standard working hours were reinstituted and the children of the workers spent an extra hour of each day without any parental care. That is all the result of the stupid, rigid and inflexible industrial relations system that we have in this country.

It is this rigid and inflexible system, supported by the Hawke Government and the trade union movement, which denies women employment opportunities and the fair go to which Labor is allegedly committed to achieving for them. This is one of the features of the existing industrial relations system that reinforces the coalition's commitment to providing greater choice and freedom in Australia's industrial relations system.

The goal of the changes we propose in this area is to facilitate choice and to provide the basis for real equality of opportunity in employment to be achieved. The legislation currently before the House does not seek to provide this flexibility or choice. Indeed, a number of areas seek to entrench further union power and influence. Compulsory consultations with trade unions are required. This is despite the fact that these were found to be unnecessary and burdensome during the pilot program that preceded this legislation. Therefore, the Opposition will seek the removal of this requirement.

Once again in the legislation we see attempts by the Government to classify sub-contractors as employees for the purposes of the Bill. This reflects the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and seriously threatens the future viability of Australia's sub-contractors. Moreover, it is a grievous violation of human rights because such legislation, if implemented, would force sub-contractors who are not employees and who do not wish to be classified as such to be dragooned into unions against their will in order to please the union bosses at the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The coalition therefore will seek to change the definition of employees contained in the Bill.

While not opposing the legislation the coalition believes that more effective equality of employment opportunities for women could be achieved through major reform in industrial relations and taxation. I have outlined a number of those earlier in my speech. It is sometimes suggested by our opponents that the importance placed by the Liberal and National parties on the family unit as the most basic and important force in our society is somehow inconsistent with the attainment of individual fulfilment by Australian women. Let me say that I and all my colleagues totally reject this notion. It is clear from our policies that the coalition aims to provide greater choice and flexibility to Australian families to allow them to pursue the way of life they desire. This can only enhance the achievement of individual fulfilment.

The coalition will monitor this legislation very closely. We are moving to insert a sunset clause which would require the legislation to be reviewed in five years time. We believe that this is a reasonable time in which to assess the effectiveness and continued need for legislation of this type. It is worth observing that in the editorial in the current edition of the Australian Bulletin of Labour Professor Richard Blandy and Judy Sloan conceded that there was truth in the argument that equal opportunity policies make good commercial sense and that equal opportunity legislation may not be necessary. Professor Blandy and Judy Sloan did not maintain that this argument in itself was strong enough to lead to opposition to the legislation currently before the House. However, they made the claim:

. . . such reservations point to the need to provide some `sunset' clause, such that the provisions of the Bill are not enforced after the period when attitudes have changed and employment procedures generally have been raised to provide for equal opportunity for all workers.

This argument is completely consistent with what the Opposition is proposing in its proposed sunset clause amendment. It is pertinent here to note that the Fraser Government regarded the concept of equal employment opportunity for women as including both the Public Service and statutory authorities. The Hawke Government's Bill does not extend to statutory authorities. The Opposition regards this exclusion as an exercise of great hypocrisy. Apparently it is all right to require private business to meet regulatory requirements in this area, but statutory monopolies such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post are to be left out. The Opposition will test the bona fides of the Government by moving amendments to include within the ambit of the legislation women who are employed in statutory authorities.

Another area left untouched by the legislation is the barriers to women seeking to re-enter the work force. Many Australian women who have been out of paid employment for some time rearing children often decide that they would like to re-enter the work force. After such long periods of absence women's confidence and experience can be low. In addition, they are usually condemned to starting at the lower ranks of the employment ladder unless their qualifications have been updated and they have gained skills associated with new technology. There are few retraining opportunities available to these women and the absence of adult apprenticeships makes their desire to re-enter the work force all the harder to achieve. This failure of the apprenticeship system to allow Australians more easily to exercise a choice to re-enter the labour market in areas of specialist skills is a major reason many women are found in lower paid generalist occupations and is yet another barrier to those women who are left untouched by this legislation. These are areas neglected by the Hawke Government over the past three years. Nothing in this Bill will overcome the lack of opportunity suffered by many women who wish to re-enter the work force.

I have identified five areas left untouched by this symbolic legislation. I have identified freedom of choice in industrial relations, permanent part time work, retraining schemes, income splitting and child care tax relief. Three common threads typify each of the five areas I have raised: Each is more important for women's work opportunities than the legislation before the House; each is already part of the policies of the Liberal and National parties; and each has been effectively rejected by the Hawke Government and the Labor movement. The Opposition will continue to fight to ensure that the opportunities of all Australians are increased in these and other related areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this historic piece of legislation, the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986, and I am pleased that there is a degree of bipartisan support for the Bill.
—Nonsense! There are 28 amendments.

—Those amendments will be attended to in due course. In the meantime, I ask my friend to let me get on with my speech. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) talks about the role of women within the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. That is fair enough. But I ask: How many women are sitting on the Opposition benches? It is true that there is one Liberal member, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan); but there is not one from the National Party in this House, nor is there likely to be one in the future. In his speech the Leader of the Opposition referred in extremely derogatory terms to the industrial relations system as it is today and he indicated that the Opposition's policy is to overthrow that system. I fail to see how the overthrow of the present system will lead to greater equality of opportunity for women. I am sure that it would lead to less.

SPEECH.PARA: The term `affirmative action' is a fairly recent one. It originated in the civil rights movement in the United States of America and the first legislative action in this field came in that country in the early 1960s. I remind the house that history is replete with examples of how women have been given a subordinate role in society. Many of the world's religions, whilst professing equality before God-a male figure- have failed to practise the same equality within their bureaucracies. Recently we have seen the Dean of Perth, the Reverend David Robarts, a very good and sincere man, publicise his displeasure at the ordination of women deacons. The Bishop of Ballarat, Dr John Hazlewood, another good and sincere man, recently stated;
The Bishop is supposed to be the centre of unity within the Church and the appointment of a woman bishop would be a very divisive thing. So I think by definition women cannot be bishops.
What logic! Fortunately, the Anglican Church and many other Christian churches are attempting to grapple with and resolve this problem, but obviously there is still a long way to go.

Until recently the State and Commonwealth Public Services were just as bad, perhaps worse. Women were regarded as temporary rather than permanent and it was not so long ago that a woman who married was requested or required to resign. More recently the Green Paper on Affirmative Action examined the relative status of Australian women with regard to wages, occupational and industrial distribution, hours of work and unemployment. It was found that on average, compared with men, women had low wages, were employed in jobs with low status and with apparently poor promotion prospects and experienced higher unemployment rates. It was also found that women constitute a substantial number of discouraged workers-persons who are interested in work but are not part of the measured unemployed because they have ceased searching for work, given the low probability of obtaining it.

It is against this background of prejudice and discrimination in the work force that this Bill is presented to Parliament. The purpose of the Bill is to eliminate discrimination and to promote equal employment opportunities for women. Its aim is to give women equal opportunity with men to compete for all jobs, since it ensures that people are chosen to do a job depending only on their individual abilities to perform the task required, not on their sex. Affirmative action has become more important when we recognise that the labour force participation by women doubled between 1947 and 1983, from 22 per cent to 44 per cent. Yet most of this increase has been in part time work-a significant factor in terms of financial provision for women in retirement. Affirmative action means that women will no longer be denied chances to gain skills and experience because of certain general assumptions about women. These assumptions are often built into an organisation's employment and promotion policies and practices. They can influence whether people receive training that will help their career prospects in the future.

There are many examples to illustrate this point, but one will suffice. This occurred in a social welfare agency with which I was familiar. The agency proposed to open a branch in a country town. The director assumed that the most senior staff member, a woman, would not be interested in the job transfer because she was married. The job was offered to a less senior member of staff who, of course, happened to be a married man. The senior staff member confronted the director and expressed her interest in the job; but by then it was too late as the decision had been made.

This Parliament has already passed the Sex Discrimination Act which, despite the criticisms of the `tired Tims' and `weary Willies' opposite, has proved to be a sound and useful piece of legislation. However, this Bill is designed to eliminate much of the discrimination against women in employment which the Sex Discrimination Act alone cannot do. Thus this legislation strengthens the Sex Discrimination Act. It is true that a few major companies have introduced a form of affirmative action without government legislation. They are to be applauded for that. But many firms have not expressed or shown any interest in implementing any affirmative action program.

The major example of a company that has attempted to carry out an equal opportunity program is that of Esso Australia Ltd, which in 1979 started a `women in management' program to encourage women to work in the company. Esso deserves praise for its initiative. It is worth exploring the history of this proposal. The firm engaged a female consultant to identify the female employment situation as it then stood and to recommend strategies for change. Having carefully researched the attitudes of women towards the oil industry and attitudes held within the company, she came up with some interesting results which, I feel, are very relevant to this debate. She found-and one would expect this-that traditionally women had not sought employment in the oil industry; that men within the company did not think that the oil industry was an appropriate place for women to work; that men did not believe that women were career orientated or had management potential; and that the few women employed by Esso could not see career opportunities for themselves within the company. These results show the social conditioning and the prejudices to which women have been subjected over the years.

In 1981 the company broadened the program and called it an `equal employment opportunity' program. That the program proved successful can be seen in the results after five years. The proportion of women in the management/professional area of Esso's work force increased in the five-year period from 3 per cent to 11 per cent, or from 22 to 117 women professionals. In the clerical and technical area, the proportion of women increased from 39 per cent to 55 per cent, or from 181 to 291 women. From the firm's point of view the program has been a catalyst for reviewing existing management style, policy, practices and work environment. Unfortunately there have been too few employers prepared to experiment in this area as Esso did. It is because of the failure of the majority of large enterprises in this country to introduce an affirmative action program that the Government has decided to legislate so that women, who for so long have found themselves at the bottom of the labour market, can improve their labour market prospects, and to ensure that women can compete on equal terms with men for promotion.

Before determining the Government's position on the issue, the Prime Minister in June 1984 tabled a policy discussion paper titled `Affirmative Action for Women'. At the same time the Government established an affirmative action pilot program. As we have already heard in this debate, 28 large private sector companies and three higher education institutions accepted the Prime Minister's invitation to participate in the program, which lasted 12 months and concluded in July 1985. At the same time the Government established a representative working party on affirmative action legislation. It was chaired by Senator Susan Ryan, the excellent Minister for Education, and included those representing Government, business, trade unions, higher education authorities, women's organisations, and the Opposition. Its task was to monitor the pilot program.

The working party's report was released in November 1985. Its major recommendation was for the introduction of legislation to require all higher education institutions and private sector employers with 100 or more staff to develop and implement affirmative action programs for women. Another recommendation referred to the need to remove legislative restrictions to women's employment, while not, of course, jeopardising the safety or health of any worker. Many of these restrictions are within the jurisdiction of State governments and it will require the co-operation of those governments with the Commonwealth for them to be removed. The major recommendations are being acted on by this Government and this Bill illustrates that fact. A timetable has been set up for the introduction of affirmative action in this country and it will be phased in over several years. It will apply first to Australia's 19 universities and 46 colleges of advanced education. They will be required to commence their affirmative action programs on 1 August 1986 and to make their first reports by 1 August 1987.

The legislation does not apply to small business but will apply to all private sector organisations which employ 100 or more staff. But initially only firms employing 1,000 or more employees will be required to comply with the legislation. The commencement date for such firms is 1 February 1987, and their first report will be a year later on 1 February 1988. It is interesting to note that there are 510 employers with more than 1,000 staff. Those employers with between 500 and 999 employees will be phased in to the program on 1 February 1988. Those employing between 100 and 499 employees will be phased in on 1 February 1989. One can see that this is a carefully thought out program which recognises that there will be problems in industry and which will phase in the substance of the Bill. It is true that some costs will be incurred by organisations and businesses required to participate in the program. However, the Australian Commissioner of Taxation has made a ruling that the expenses incurred by employers in implementing affirmative action will be deductible under section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

This Government believes in consultation. This was shown in the steps-which I have already outlined-taken by the Government in preparing the Bill. The Bill provides for the establishment of a representative advisory committee to provide advice to the Minister and the Director. It is anticipated that the Minister will appoint committees to provide general advice or a committee might be established to advise on a particular industry or occupation. This Bill is a major Government initiative which is designed to remove any existing obstacles to women fully participating in the Australian work force. It deserves the support of all members of this House and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is little doubt that every member of this chamber would be very seriously committed to the principle of equal opportunity in employment. Surely, there is not one of us who would endorse any discrimination against any person on the basis of sex, creed or skin colour. There would, I hope, be unanimity in the viewpoint that merit and capacity to satisfactorily perform would be the criteria for selection in employment, and that whatever the sex, colour or creed of the applicants there should be equality of opportunity. In a nation which can honestly claim to be one of the few genuine democracies on earth, which prides itself on believing in a fair go, and which, with perhaps less justification, describes itself as a Christian nation, human dignity, human rights and rejection of discrimination are values which we ought to cherish and ought to defend. Having said that, I am compelled to observe that this type of legislation-the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill-and the Sex Discrimination Act and the Australian Bill of Rights Bill are not the correct course to achieve these desirable goals.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said in debates on previous legislation-and I say it again in relation to this Bill-it is folly, dangerous and even discriminatory to attempt to legislate these values. Whenever we try to legislate to give rights, protections or opportunities we simultaneously reduce the rights, protections or opportunities of someone else. This Bill suffers from that same defect. When the debate on the sex discrimination legislation ensued we were assured that that Bill was not objectionable or revolutionary. My observation then was that it was providing a base on which successive affirmative action Bills would later erect an edifice, a system, which would be revolutionary, objectionable and itself discriminatory. It might be claimed that this Bill does not fall into that category, but it is the first step along the road. It will be joined by others and I fear it will lead us into the sorts of changes in society, in the family, and in attitudes that are not desirable. That is one of the reasons, even though I value the principles of equal opportunity, human dignity and human rights, for my objection to this Bill. We must not only examine the detailed provisions of the Bill, but also soberly consider where it will inevitably lead.

Another reason is that it is an insult to Australian employers, for it is an accusation that the only way discrimination will be avoided is by force of legislation. Surely it is obvious that it is by education, by voluntary acceptance, that we can reach a goal. By coercion and compulsion we not only fail to reach that goal, but indeed create a society far different from what is desired.

In introducing this Bill, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that initially it would apply to employers and organisations employing 1,000 or more employees, although it would then further extend to those employing over 500 and then, further to employers of 100, although that can extend even further if the number falls to 80 employees. In effect, he said that it involves only large employers and does not cover small business. Whilst literally what he says is correct, it is patently obvious that this is but the harbinger of further future legislation which will cover small business, for no one would believe that this would be the final and only legislation along the road to affirmative action.

Quite obviously, the history of the Government shows the inevitability of that course. For example, in the accord conference where big business had a seat and small business was excluded, the compliance of big business, which was able to absorb the demands, the cost and the imposts of decisions made at that conference, resulted in those burdens flowing on to small business, which had no such capacity. When the Prime Minister states that this legislation will cover only larger employers, small business knows and can be sure that there will be no long term immunity for it irrespective of the dislocation and impracticability which it will visit upon it.

The Prime Minister must have had his tongue in his cheek when he said that the Government was determined that this reform would not be unnecessarily bureaucratised and that employers would not be burdened with unnecessary paper work. In direct contradiction, he then went on to say that employers would be required to provide a least two reports a year, as well as other paper work and information. There has to be a breakdown of employees by sex and job classifications-more paper work. There has to be a description of the affirmative action program-more paper work. This is provided to a director who, presumably, like the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Taxation Office, the companies' office, the sales tax office and a host of other offices, will seek more information and will generate questions and correspondence-still more paper work and regulation. So we have bureaucracy, and we have a burden of paper work-both of which have the inbuilt propensity to multiply.

There has to be a policy statement. Staff members must be allocated to the program; indeed, there is already an admission that employers will be required to allocate both staff and resources to the program. Who could possibly believe that this will be mainly in the initial stages, and who could possibly doubt that the requirements of staff and resources will increase as time goes on? I have never yet seen the director, or encountered the bureaucracy which reduces its demand. Indeed, was there ever a director or bureaucracy which did nor generate more and more, demands, requirements, forms and paperwork? Mr Deputy Speaker, did you ever see a director who so failed to uphold the traditions of the Public Service that he failed to create around him an ever expanding department? I suppose it is one way to create jobs, but they are the wrong types of jobs. In the private sector it will add to costs, it will add to regulation and it may well be the straw to break the camel's back.

Inevitably, the unions will be directly involved, looking over the shoulder. A government so beholden to the trade union movement which is hell bent on compulsory unionism-the superannuation venture is an undisguised move towards that goal-now gives the unions another weapon. The unions must be consulted. They will be looking at classifications et cetera. The Prime Minister calls it a `profile'. I guarantee that they will demand each employee has a union ticket. The Director, the ever helpful unions, will review all policies and practices. The employer will have no peace and will have increased pressure on him. Then, in his spare time, the employer will be required to set objectives and forward estimates, to evaluate and monitor these annually, and to submit all sorts of reports on them. What a big brother situation is being created.

The Prime Minister says that employers are not required to take any action which is incompatible with the merit system. This is both illogical and in contradiction with all the sentiments which preceded this profound statement. If the merit system is to prevail, and any employer who wants to maximise his efficiency and profits would employ on merit, why have we this legislation? Why the emphasis on obtaining statistical balance? Why the bi-annual reports to the Director? Why the consultation with the unions? Why all of the reports and all of the projections if the merit system is to prevail? Is the merit system to apply only if the applicant is female? Is the Director or the union going to be the arbiter if the applicant with superior merit is male and is preferred over a female but the statistical balance is askew? Obviously there are severe qualifications to the Prime Minister's statement that there is no requirement incompatible with the merit system. There is a severe restriction on the employer's capacity to choose the most effective staff. His rights of choice are circumscribed and he has the pressure of being under the eye of a director who must have more cognisance of the intent of the Act and his role than of the efficient operation of business.

The Prime Minister also said that there will be no quotas and no reverse discrimination. Again, this is hard to visualise. If the merit system, no quotas and no reserve discrimination are to prevail, what can possibly be the purpose or point of this legislation or legislation like it? What a position of power is given to the Director, who not only is to receive the reports et cetera, but also is to advise and assist-whatever that means-which virtually gives him power to direct the employment policies of businesses.

We come then to the nub of the matter. This new arm of government will have a director, presumably with a personal staff, initially an interim agency within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to be subsumed later, we are told, by a permanent agency and then representative advisory committees. Then the Minister `might'-I guess that should be `will'-appoint committees to provide general advice, or a committee to advise on a particular industry or occupation. What marvellous potential for a growth industry of advisers and supervisors-what marvellous opportunities to provide openings for jobs for the boys, retired unionists and militant feminists.

Then there is the penalty, the punitive provision. If the Director does not receive reports or information or response to requests, or does not like them, he has the power to name in a report to the Parliament, a public document, the employer who displeases him. We are expected, of course, to be overjoyed and comforted that the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the de facto government of this nation, has prepared an affirmative action manual to assist trade union members and officials to make a useful contribution to the development of affirmative action in Australia. I will bet it has! That is who is leading the orchestra, that is who is pulling the strings-as if we did not already know.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are out of tune.

—They are out of tune, indeed. The Bill also covers Australia's 19 universities and 46 colleges of advanced education. I would have liked to have said something about that but this matter has already been covered by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) and I endorse his remarks in that regard. The Prime Minister will be writing to the State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on the matter of child care facilities for staff. Russia and China might be willing to provide the sketch plans for the system that seems to be envisaged here-a system that they have developed fairly well. However, we should note that the system is far from utopian and is destructive of family and family values.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to another criticism of this legislation. With the Australian economy in tatters, with the deficit at an alarming level, with interest rates at record levels, with bureaucratic growth causing such concern, the Government chooses to divert to such projects as this funds and resources which certainly would be better applied to the alleviation of hardship and poverty. What queer priorities this Government has. With all the talk about the level of unemployment and the need for more jobs, we embark on this course. The only jobs it will create are those for more bureaucrats, but it has the inbuilt potential to destroy many jobs. It has the potential to cause unrest and uncertainty among employees who can lose their jobs if affirmative action deposes them. As more and more paper work, regulation and direction is imposed on business, employers are more and more loath to expand their work force and provide more jobs. Indeed, the reverse applies.

For all the rhetoric and all the platitudes, it is difficult to comprehend how affirmative action, if it is effective and pursued, is not reverse discrimination. It must be. If all the soothing words of the Prime Minister were literally true, there would be so many qualifications that this legislation would be useless, toothless and meaningless. I repeat that he has said that merit will prevail, there will be no quotas and no reverse discrimination. Why then do we have the legislation, unless it is to be effective, punitive and the precursor of more legislation for affirmative action?

Already this Government has penalised by taxation and regulated and interfered with business unduly and extensively. Now it proposes to intervene even further. Everywhere I go, people in business tell me that all they want is for government to get off their backs. They certainly will not offer any prayers of thanks for this new and ominous intervention. We already have enough laws and regulations to tackle discrimination, if we have the determination to apply them. Further regulation and compulsion is not the path to the desirable aim of equal opportunity. Women ought not to be denied equal opportunity. On the basis of merit women ought to be able to obtain jobs, and if their qualifications are superior they have every right to expect preferment. But legislation which, on the basis of statistical balance or compulsion, under the pseudonym of affirmative action, inhibits an employer in the capacity to consider merit and efficiency and places gender as the overriding consideration has no merit and is bad legislation.

I abhor discrimination. I applaud equality of opportunity. I believe in the dignity of the human being. I oppose the denigration or suppression of human rights. The legislation this Government is trundling into the Parliament advances us not one centimetre along the road to attaining those aims-aims which I believe are common to every one of us, no matter on which side of the House we sit. Indeed, I have repeatedly said that compulsion in legislation is counter-productive and ineffective. It matters little whether it has a benign countenance; it will evolve into something more draconian, more intrusive and more confusing.

We seek the voluntary and co-operative removal of the barriers of discrimination. For all the words of the Prime Minister about voluntary participation and the desire to avoid a punitive approach, this Bill does provide punitive recourse. It does set down targets-another name for quotas-to be achieved within certain time scales. It does coerce. It does subject business to providing staff and resources to comply with the provisions of the Bill. It does involve regulation. It involves massive paperwork. It involves reporting and inquisition. It does lay the groundwork for further expansion of the bureaucracy. It does direct funds and resources, at a time of economic upheaval, into a program which certainly must have a lesser priority than other areas to redress unemployment, dampen inflation, put people into homes and reduce interest rates. With the need to restrain government expenditure and control growth of the bureaucracy, with government paying lip service to those goals and in the same breath pledging to deliver on the trilogy and cut taxes, we have the spectacle of funds and resources-they will be massive-being directed into this new area and a bureaucracy being established to service it. For all the reasons I have stated and because the priorities of this Government confound all logic and common sense, I cannot support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Affirmative action as an issue was placed on the political agenda by the women's movement in the 1970s but it took this Government to recognise it as an important electoral issue. I remind the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), that this is something the people of Australia want. It took this Government to set in motion the mechanisms needed to ensure that the status of women in Australia was recognised and that it would be one of equality with men. Our overall record is one of which we can be proud. In the space of three years we have legislated for the legal right of equal treatment through the Sex Discrimination Act. We have established an affirmative action pilot program for women in the private sector work force, and we have legislated for equal opportunity in the Commonwealth Public Service. Now, today, we are debating in this chamber the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, which will provide for the legal right of women to equal employment opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition to this Bill from reactionary forces in society and certainly from the reactionary forces opposite is quite extraordinary. One has only to mention affirmative action to those forces and the alarm bells are set off, producing deep emotional responses from both reactionary men and reactionary women. This very conservative minority feels threatened by this legislation and does not want to contemplate the prospect of change because it may affect their privileged position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you get here on that basis?

—I am the only woman from New South Wales ever to get here. I abhor the fact that I am the only woman member from New South Wales in this chamber. I do not want to protect my privileged position; I want to see many more women come here. The women who fear affirmative action are those who were referred to by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) in his speech yesterday. He said that he had talked to women of ability and achievement who feared that affirmative action would be counterproductive. Do honourable members know why? They said it is because their value as role models will disappear. Do honourable members think I am happy in my position as a role model? I would like to be one of many women in this place. Do any men need role models to progress in the work force? I think the honourable member for Wentworth was speaking only to those women who have made it.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation aims to help a lot more women on the shop floor to equal opportunity in the work force. They are the women to whom this Bill is addressed.
