As well as ensuring that women have a place in the work force and are paid equal remuneration, this Bill has as its premise that women should not be treated as wives or mothers only because men are not treated as husbands or fathers only or, by the way, as role models only. Any program of preference which will ensure equal opportunities for different roles strikes at the very heart of traditional attitudes and the gender-based division of labour within the family and in the work force.

Some opposition to the Bill will continue until it becomes clear that men and women working together on an equal footing can create the genuinely egalitarian society that most Australians desire and that we all boast about.

It is not just over the last decade that women in the workforce have been struggling for equality; it has been going on almost since the turn of the century. Let us look at the situation in relation to wages. In 1907, the sexual division of labour was enshrined in the wage fixing system in Australia when Mr Justice Higgins, then President of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, was called on to decide what constituted a fair and reasonable wage. He determined the basic minimum wage of 42 shillings per week. That was the amount he considered an unskilled worker required to support a wife and three children. In 1912, the female basic wage was arbitrated under the leadership of Mr Justice Higgins. The single unit female wage was set at 60 per cent of the male family unit wage. Single female wage occupation rates were set so as to support a single woman.

In 1916, Mr Justice Powers defined women's work as intrinsically of less value and determined that the basic value of women's work was only 58 per cent of that of men. In 1919, Mr Justice Higgins reduced it to 54 per cent. It was the view at the time that males were the proper breadwinners, and it is likely that a consequence of that judgment was the formulation of the social valuations of what constituted the appropriate female wage. The effect of this decision not only has helped maintain the existing framework of inequity in the work force but also, over the years, has discouraged investment in female education. It has also discouraged women from obtaining vocational training and has encouraged them to remain in occupations which are relatively lower paid.

In 1942, the Women's Employment Board was established and a different set of judgments made. Female award rates for male jobs were set at 90 per cent of those of men. This had little to do with the acknowledgment of women's work in society. It would appear that it was a response to the labour shortage in wartime emergency. While this decision was for `the duration only', the war and changes in the Australian economy which followed it brought home to society in general and to women in particular the importance of women's labour.

The Arbitration Court could no longer justify allowing women only 54 per cent of the male wage, and, in 1950, it increased the female basic wage to 75 per cent. Obvious changes in the social valuation perspective came about first in the equal pay case of June 1969, and the notion of equal pay for work of equal value was institutionalised in the equal pay case of 1972. So, it took from 1912 to 1972, a space of 60 years, to recognise and accept the notion of equal pay for work of equal value. Attitudes change very slowly indeed. In 1972, we won the equal pay case. In 1986, we still have not achieved equal pay and we still have a long way to go. Anti-discrimination policies are a very necessary part of achieving the goal of equal employment opportunities and the Government has recognised that. No legislation in itself is sufficient to improve the labour market position of women. Many issues still remain to be solved. Equal pay and child care are issues that are still not resolved. The provision of affordable child care facilities must be regarded as essential to any affirmative action program, not just for women but for men as well. Until enough child care places are provided, maternity leave provisions are useless for many women. The provision of and access to adequate housing for single women with children are other areas which must be addressed if equal opportunity is to be made available to women in all social circumstances.

The evaluation of skills of women and the meaning of merit are issues which the women's movement must continue to raise if we are ever to achieve real economic justice for women. For example, 34 per cent of all female workers are in the clerical occupational category and 23 per cent of these are stenographer/typists. To put the value of their skills, their merits and talents is very different from suggesting that some stenographers might want to move into administration or management. In the nursing profession developing clinical skills is not financially rewarded, but moving into administration is. Some women prefer to be secretaries or nurses rather than becoming administrators and their work should be properly valued and properly rewarded. The undervaluation of what is traditionally women's work means that women continue to be doubly disadvantaged. Steps have been taken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to address this question. It has a comparable worth case on behalf of Australian nurses before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, although the progress on this case is slow, I am confident that the ACTU will be successful in winning the case for equal pay because, if this case is rejected, the likelihood of achieving equal economic status between the sexes will be set back quite dramatically. Another consequence of this rejection would be that many males would continue not to be attracted into this traditionally female occupation because the incentives are simply not there.

The concept of comparable worth is contained in provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women and must be supported in light of Australia's ratification of that Convention. The affirmative action pilot program which preceded this legislation involved 28 large private sector companies and three higher education institutions. One significant employer of women in the private sector and a participant in the pilot program was G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd. I wonder whether the honourable member for Wentworth talked to any of the women working at Coles. Coles has approximately 3,000 managerial staff overseeing about 40,000 full and 30,000 part time staff and only a handful are women. It will be a long slow haul to rectify this situation, but at least Coles is willing to try. It has now appointed equal opportunity officers whose existence may remind management and staff that Coles is indeed part of a program to encourage women to apply for the same positions as men. Telecom Australia, another participant in the scheme, wasted no time in producing a comprehensive booklet outlining the program and offering practical advice on how to put it into practice in every department.

In New South Wales, equal employment opportunity programs have been in existence for some time both in the public and private sector. One successful program conducted by Esso Australia Ltd originated from a women in management program in 1979. This program presented all the challenges of any program of change. The concept of introducing women into a traditional male industry was found initially to be uncomfortable for many male employees who felt threatened by the influx of the new women. They thought these women would be given special treatment. The company also found that the program was disruptive and that the initiative questioned values and attitudes that had been built into the company over a long period, but it persisted with the program. The result is that today the number of women in the management/professional area of Esso's work force has increased from 22 to 137 women professionals. These women include 11 engineers, 17 geo- scientists, 31 accountants and 20 computer specialists. Over the same period the attrition rate for women fell from 50 per cent to 10 per cent. I wonder whether the honourable member for Wentworth spoke to any of those women, because they are the women who have benefited from an affirmative action program. In the clerical and technical area the number of women has increased from 39 per cent to 55 per cent or from 181 to 291 women. This recruitment included technicians, apprentices and trainee gas plant operators within non-traditional working areas, and that is an excellent example of what affirmative action programs will achieve. Mr J. Kirk, the managing director of Esso said:

The program has been a catalyst for reviewing existing management style policy practices and work environment. In terms of contribution to the company, the women, like the men, range from top performers to poor performers. They have added new perspectives to the way ESSO has dealt with issues, and they have changed the work environment for the better.

Let me add that they have changed the work environment for the better for everyone including the male employees. As usually happens when there is any challenge to the existing system made by women on behalf of women, it also improves the position of the men working in that institution. Any challenge to the system on behalf of disadvantaged women helps the disadvantaged men.

As I have said earlier, Australian women are disadvantaged by social attitudes and, once employed, they face systematic discrimination from training and promotion patterns in both public employment and private enterprise. Women also experience greater unemployment and under-employment. There are far more women than men in part time employment and less secure jobs partly because they bear the main responsibility for the care of children and other dependants. This Government recognises this. The affirmative action program will undoubtedly identify many more problems and clarify new challenges for government. Our Government has the commitment to face those challenges. We have taken the first steps in introducing the Sex Discrimination Act and the affirmative action legislation, both of which have been accepted programs in many countries for many years. It took a Federal Labor Government to take this important step in Australia. In the pilot program it has done so in a way which was not only efficient but attracted the acceptance and co-operation of the majority in the business sector, the tertiary education sector and the trade union movement.

For those who doubt the need for this legislation-and that appears to be many honourable members on the other side-let me refer to a recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report which states:
Girls are underserved and channelled into educational and training paths to lower paying, lower status, jobs. Access to higher education is biased against girls and disadvantaged young people.

This OECD report makes particular mention of the shameful situation in Australia. In another section of the report it is mentioned that, without extraordinary measures, girls and young women will not be able to overcome firmly entrenched patterns of discrimination, lower wages and occupational segregation. The Sex Discrimination Act and this affirmative action legislation are part of those measures needed to overcome those patterns. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great difficulty in debating legislation of the kind presently before the House is that difficult and complex concepts are reduced to one line slogans. If one is for affirmative action legislation, one is automatically described as enlightened and supportive of women's rights. If one is against affirmative action legislation, one is described as prejudiced, narrow-minded and against the rights of women. In truth, neither cliche accurately portrays the proponents for and against affirmative action legislation. The same sincerity that is conferred without question upon proponents of affirmative action legislation is not extended to its opponents. It is a much employed tactic of strident minority groups to paint those representing the majority of the Australian community as repressive or in some way undemocratic.

SPEECH.PARA: Equal opportunity for women is a much valued principle. No woman should ever suffer discrimination on the basis of sex, although we know that such discrimination occurs far too broadly in our society for any of us to be satisfied. The legislation before the Parliament is an attempt by the Government, and a number of genuine and perhaps even sincere members of the Government, to attack that discrimination. However, I must say that I, for one, oppose this legislation on two broad grounds. Firstly, I believe affirmative action legislation is reverse discrimination and inconsistent with the principle of equal opportunity and, secondly, I believe the cost to business, and in turn consumers, is not justified.

I wish to summarise the main components of the legislation to substantiate the two limbs of my opposition. To whom will the legislation apply? It will apply to universities and colleges of advanced education by 1 August 1986. It will apply to organisations employing 1,000 and more staff by 1 February 1987, organisations employing between 500 and 1,000 staff by 1 February 1988 and organisations employing between 100 and 500 staff by 1 February 1989. You can immediately grasp, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this legislation will apply to a very large section of the private sector. To my mind there are a number of organisations employing 100 and more staff which can be termed as small businesses and to whom this legislation and all the red tape and reporting provisions imposed will provide and cause extra costs at a time when we know that no business can possibly sustain further cost pressures from government. These organisations will be required to provide two reports annually to a new Director of Affirmative Action. One will be a public document and the second, which will be in far greater detail, will be confidential. Failure to comply with the legislation requiring the handing in of reports to the Director of Affirmative Action will result in the Director of Affirmative Action naming those companies in the report to be tabled in the Federal Parliament.

What must those companies do which they will report to the Director of Affirmative Action? A company must issue a policy statement to employees. It must confer responsibility for an affirmative action program within the company upon a person of proper standing or authority. It must consult at length and in great detail with the trade union movement or as many as possible of the trade unions which have members within that organisation. It must consult with employees. It must collect and record statistics and other information. It must review policies and practices. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see immediately that these organisations will be involved in a great deal of detail which will take a fair amount of time and at a certain cost.

All of this is leading up to the most strident of the demands upon these organisations-that is, these organisations must set objectives and forward estimates. Every Government member will argue that this legislation does not set quotas; it does not in some way promote women on the basis of gender rather than merit. All Government members will argue that it is different from the American legislation, which requires that a certain number of women fill a certain number of higher managerial positions. But the Government is not just splitting hairs to differentiate between quotas and forward estimates; it is playing with the truth. It is a matter of semantics. Is something navy blue or dark blue? One cannot differentiate between those descriptions. If organisations are required to prepare estimates of promotion of women to certain positions, in my view this is certain to lead to quotas. I find the argument that this legislation does not impose quotas to be quite incorrect. The setting of targets will result in quotas.

The legislation establishes a Director of Affirmative Action with some 25 staff and a budget of $1.5m annually. That is the initial expense. We have no doubt whatever that the number of staff and the budget will increase over the years. It is yet another statutory organisation to add to the dozens, if not hundreds, already in place. We know the Senate has had enormous difficulty in even obtaining the number of quangos and statutory authorities responsible to the Federal and State governments. This will add to that number. It is an unwarranted intrusion into management. It will mean extra cost and regulation and it gives further authority to the trade union movement in what is properly the sphere of management. The Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry have opposed this legislation.

The legislation requires organisations to make forward estimates which under clause 8 (3) are defined as a quantitative measure or aim which may be expressed in numerical terms. Honourable members are delving into the realms of the ridiculous if they do not interpret `forward estimate' to be `quota'. It is a measure of this Government's dishonesty that it has not had the courage of its own convictions to introduce legislation which will properly and honestly reflect its intentions. This is merely a first step which it knows is certain to be passed by the Senate, thereby allowing it at a future date to increase the scope of the legislation.

I oppose the legislation not only because of its impact upon business and hence the consumer, but also because philosophically I am unable to support it. I do not believe it will help women. I believe that the statement of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), who told us in a grandiose manner that this legislation will help the woman on the shop floor, was nothing short of ridiculous. This legislation will not assist women for whom I think there are compelling reasons for affirmative action-women, such as migrants, who have language difficulties, women who work on true shop floors, on production lines. This legislation, as with the sex discrimination legislation, the Bill of Rights and the plethora of State legislation, will assist the tertiary educated women who are aware of their rights at law and who are qualified in any event. I do not believe it will help the women to whom I believe we ought to be giving far greater assistance. Goodness knows, it is quite irrelevant to that very large group of women in our society who have chosen to remain at home and raise children. As always, the Parliament, under this Government, is obsessed with women in the work force at the expense, I hasten to say, of women in the family home.

A great many women oppose this legislation. The National Party is represented by women in every parliament, at both State and Federal levels. Women occupy positions at the highest levels of our political organisation. They oppose it. It is the formal policy of the National Party's women's section to oppose it. The Country Women's Association opposes it. A great many women in industry, in whatever managerial position one likes to think of, oppose it because in many ways it reflects upon them. Did they achieve promotion and success on the basis of merit and qualification or simply on the basis of gender? For that reason, I believe that it is demeaning to a great many women. It will give preference on the basis of gender alone, and the best people will not always get the job. In drawing to a conclusion, may I say again that I oppose this legislation. However much following Government speakers will seek to portray me as such, I do not in any way oppose the concept, principle and implementation of equal opportunity, but I do not support affirmative action legislation which is discriminatory in concept, expensive in practice, and which ignores the women and a great many people in society for whom we ought to have far more concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is somewhat disappointing that this Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill needs to be introduced at all. I refer to the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who said that, had we followed the philosophy and dictum of the philosopher John Stuart Mill that all people in our society should be treated equally, there would be no need for this Bill. However, that gentleman's words were not heeded, and it must be pointed out that such has been the discrimination against women in this country and the lack of response by employers, both public and private, to appeals to redress the situation and treat women as equal partners with men that the Government has been forced to step up the appeal through this legislative framework. In short, reason and moral pressure alone have failed. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in introducing this Bill, `this legislation is necessary to ensure that all large employers take seriously their obligations to their women employees'-and, I might add, to potential women employees.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is the second of two Bills introduced into Parliament by this Government to honour Australia's obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which was signed, I point out, by the Fraser Government in July 1980 and which was ratified by the Hawke Government three years later. The first Bill, the Sex Discrimination Bill, passed into law in August 1984. This Bill, then, is further tangible evidence of our commitment to enhance employment opportunities for women. It is unbelievable that members of a former government which signed an international covenant now oppose in part or in full the principle of affirmative action enshrined in this Bill and hence deny their obligations under that covenant now that they are in the Opposition. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and his colleagues in the National Party of Australia have placed on record their intention to oppose this Bill. Their hypocrisy, confusion or desire for political expediency is exceeded only by their two-faced attitude towards the human rights legislation, now in another place, although they signed and ratified the international covenant on which that legislation is based.

Many approaches can be taken to increase the entry of women into the work force and to promote women up the ladder of seniority. Quotas could be imposed and hard targets could be set to increase the number of women in the workplace and to ensure greater representation of women at different levels. But, contrary to what the honourable member for Gippsland said, the Government is not following the American approach; we are not setting targets or quotas. That policy of positive discrimination has been specifically rejected by the Government as being unworkable and undesirable. It is unworkable because our society for too long has been sexist in its promotion of people for different jobs. Women have been told to stay in the home, to stay with the family and to provide for the males of the household. When they undertake their education, girls and women are channelled into female studies-the `soft options' rather than the sciences, which are still dominated by men. When they enter employment they are channelled into assistant positions to male professionals and into what is known as traditional female work, usually the lowest paid and with the least prospects of advancement. A quota system or targets cannot work if we have not prepared and educated our women to accept equality themselves, nor men to accept women as equals. To work, affirmative action must be planned and introduced over a period and at a pace appropriate to particular workplaces. This Bill does just that.

Positive discrimination, where women would be employed or promoted before or over men just because they are women, would be an undesirable route to take as it transgresses the principle of merit. For far too long the principle of merit has been largely ignored as men have been favoured over women on the ground of gender for senior positions and as men have been pushed into education opportunities which have led to higher paid and higher status positions in the work force. We cannot redress that bias by revising the impact so that it favours women. We cannot right one wrong with another without paying the penalty of eventual failure through hypocrisy and double standards. Further, let us heed the recent warning of Dr Peter Wilenski, Chairman of the Public Service Board, that the concept of merit must not be distorted and that it must mean that the best person gets the job rather than its being a tool of those in power for maintaining the status quo. Dr Wilenski said:

Standards of merit, either deliberately or unconsciously, were often based on the values, style and priorities of the dominant male groups in the organisation. The tendency of organisations to recruit, train and select for similarity-in other words, cloning or homosocial reproduction, has become widely recognised.

Merit, then, is the centre principle of this legislation and the Bill properly defines the affirmative action program as measures designed to eliminate discrimination and to promote equal opportunity for women; that is, to promote merit and to banish those practices, biases and prejudices against women which work to ignore merit. This legislation is not a whim of government; it is not hard ideology forced upon the public by a party but is the outcome of almost two years of consultation, pilot programs and reports. To test the Government's policy discussion paper tabled here in mid-1984, a pilot program involving large private sector firms and higher education institutions was run for some 12 months. A representative working party with members of government, trade unions, business, higher education, women's organisations, and even the Opposition, monitored the pilot program and this legislation is based on the report of that working party which was released late last year. Despite the various opinions of such a diverse group, remarkably, a common approach towards affirmative action emerged and recommended that legislation be introduced requiring all higher education institutions and private sector employers with 100 or more staff to develop and implement affirmative action programs for women.

Australia's 19 universities and 46 colleges of advanced education will be at the leading edge of the affirmative action program and will be required to commence their programs by 1 August this year, with their first reports to be made to the Director of Affirmative Action a year later. I point out that many institutions have jumped the gun and commendably have already begun programs to improve women's employment opportunities. To be successful it was important that higher education be chosen as the spearhead for the fight against prejudice and in favour of merit. Universities and colleges play a crucial role in Australian society. They educate the educators and thus are instrumental in influencing, and indeed defining, our systems of belief, our knowledge and views about society and the roles men and women should play in society. It is essential, therefore, that these institutions be in the forefront of positive social change. They must provide genuine equality of opportunity for students and staff alike, and they must be seen to do so. Women will never achieve equality in society unless such equality exists in our educational institutions, which are the source both of career opportunities and of important opportunities for the self-development of individuals.

The existence of female academics as role models for women students and potential students, at all levels and in all subject areas, is imperative if we are to achieve equal opportunity for women in education and in Australian society. I adamantly and wholeheartedly reject the comments made yesterday by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) that in his view the appointment and promotion of `notorious feminists' in universities has led to the dropping of standards. Our universities and colleges are also the centres which provide the education and training to those who wish to enter the work force or those who need to retrain or update their knowledge and skills.

The broadening of access to higher education for women is an essential pre-condition for any broad based affirmative action policy or legislation to cover the Australian work force in general. The honourable member for Gippsland should note well that if we are to do anything for women on the shop floor, women in factories, we have to indicate throughout our education system that we are prepared to give them a better deal so that their daughters will see a different world from the one they themselves have experienced. The attitudes of our teachers, welfare and medical workers are also deeply affected by their experiences in higher education and it is important that they exit from higher education with attitudes towards women which exhibit all the best features of affirmative action. It can be seen that higher education institutions, as well as initiating affirmative action within their own walls and halls, can reinforce affirmative action by being seen to implement the program as well as talk about it.

A week or so ago, a woman, Professor Di Yerbury, was appointed Vice-Chancellor of Macquarie University in Sydney. A month earlier two universities in Victoria announced the appointment of women to top positions. The Council of the University of Melbourne elected Fay Marles as its Deputy Chancellor to replace Davis McCaughey, the new Governor of Victoria, and Margaret Cameron was appointed Pro Vice Chancellor of Deakin University. Surely, then, with these appointments, all is right in the academic world regarding equal opportunity for women. Sadly, these important and laudatory appointments do not represent the general scheme of things; they are isolated top level appointments. Professor Yerbury's appointment to Vice-Chancellor was in fact the first in Australia's history. I congratulate her on that achievement. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing women's employment in higher education, compiled by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the Government's Green Paper on affirmative action for women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It can be seen that there has been only a minor increase in the total percentage of women occupying teaching and research positions over the six years 1979 to 1984 inclusive and that women remain heavily clustered in the lower ranked positions. This immense imbalance not only is due to bias in selection procedures towards males, and the discouragement towards women undertaking higher levels of post-graduate education over the years, but also can be traced to the obstacles placed before women who wish to pursue an academic career. Two major examples of those obstacles are the increase in contract or short term employment which has brought about a two-class structure of jobs within the system, and the absence of child care facilities on campus. The matter of child care facilities was covered, quite correctly and quite well, by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) earlier in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A peculiar feature of the higher education sector, which applies to some extent to the administrative, technical and clerical staff areas as well as to academic employment, is that a sizable proportion of the staff establishment is employed without permanency and all the advantages which accompany it. This binary or two-tiered structure creates serious industrial problems and lowers morale among academic staff in general, not just women. At least in the academic area, we find that women are concentrated in untenured positions. In universities for instance, in 1981-the latest figures available-only 45 per cent of women academics held tenured jobs, compared with 84 per cent of men. The specific nature of contract academic appointments in many institutions precludes individuals from renewing their contracts and holding their jobs for more than the three or five years their contracts specify. They are, therefore, forced into an itinerant employment pattern which requires geographic mobility; usually a greater problem for women than for men because their male partner's career considerations usually take precedence, even in their own minds, over their own. Responsibility for child care, usually primarily assigned to women, can also preclude their mobility. A serious outcome of this itinerant employment is that the necessary research these women should do to further their careers and to provide a women's perspective in research generally, is seriously inhibited.

It would seem these disadvantages were being perpetuated in the absence of legislation and a program. For example, in the South Australian College of Advanced Education, at the beginning of 1984, when it began its affirmative action pilot program, 68 per cent of the appointments were awarded to men-up 2 per cent; 82 per cent of the 55 tenurable appointments went to men-up 10 per cent; and 43 per cent of contract appointments went to men-unchanged. At the same college a survey in 1984 showed that 40.6 per cent of female academic staff, compared with 14.1 per cent of male academic staff, earned less than $30,000 per annum and nearly 20 per cent of female academic staff were classified as Lecturer 3 or below, compared with only 5 per cent for their male counterparts-a ratio of 4:1. For general staff the picture is worse. Forty-five per cent of female general staff are classified as clerical officers grade 1, while the figure for males is only 3.5 per cent-a ratio of 13:1. For female general staff, 76.7 per cent earn less than $20,000 per annum, while the figure for males is 46 per cent.

Obviously the lack of equal opportunity for women and the need for affirmative action programs is as much an industrial issue as it is a social one, for it affects the terms and conditions of the workers concerned. Recruitment, selection, promotion, staff development and part time or casual employment are all issues which are of major industrial significance to employers at our higher education institutions.

The Prime Minister outlined the eight steps contained in clause 8 of the Bill which constitute an affirmative action program. Two of those steps require consultation with unions and employers, but to be really effective I believe that conscientious employees will need to consult with unions at each of the eight stages of the affirmative action program. It should be obvious that consultation impinges on all stages, from the preparation of the original policy statement, development of a program, collection of statistics, identification of discrimination in the work place, remedies and monitoring. Furthermore, it is unfortunate that there is no definition of `consultation' in the Bill. I grant that this may be difficult to draft but, without a guide, while some employers may consult widely and continuously, others will develop a program in vacuo and present it to the unions as a fait accompli, with an opportunity to comment only. I suggest that those employers who do not recognise that affirmative action is an industrial issue and do not work closely with their unions will not achieve satisfactory progress despite this legislation.

Let me say this to those who believe that this Bill will impose extra costs on private and public firms: Affirmative action in employment which promotes the principle of merit instead of the bias of gender makes for sound personnel practice. Affirmative action which removes discrimination against women in their education, training and job opportunities makes for sound human resource management. This Bill goes a long way towards recognising-to use the words of the Chinese-that indeed women do hold up half the sky.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are confined by agreement to 10 minutes each in this debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, I shall endeavour to meet that objective. I have a number of contributions to make in respect of statutory authorities but I will first make some general observations. The House is well aware of my long-standing commitment to equality of opportunity between the sexes and, indeed, between all individuals regardless of their particular differences. I think it is fundamental to liberalism that the individual have equality of opportunity and, of course, from the national point of view it is essential that the maximum benefit be gained for the nation from each of our human resources. I merely remind the House that the obstacles to equality of opportunity for women do exist. Some of them were mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). In particular he stressed five points. I believe that he is correct in those observations and that the Government must analyse and act on each of those five points and, of course, that it must act on those other items which were listed previously by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he introduced his statement on the National Agenda for Women. The House will recall that that was agreed to in principle by the Leader of the Opposition with some omissions pointed out and some areas of differences expressed by him. One of the most important points in that National Agenda for Women concerns educational curricula. Therefore, in addition to the points made today by the Leader of the Opposition, one of which obviously was the availability of quality child care, there is the fundamental matter of equality of opportunity in education. This is in order that women can then have a genuine choice of vocation having the same qualifications as men.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially what we are looking at is an attitudinal matter. Most men still think that there are some things which are naturally men's work and some things which are more naturally female's work. On the whole most men still do not regard women as equal when it comes to vocational activities. While there are some men who are exceptions, some of whom are in this chamber, they only prove the rule that there is a genuine attitudinal barrier. Therefore, the argument, such as it is today, ought only to be about the means of raising awareness and breaking down that attitudinal barrier. Sadly it is found not merely at all levels of management-the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) criticised employers-but also it is found, I am sure he would actually agree, throughout the trade union movement. I find rather hollow some of the criticisms which the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been making recently, including criticism of this legislation, when until very recently there was no acknowledgement on its part of the legitimate interests of female trade unionists. It is a very belated effort on its part. We have tentative recognition now by the ACTU and by the Business Council of Australia. I commend the Business Council for establishing its council on equal opportunity and for having on the council representatives of the Confederation of Australian Industry and of the Federal Government. It is important that every effort be made to create an awareness within enterprise of the rights of individuals regardless of sex and of the enlightened self-interest that can be gained by enterprises from the contributions of women employed by them or who are able to be employed by them.

In order to show the deep seated nature of attitudes even in this building I recall that I was the only Minister in the Fraser Government who had a female senior private secretary. I think there are only two, at most three, of the 27 Ministers now who have female senior private secretaries. I find it extraordinary that it is thought that women cannot do the senior job in a Minister's office. I think that there is that underlying impression which ensures that men tend to get preference. Probably because that impression prevails so strongly as an attitude many women, who would be qualified to do the job, do not in fact apply. Therefore, progress towards equality of opportunity is exceedingly slow.

As I have said, the Leader of the Opposition has rightly made a number of observations about where obstacles to equality of opportunity really lie. Those obstacles are not addressed by this Bill. I believe that the Government should accelerate action on its National Agenda for Women, which again, if one wanted to be carping, one could find some fault with. However, essentially it is a program which is supported by the Opposition. I think that we ought to have many more debates in this Parliament, by way of a ministerial statement rather than by way of legislation, so that we help in awareness raising among the men who predominate in this chamber so that the obstacles to the exercise of genuine equality of opportunity are removed. The honourable member for Streeton referred to that great liberal philosopher John Stuart Mill who, I must say, has been a constant source of inspiration as far as I am concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been in your mind recently.

—As the Minister at the table has rightly said, he has been in my mind recently in respect of the death of Alan Missen who was a great disciple of John Stuart Mill. I took the precaution of looking in the Library at some of Mill's writings on the subjugation of women. It is true that in the century or so since he wrote and acted, including the time when he was a member of parliament, some progress has been made. Women are no longer now totally bound to their husbands in the legal sense in which they were. They now have rights to property and so forth. Therefore, one would hope that over a century some substantial progress would have been made. However, it is extremely apparent that the things that Mill was writing about, talking about and acting on in the nineteenth century still prevail attitudinally. Men are still hung up with the fact that women have certain defined roles. Oddly enough of course the so-called traditional family, about which we hear so much, which is allegedly a dependent female spouse at home looking after children, has not been a reality in much of human history. In most of life until this century women were working with men in menial functions, especially in rural societies, but even in the early industrialised societies. It has really only been in this century that we have had the phenomena of the dependent spouse and dependent children. Of course there are grave misunderstandings about the education of dependent children. The nineteenth century debates on education arbitrarily chose the age of five years as the age when people went to school. In fact, we know that children benefit very much from structured pre-school education, as we now call it, and by high quality guidance and structured learning in child care centres as opposed to the unstructured caring that they can receive at home. Most primary school teachers now find that there is quite a difference between the understanding of those children who have had the benefit of pre-school and child care education--
—But it is not absolutely cut and dried; there are some exceptions.

—There will be some exceptions. However, I make the observation that we are still locked into some nineteenth century assumptions that were seen to be radical in their day. Of course, if the views of some people were taken to their logical conclusion we would still have children down the mines and we would still have many of the so-called management prerogatives prevail-at the expense of the rights of individuals. I think that this sort of debate, if tackled maturely in this House, can help a national awareness of problems. For us genuinely to enable people to exercise choice we have to do a good deal more than any government has done in Australia to overcome the barriers that are so deeply entrenched, not least because of the educational curriculum.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the letters to the editors of daily newspapers one sees again ample illustration of these attitudinal barriers and why Dale Spender, that noted feminist writer, has said that there will always need to be women's movement. I have no doubt that the old habits will die very slowly indeed. Having spoken of letters to the editor, I would like to read one letter from a Jennifer Darling to the Editor of the Age on 15 March. She said:

We've read many opinions lately asserting that feminism, women's careers, equal opportunity and affirmative action are denigrating women's role in the home, keeping men and youth from the workforce and the nation's future population down.
As a woman with a profession, two marvellous children and a `guilty' armchair-feminist husband . . . I wish to say this-

In our home children are an event of human experience for whom both parents are responsible. Their foibles drive us crazy. Witnessing their development gives us faith in the future. Their very being is not for the future of the nation but, realistically, a burden upon the future tolerance of the planet as a whole and its ability to sustain them.

In return, we encourage them to love and respect the world and community they share, taking their own talents and interests beyond the home. The schools where they spend their weekdays are another door to the world not a symbol of status to set them apart.

Rather than being resentful or neglected, they are growing up independent, resourceful and interested in the work I do. They have experienced care and guidance from private individuals and at a local government childcare centre which they recall with bemusement and affection.
Being a professional may keep someone else from a job. I see my work as a product of my own talent and a contribution to my welfare for the service I provide.

Involvement in feminism is not intended to drive homemakers into frenzied battle against professional neighbours. Feminism for me is a voice to remove inequities from the lives of those who do feel oppressed and exploited.
As for my husband, he's simply a lovable male human being who appears to share the need to be heading in the same direction, from the same place, in the same time as me.

TALK.START.PARA: —A top letter.

—It is a first class letter, as the honourable member for Tangney says. It seems to me that there lies the challenge to this Parliament and this nation to get that level of maturity in family life and in the community's understanding generally of what we are trying to achieve when we stress the need for equality of opportunity between people.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly about statutory authorities. There are seven statutory authorities in the portfolio of Communications. I am currently the shadow Minister and the view that I take and I hope the Minister would take would be to ask those seven authorities to report in their annual reports in just the way that businesses are being asked to report here as a result of this legislation. I understand that the Government could prescribe statutory authorities to report in the same way as Public Service departments. I think it would be wrong to do this. I do not think the statutory authorities should be any more under the jurisdiction of the Public Service Board. However, I think that the responsible Ministers have an obligation to ensure that the equal opportunity programs in those authorities are subject to the same or similar scrutiny to that which applies to the private sector in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done that with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

—The Minister for Science says that he has done that with CSIRO and I commend him for that. I do not doubt that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) would look at his favourably too. There is expertise in the Equal Opportunity Bureau of the Public Service Board and that expertise might be availed of by some statutory authorities. For example the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, previously under Dame Leonie Kramer and certainly under the present Board with Ms Wendy McCarthy being the Deputy Chairperson, has a very well advanced program on equal opportunity. As its last annual report indicates, Telecom Australia also has a very advanced program. I would have thought that these organisations are probably already meeting the minimum standards of this legislation, but if other authorities are not as far as advanced they could augment their own expertise by reference to the Equal Opportunity Bureau of the Public Service Board. Perhaps they could do that by way of a contractual relationship and not by way of subjecting that authority to any jurisdiction of the Board itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, the importance of this legislation lies in the fact that it enshrines the merit principle. Whatever the defects in its administration, as pointed out earlier by the Leader of the Opposition, no one can argue against the principle that merit should be the determining factor in employment. We must do everything we can to break down the barriers which exist. We have said that we will monitor the progress. We believe that the Government must tackle each of the barriers to equality of opportunity and, in government, we would commit ourselves to so removing those obstacles and to tackling equality of opportunity in what would then seem to be the appropriate manner. I hope that the Minister for Communications might indicate his view of the suggestion that I have made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill and I am particularly pleased that I have the opportunity to speak after the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee). Legislation like this-important social legislation-does not just emerge from the support of one party or one section of the Government. It comes from everyone in our community feeling that it is about time to give this sort of legislation support. Without the support of people like the honourable member for Goldstein and Senator Peter Baume, who I am glad to see is in the chamber for this debate, we would not see this legislation before the House today. It is important for those people who are listening to this Parliamentary debate to understand that there is legislation like this which receives support from most members of the House. I know that there have been a few exceptions but on the whole most members have supported the legislation. Parliamentary procedure is at its very best when there is this sort of contribution from all parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I am personally very much indebted to the honourable member for Goldstein for a particular event that occurred when I had just had my first child. I was still in hospital and there was considerable debate on whether I should return to the work force. At that stage the Government was about to bring down the Budget and I said `I am going back to work'. That did not seem to present any problem to myself, my family or my new baby but it seemed to provoke considerable controversy in the rest of Australia.

One Opposition member decided that he would make an issue of it. He went on a radio program called PM and criticised me for returning to work. I was quite flabbergasted by this insight into his opinion of my ability to raise a child, but, rather than make a comment, I sat in hospital and fumed. I was very pleased to hear the honourable member for Goldstein on the radio making a comment. He said that it was up to me to work out how I ran my own life and to decide what I was capable of doing. I have never publicly thanked the honourable member for that, although I have thanked him privately. It is women like me, who work and try to set some example to other women in Australia, who could not do so without the support of men like the honourable member for Goldstein. I thank him for that. Honourable members may be interested to know that my second child was born in the middle of an election campaign and whether I returned to work was not an issue at all. I did not receive one abusive letter or one comment from anyone in the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did your vote go up?
—Yes, my vote went up, so I think we can see that gradually society has changed. However, it only changes because men and women in our society change their views on life.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to speak on this Bill which clearly demonstrates that the Labor Government and, I believe, the Parliament are committed to increasing women's opportunities, especially in the work force. The legislation shows that the Government is prepared to back up its commitment with action. The Bill requires certain employers to promote equal opportunity for women by development and implementation of affirmative action programs. It will establish the office of the Director of Affirmative Action and affirmative action will be phased in. Other members has discussed that in more detail.

I wish to take up a couple of issues and discuss them. First of all, why is this legislation necessary? As a woman who previously worked in the private sector before I came to Parliament, I can assure honourable members that discrimination against women in the work place is alive and well. Life as a woman member of parliament is easy compared with working in the private sector. For years I worked as a consultant to a number of large companies and every time I attended a conference in my own right or with my employer it was always inferred that I was a steno-secretary. Of course there is nothing wrong with being a steno-secretary, but it is about time that employers realised that women can do a lot more in the work force than simply type and take shorthand. The facts speak for themselves. Where do women work? Australia has the most highly sex-segregated work force of all comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. An examination of Australian labour markets shows that women are concentrated in a very narrow range of occupations. In November 1985, 65 per cent of all women workers were employed in only three occupational areas-clerical, sales and services. They, of course, are also the lowest paid workers.

Affirmative action is not an end in itself; it is a goal simply to provide equal employment opportunities for men and women. It is a term covering a wide range of programs which organisations can undertake to remove discriminatory practices. These programs can range from a review of employment practices to identifying how they discriminate against women to introducing special programs to encourage women to apply for a wider range of jobs within the organisation. Affirmative action is simply a series of management techniques which are employed to achieve a better representation of women in the work force. Surely that is a pretty good business principle.

Affirmative action for women in employment is based on a few simple principles that I think all of us in this chamber would adhere to. Firstly, I instance equity and justice. Each individual should have the right to compete for employment, subject only to ability. Women should not have to prove that they are better qualified, that they have more experience than men, that they can manage their children or that they will not leave in two years time before getting the job. They should be treated like men and given the same opportunities as men. Secondly, there is freedom of choice. Each individual should have the freedom to choose his or her occupation, subject only to the constraint of available employment. Thirdly, there is economic efficiency. The skills and talents of all men and women who want to work become available through affirmative action programs. Increased access to all available talent and the use of the best qualified people promote efficiencies. If Australia is to build a viable, strong and sensitive work force it must get the best it can from all employees regardless of sex.

Affirmative action is based on the principle of merit; it is not based on quotas. A quota would mean a fixed number or a percentage of women employees that must be reached regardless of the number of qualified female applicants available for the job. The quota was part of the American legislation; it is not part of this legislation before the House today. The principle in this legislation is getting the best out of all employees based on the principle of merit.

The Government does set an example as it has with affirmative action for its own employees. The Government introduced legislation as part of the Public Service Reform Bill in May 1984 which requires Commonwealth government departments to develop and implement equal employment opportunity programs for women and disadvantaged groups in the Public Service. I have been pleased to see, when I have spoken to people at a number of training programs, the increase in the number of women attending those programs. We still have a long way to go. As at June last year, we had only 78 women-4.9 per cent-in the Senior Executive Service out of a total of 1,505. The Government has already made provision for legislative based equal opportunity programs under the provisions of the Public Service Act to be extended by regulation to Commonwealth authorities. I was interested in the comments made by the honourable member for Goldstein about affirmative action in statutory authorities. I believe the Government is looking at ways that it can extend affirmative action to these authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are moving an amendment to help you on your way.

—Good, I am sure that will be very welcome as many of the other comments in this debate have been. One area that is critical to the provision of equal opportunities for women in the work force is child care. Other members have made reference to that. I simply want to endorse the points made particularly by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) in this area. Women also have to provide child care facilities to give their children the opportunities they require and to get the maximum opportunities for themselves in the work place. I understand that the Federal Government is requesting the States to relax regulations to facilitate adequate child care facilities and enable a greater participation of women in the work force, but I believe it is about time that this Parliament set an example for the rest of the community for work based child care by providing child care facilities in the new Parliament House. I understand this has been an issue under discussion since I first became a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House in 1980. We still have not got any further. When I went on a tour around the New Parliament House last Saturday I was impressed with the extent of the space in the building. I find it extraordinary that somehow we cannot manage to provide some child care facilities, not only for the members of the parliament but also, probably more importantly, for the employees who are going to work in that building. If the Government is establishing a tradition of having work based child care, it is very important that we set an example.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area where the Government is showing leadership is the provision of more flexibility in working hours, and this relates particularly to the provision of part time work. Part time work is a very welcome addition to the Public Service. I understand that regulations are now being discussed with the relevant unions and I hope that by the end of the month we will have the regulations in place to bring about permanent part time work in the Commonwealth Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Reg and Mrs Sylvia Faulkner-Small Business-Rural Economy-Company Takeovers and the Share Market-Unemployment-Mr Brian Cox-Mr Caspar Weinberger-Rural Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today in the grievance debate on what I regard to be the extremely disquieting circumstances of a dogged 12-year search for justice by two members of my electorate, two of my constituents, Reg and Sylvia Faulkner. Their case will be known to many members of this Parliament, for a number of us from both the Government and the Opposition benches and from both this House of Representatives and the other place have given help and support to the Faulkners over these 12 years. Despite that support, as I say, from both sides of the Parliament and from both Houses of the Parliament, and their determined efforts over the years, the Faulkners seem as distant today as they were in 1974 from achieving the fundamental right of every citizen to have a matter of law considered and decided upon by the courts and judiciary of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: When I raise this case, I in no way make a judgment on the merits or otherwise of either side of the question. What I am concerned about is this extraordinary delay of 12 years in a matter coming before the courts-and it still has not come before the court. I have been aware of the case almost since its inception. Initially I felt a growing exasperation that our legal system could be so ponderous, and that exasperation turned to concern when there came a suspicion that certain parties associated with this case might be deliberately delaying the course of justice. Now, after 12 years, I am very alarmed that the circumstances of this case and the nature of the delays are of such a magnitude as to be a serious reflection on the ability of the Australian legal system to provide justice and to redress wrongs.

I do not think it is an exaggeration to suggest that a system which has traditionally been admired by world jurists has become an arena where all too often distress and injury are being caused. The alarm is heightened in my mind by the fact that on the one hand the defendants in this case are the Commonwealth of Australia and an ex-brigadier, while on the other hand we have Reginald and Sylvia Faulkner, a husband and wife, ordinary citizens, decent people, with what they regard as a genuine grievance that should have been adjudicated upon-not in 1986 or next year but, in fact, in 1973.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am loath to interrupt the honourable member but I am not quite sure whether he is alluding to a matter that is before the courts.
—No, it is not before the courts.
—It is not before the courts; fine.
—That is what I am saying. It has not come before the courts; it has taken 12 years to get to this stage and it is still not before the courts.
—But has it been listed?
—No, not as far as I am aware.
—I just remind the honourable member of the sub judice rule, and he may proceed.
—I understand that, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Is there a writ of something pending or in existence?
—I am not aware of any writ in existence. The matter is still--
—If the honourable member has assured the House that to his knowledge the matter is not before the courts, the House--
—I am not aware of it being before the courts. That is why I am saying that I think it should come before the courts.
—The House may take the view that the advice we have--
—The interrogatories are in process at the present time.
—If there are interrogatories, there must have been a writ.

—The point I am trying to raise is that these people have been trying to get to court for 12 years and the process has been delayed for this extraordinary period of time. How am I to assist in this process, if I cannot talk about it?
—The House has a problem in that we cannot reflect on matters that are in the legal process. I want to help the honourable member.

—I understand that, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I said in the process of my remarks, I am in no way making any judgments about the merits of the case, one way or the other. All I am concerned about is the fact that it has taken this extraordinarily long time for the matter to be brought forward and for the people to have their day in court.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Could I assist the honourable member? Is he in fact making a complaint about the administrative procedures?
—Yes.

—If he directs himself and says that there are certain deficiencies in administrative procedures, it seems to me that, if that criticism is aimed at, say, the Attorney-General or at the bureaucracy of a particular court, he may be on safer ground rather than, in fact, adducing the merits of a particular case and creating the impression, anyway, that there ought to be a judgment one way or another on the merits of that case.

—Speaking to that point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am endeavouring, as I have said, not to canvass the merits of the case one way or the other. I am concerned about the administrative procedures. I am concerned about the delay. There have been, it appears, losses of documents. This sort of thing really concerns me in relation to an attempt by some constituents of mine to bring their case before a judicial body. I am not reflecting on, as I say, the merits of the case one way or the other. I do not know. All I am seeking is some attention to be drawn to the fact that this process has been going on for such an extraordinarily long period of time, and I do not think it is fair.

—I think that that sort of criticism of a process of justice is reasonable. I think they are points that the Minister and I have made. The honourable member seems to be proceeding along that point, so he may continue.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. Just to give some background to the case, it was in 1964 that a metal clip was invented for connecting wire ropes to heavy loads. The Australian Army expressed interest in the device, known as the Trisal clip. Companies were set up and there was an indication that the Army would purchase large quantities of the device. No orders were ever placed and the company was subject to a scheme of arrangement.

—On a point of order: I hate to interrupt the honourable member but he does seem to be canvassing the issues of a case that he has admitted is before the courts. There are, under the rules of New South Wales courts, time limits for filing proceedings. If it is 12 years since something has been originally initiated as a writ, that is a reflection on the solicitors for both sides. There is no excuse for such a delay and I appreciate what the honourable member is trying to do, but we cannot really have the actual terms of the dispute raised here in the House today.
—Could the honourable member address himself to the generality rather than the specific?

—It seems to me that the House should be aware of the nature of the background to the case. That was all I was establishing-that some 12 or more years ago a situation developed which has led, since that time, to people becoming bankrupt and to efforts on behalf of my constituents to bring the matter to court. There have been extraordinary delays in the administration of that process. The Commonwealth has been involved in the administration of that process. Still, 12 years after the initial efforts, this matter has not been finalised. All I am seeking to do today is to suggest that the process by which claims are heard seems to have been unduly delayed in this case. As I say, without making any judgment on the merits of the case, it seems to me quite wrong that the administration of justice should take this extraordinary length of time. If I am precluded by the forms of the House from debating or introducing any of the matter relevant to the case, so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential point that I am seeking to make is that I believe the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) should take a very close interest because the Commonwealth is involved in it. I know he is aware of the case. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) should be aware of the case. I believe that both of them should make every effort to assist in bringing this case before the courts so that these two constituents of mine have the opportunity of their day in court. If we are going to have a system of justice which involves a delay of 12 years or more in the hearing of a case of this nature, it is simply an inadequate system of justice. The Attorney-General is responsible for the Federal system of justice in this country. He is aware of the case-it has been made known to him-and I would entreat him to give it his closest personal attention so that people, ordinary people, decent people in the community, can at least have an opportunity to put their case before a court of this land and the matter adjudicated upon.

I reiterate that I do not make any statements about the merits, pro or con, of the case, but I do say that, if we have a system of justice in this country which, after 12 years, sees a situation where two citizens of Australia still cannot get to court to have their grievances tested, it is a very inadequate system of justice indeed and something needs to be done about it very smartly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday at my morning interviews, I interviewed an Australian small businessman who went into a business and unfortunately lost the business during the recession in 1982. He had put his home up as a security with the bank and he lost his home. He was a man, born in Italy, who was extremely distressed by the experience and had no one to stand up for him. He had to go into a Housing Commission house. He is a man in his late fifties. So I was somewhat concerned when I arrived in Canberra on Tuesday morning and found trucks blockading the airport and the farmers protesting, because I thought that there was nobody protesting for the small business community; regrettably no one seems to care what happens to them.

SPEECH.PARA: But I thought I would today raise the problem of the rural community because last night I had a telephone call from a farmer who in 1979 bought a property of 1,623 acres nine miles from Canowindra. This farmer is a cousin of mine. I had met him at his mother's funeral last week when he told me that things were bad in the bush and he was going under with interest rates. I know this man. I know that he is hard working. I know that he has always wanted to go on the land. In 1979, after 32 years in business, he sold a pharmacy and his home in Sydney and raised $600,000 and bought a property at Canowindra. Unfortunately, although he has worked very hard with his two adult sons and they have put $300,000 worth of improvements on the property, he has had nothing but bad luck ever since. Nearly every year he has struck a drought or rain or mice or frost and has had no crop. In 1979 the drought-no crop; 1980-no crop; 1981 was the only year that he had an average crop; 1982-there was a drought again; 1983-the harvest was wet and he lost money because of rain damage; 1984-50 per cent of the crop was lost because of frost damage, and mice took much of the rest; 1985-a wet harvest and he had dockage of $45 and $24 a tonne; and 1986 looks to be a disaster year in the bush in New South Wales.

This man now owes the bank $720,000. His interest rate until last week was 21.75 per cent. No one can run a business and pay interest rates of 21.75 per cent. This has been dropped now to 19.5 per cent. His annual interest bill is $140,000. The newspapers have been searching for people who are in a crisis in the bush and I am raising this matter today because today representatives of the bank are at his property and are probably having lunch with him and his wife now. They do not know that I am saying this because there is no Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcast of Parliament in Canowindra. I did say to him that it is time that people in trouble in the bush stood up and let their names be used, and he very reluctantly agreed. He has a great crisis and it must be known. I know that he is hard working. I know that he is an honourable bloke-not just because he is a cousin of mine. He is a man I believe in and he is a man who has sacrificed all to go on the land.

His fear is that the bank may cut off credit. He is a good farmer. He is a graduate of the University of Sydney. He is a graduate of the Sydney Rural School of Science. In 1984-85 he won the district wheat competition. In 1985-86 he was second, only because they did not have enough money to spray against black oats. He has had a good district average price for lambs, and the lamb market in Australia has been indeed sick.

I have great sympathy for this man, whose name is John Maher. Our grandfather had a property, a selection, out at Forbes on the Bundaburra Creek. Grandfather had to walk off in the 1890s drought because the banks forced him off. Our great grandfather had a farm on the banks of the Lachlan at Forbes. He also had to walk off because of money owed to the bank due to floods on the Lachlan River. Yet we have farmers blockading the airport and threatening to blockade the airport again on Friday to stop us getting home. I do not know what they are hoping to achieve. My cousin said that he was appalled by their kindergarten antics. How can they take three, four or five days off from their properties if they are really working their properties hard trying to make a living?

This gentleman, this cousin of mine, said that farmers do not want a moratorium; they do not want a ban on paying any debts. They want to be able to get some means of setting aside the hard core debt. They need credit; they need money to plant their crops; they need money to pay tradesmen and creditors; but they need something to set aside the hard core debts, some sort of scheme so that debt can be paid off when viability returns to agriculture in five or six years. I do not want to see John Maher forced off his farm, as were his forebears, particularly as the banks in Australia are part of the most profitable banking system in the whole world. The high interest rates are making them a fortune every trading day.

My cousin deplored what the Livestock and Grain Producers Association did. It is no use farmers coming and shouting abuse at people at the airport. They picked on all the wrong people; all the people dressed in nice suits turned out to be judges and businessmen. They did not know who the members of parliament were. It was the silliest demonstration I have ever seen. It did no good at all.

Unfortunately there are genuine cases and tragic cases in the bush-people with appalling debts in the rural sector. That is why I raise this today, because I overlook the inanities outside. There are people in the farming sector who have great problems, and I think it is time that some of these people came forward. It is very hard for them to face the glare of of publicity, but they have to do this and stop some of the cant and hypocrisy. Even today we have a matter coming on for debate later about the farming sector of Australia, but it is this Government that has halved the rate of growth in farm costs. I am raising these matters today. I agree with everything that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr John Kerin) said about the LGPA protest. I say good luck to the people in the bush who are struggling, who are really facing eviction by the banks, because it is a national crisis. They are not multinationals; they cannot go somewhere else and sell out and just go off.

This cousin of mine does have a small equity left in his farm; but, if facing debts of $740,000 and an interest bill of $140,000 a year, anyone would be worried, anyone would be sick to death and would not be able to sleep at night. I believe it is appropriate to raise these things in a grievance debate in this House so that the Australian people can learn of some of the problems of the rural community, the people who really do produce half of our exports-half of the exports of this nation are in agriculture. The economy is slowly getting better at a pace that is less than perhaps we had hoped because the rural sector can make very little contribution because of the drought in New South Wales.

I hope that some of my comments today might be noted by the banks, the people who are making great profits at the expense of the rural community and the business community. I hope also that, in any package of assistance that is brought forward, we do not forget the small business people, because there is nobody down here protesting about their losses and their appalling situation. If they put up capital and lose, no one seems to care two hoots. I think it is time we had some sort of a package to stop people losing their homes, to stop them losing their businesses and to allow them to trade out when the situation improves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk today about the issue of takeovers and the share market in particular. After all, in the last few weeks this Parliament and indeed the nation have been consumed by debates of the importance of takeovers and whether they should or should not proceed. The genuine concern that I have is not that people have the capacity to take over companies; my concern is the decline in public involvement in share markets. When Harold Macmillan was the Prime Minister of Great Britain during the 1950s, he talked about Britain becoming a property-owning democracy. He believed that by being a property-owning democracy that country would achieve greater social stability and greater development. When Harold Macmillan was talking about property-owning democracy he was talking about the ownership of property, being housing and land. I think that principle should be extended much further; it should be extended to the wealth-creating resources of our country-in other words, our companies and our corporate sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Capitalism, I believe, would be all the more successful, and indeed all the more popular, if it became people's capitalism, if there was the involvement of ordinary Australians in those companies that create the wealth of the Community. The trend over recent years has been otherwise. Economic power in this country and throughout the Western world has become increasingly concentrated, with institutions gaining a larger and larger part of the share market and of the shares traded on that market. One only has to look at international comparisons to see how this trend has been world-wide. In the United States of America in 1970, 15 per cent of the population held shares, which by international standards is actually a very high proportion of the population. That percentage had declined by 1980 to just over 13 per cent. There has also been a very significant decline in the United States of the proportion of shares which are owned by individuals rather than by institutions.

The findings in the United Kingdom are pretty much the same. Back in 1957 individual holdings in the share market amounted to about 65 per cent of all shares. By 1975 that figure had dropped to 37.5 per cent. I cannot get any more recent figures, but I doubt that that figure has changed very much since then.
