In 1975, 3.7 per cent of the British population actually owned shares, which is a tiny percentage of the population of that country owning the corporate sector of the nation.

In Australia, which is what we are concerned about, there has been very much the same trend. Today in Australia the latest figures show that about 4 per cent of the population own all the shares traded on the Australian share market. The consequence of only 4 per cent owning the shares is a concentration of ownership in the hands of a few and particularly in the hands of institutions rather than individuals. Those shares are, in the main, held by the five large life offices in this country and by the enormous superannuation funds, which are likely, of course, to expand as this year wears on.

In 1979, that is, the latest available figures that we have, 32 per cent of the shareholdings in Australia were owned by individuals. Yet in 1953 that figure was 75 per cent. The top 20 shareholders in this country, who are institutional shareholders, held about 30 per cent of shares back in 1953. In 1979 they held 40 per cent.

Why is broad public ownership of shares important? I think there are a number of reasons: First of all, we want to reduce the concentration of economic power. With the rise of superannuation funds, and particularly in the future funds that will be controlled by the trade union movement, the last thing we want in this country is some kind of `pension fund socialism' where the corporate sector of Australia is basically owned by pension funds, many of which may in the future be controlled by trade unions.

We want to diversify ownership of the resources of the community amongst ordinary Australians. We do not want to do that through government involvement and government intervention beyond a reasonable degree. We do not want government saying who and who cannot buy shares, as long as trading is done legitimately. What we do want is to get ordinary people more involved in the ownership of the community's resources, not just a few large institutions.

Diversifying ownership of shares would have a second effect of making takeovers much less simple than they are at present. Where shares are held by a few institutions it is clearly relatively easy for takeovers to be successful. Where they are owned by large numbers of individuals, clearly the process is going to be considerably more complicated.

A third reason I think we should have broader public ownership of shares is to give ordinary Australians a much greater stake in their nation's future. At the moment the vast majority of Australian's only stake in the economic development of their country is through the receipt of wages. If we could also ensure that large numbers of people owned shares, that would be a further way for those people to gain the rewards of economic success-not just by going to employers or to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or whatever it may be to gain a greater share of the success of the economy, but also by receiving the fruits of that success through the appreciating value of their shares and through the dividends and bonus issues and so on that those shares would bring.

Fourthly, I think broader share ownership would have significant industrial relations advantages, particularly where there is employee share ownership in individual firms. The results of employee ownership schemes in existing firms, both in Australia and overseas, have been extremely encouraging. Surveys and studies have shown that it aligns personal and company goals; it involves, in other words, the employee in the institution or company in which he works and it takes him away from the role of what is rather emotively described as just a wage slave. It gives the employee a greater commitment to the company in which he or she works and it is also important from the company's point of view, and perhaps from the employee's point of view, that employees work longer in particular companies. It has the effect also of increasing the motivation and, therefore, the productivity of the firm.

The question, of course, that is difficult to answer is how it is possible to create a greater degree of people's capitalism in the Australian economy. Very briefly, there are three ways we can look at encouraging that process. First of all, through the process of industrial democracy-a phrase which is so glibly used by those on the other side of the House-we can encourage companies to sell shares to their employees. In some instances it may be that companies would be willing to do that at a discount or on preferential terms to their employees, but I think it would befit all of us, as members of parliament, to encourage companies to look more closely at those sorts of schemes because where they have existed in Australia-and Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd, I suppose, is the best known example-they have proved to be a very significant success and they have also created harmonious industrial relations for the reasons I have explained.

Secondly, through the taxation system there is no doubt that share ownership can be encouraged. The Government has announced that it is going to introduce the imputation system to eliminate double taxation of dividends, and I support the broad thrust of the scheme that the Government is introducing. I think that one of the consequences of having an imputation system is that it would encourage, in the longer term, greater individual participation in the share market rather than just institutional participation. In the United Kingdom, in the recent Budget introduced last month, that Government established something called a personal equity plan. Under that plan British citizens, ordinary citizens of that country, will be able to invest up to $5,000 a year, `in Australian currency' free of any capital gains tax and free of any tax on dividends received. To do such a thing in Australia may prove to be expensive and would have to be examined very carefully, but I think the British have set an example there, at least in terms of sentiment, that we ought to look at very carefully.

Finally, this is an educative problem. Australians are scared of the share market; they do not understand the benefits they can gain. I think it is incumbent not so much on governments but on stockbrokers, on the stock exchanges of Australia and, indeed, on banks, particularly at the branch level, to encourage people to understand the benefits of the share market and to encourage people to put their savings not just into traditional forms of saving but also into shares out of which they can gain so much. Capitalism in this country will work if it is not just for the privileged. Capitalism should be for ordinary people. They should have the opportunity to participate in the process of capitalism. We need to get away as quickly as we can from a small number of institutions controlling this economy towards a broader community participation, and the way to do that is through the share market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to express concern about the concentration of economic power in this country, but do so from a rather different point of view than the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I suggest that there are some aspects of this matter in respect of which we would share common views, but I make the observation that his call for a form of people's capitalism has very little to offer, in my opinion, to the two million and more Australians who live in poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: What I seek to do today is to raise in the House the opportunity for an honest debate about the question of government regulation, because it seems to me that there is at the moment in the community, and to a large extent in the Parliament, almost a zealot-like reliance on so-called free market forces in relation to the Australian economy. I believe that that approach to economic management spells doom and tremendous economic difficulties for this country in the years to come.

What I seek to do is to raise for debate a different approach and to express some particular concerns about the laissez-faire approach that is being adopted in the area of corporate takeovers. My concern is that regulations in Australia governing takeovers are tipping the balance too far in favour of the offerors in takeover battles. I believe that it is time to inject some balance into the debate. It is clearly a myth to suggest that takeovers automatically lead to the replacement of weak and inefficient management by more efficient managers. Indeed, Mr Henry Bosch, who I think would acknowledge himself as a free marketeer, has gone on the public record as estimating that in his view this occurs in only a tiny minority of cases.

The problem has been in part that, in attempting to resist takeovers, Australian companies are increasingly attempting to keep their share prices up over a short term. This means, of course, that valuable corporate resources are being diverted away from areas such as research and development and the regeneration of Australian industry and that long term planning is suffering as a result of this short term need to keep up share prices.

I believe that, because of the inadequacy of takeover law in this country, there is no Australian company which is not under threat from a takeover. Of course, the current example of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-BHP-provides a very important example of what I say. I do not seek to become involved in the personal assessment of the relative worth of BHP's existing board or the merits or influence that Mr Holmes a Court and his associates might bring to BHP. That is not my job. What I seek to do is to raise the general principles and to assert what I believe is unquestionably the nub of the issue in this debate-that there needs to be greater government involvement in assessing takeovers of Australian companies and that this general principle certainly applies to BHP.

Overseas studies have shown that there is no improvement in the economic efficiency of companies following takeovers and as a direct result of those mergers. Indeed, Australia has reached the overkill stage with respect to takeovers. The managers of the offeror companies clearly have nothing in particular to offer by way of improvement to the management of the companies that they are seeking to take over. In fact, clearly many of them have no experience, expertise or involvement in the area of business carried out by the company which is the subject of the takeover. I believe that if we are serious in this Parliament about increasing national productivity, which is often a view trumpeted from both sides, we ought to be looking very critically at the impact of takeovers on the economy, because there is evidence that those takeovers are increasingly diverting massive financial resources from productive areas of investment. The records show that corporate borrowings overseas, largely to finance these takeovers, have increased by about $50,000m in recent years. In fact, the $2,000m to finance the Holmes a Court takeover bid of BHP will come from a foreign bank.

If members of the Liberal Party and of the National Party and, indeed, of my own Party are serious about the level of overseas indebtedness of this country, it is an abdication of any honest debate about takeovers and the Australian economy not to give serious consideration to the question that I have raised. One of the other matters that I will turn to in a moment is the dirty tricks and taxation rorts that are used in the takeover battles. I do not believe that they are in the national interests which should be the primary concern of this Government and the Parliament.

I have made the point already, but I want to reiterate, that the existing takeover law does not give sufficient consideration to the national interest and gives too much consideration to corporate interests. I am not surprised that the trade union movement has expressed great concern about the takeover of BHP. I make reference to the view of the national secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association, who referred to companies in the steel industry being concerned only in the profitability of their shares and not in the welfare of the steel industry, the workers employed in it nor the network of family and municipal interests and relationships on which the prosperity of cities like Newcastle, Wollongong, Port Kembla and Whyalla is based. That trade union view, of course, is not just about employment. It is also about broader national interest questions and about the taxation matters that I have referred to. The President of the New South Wales Branch of the Labor Party, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions senior vice-president, Mr John MacBean, has of course gone on the public record calling for a public inquiry. His view, I believe, is still valid and is in no way diminished by the events that have occurred since he first made that call and reiterated it.

A very good barometer of public opinion, certainly opinion within the Australian Labor Party, must be the views of the administrative committee of the New South Wales branch of that Party. I am quite sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would share, at least privately, my view that that august body, if it reaches a unanimous resolution or decision on a matter, is a body that ought to be taken some notice of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most certainly.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That body made a decision on 7 March and considered the widespread concern in the community concerning the rush of takeovers occurring in Australia. Importantly, it made the point that I seek to make: The takeover of BHP is an extremely important example of this very disturbing trend. The administrative committee of the New South Wales branch took the view that, not only in the Labor movement but within the electorate generally, the rush of corporate takeovers is regarded as unwelcome and is perceived to contribute nothing to the general economic and social wellbeing of Australia. It said, and I say, that the public interest should be the first consideration in such issues and that Labor governments are elected not to stand idly by, to use the words used by it, in splendid theoretical isolation, but to intervene in the public interest where appropriate. That body went on to talk about the need for a public inquiry, the need for more effective scrutiny of takeover bids and the removal of mechanisms relating to negative gearing of speculative takeover bids.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest it be thought that only people within the Australian Labor Party are expressing concerns about this issue, let me again refer to the view put forward by Mr Bosch of the National Companies and Securities Commission. He was quoted on numerous occasions, but also in the Melbourne Age in the middle of last year, as criticising the laissez-faire approach that is all pervasive in the community:
. . . when large numbers of loyal employees are swept aside for no better purpose than the aggrandisement of a paper entrepreneur, I feel serious disquiet.

He is an acknowledged free marketeer but his view is that the existing laissez-faire, free market, zealot approach that is all pervasive in the community has gone too far. It is my view that it is time to turn back and have a more balanced and rational debate about this important question.

I conclude with three calls. I call on the Government to initiate, firstly, public inquiry into the BHP takeover; secondly, an urgent review of the Trade Practices Act as it relates to takeovers; and, finally, an urgent review of the taxation law in this country that allows the rorts in the takeover area to be perpetrated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the time is long overdue in this country when people who receive unemployment benefits should be expected to give some return for those benefits. Basically, what I propose is that all able-bodied recipients of welfare be required to do two days community work a week before they receive their cheques. Note that I use the term `able-bodied'. I stress at the outset that I am not talking about people in wheelchairs, nor am I talking about pensioners such as age pensioners who have served this country and contributed to the present standard of living that we all enjoy as a result of their past labours. What I am referred to is unemployed people on the dole.

SPEECH.PARA: The single adult unemployment benefit today amounts to $91.45 a week and is to rise next month, I am told, to $102.10 a week. If one is married, one receives a weekly amount, compliments of the taxpayer, of $163.30, soon to rise to $170.30. For each dependent child one also attracts an extra $16 a week. Those figures for the dole for the single adult of around $100 a week are given with no strings attached provided no work is available. As $100 is approximately equivalent to roughly the wage rate for two days unskilled labour, I believe it is a reasonable request to expect two days labour in return for that money. Recipients who are married and those with children would also be required to work for only two days a week as clearly one should not be disadvantaged because one is married or has children. By requiring those who have access to the public purse to work two days a week, the cost to the taxpayer would also be roughly the same as the cost of the dole.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would they do?

—I will tell the honourable member in a minute if he will listen. I am against offering full time work. If we provide a full five days work as, for example, under the old regional employment development scheme, the cost to the taxpayer would be substantially more and consequently the need to get a productive return for the taxpayers' money would become much more paramount and difficult. It would also mean that anyone put out of a job in effect would automatically be granted full time work with the Government, which I am sure we would all readily agree is the last thing this country wants.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for his support. However, with the scheme I propose, as the cost of the dole is approximately equivalent to two days unskilled labour, the only extra cost to the taxpayers would come from such items as supervisory costs and workers compensation, which I will deal with later.

SPEECH.PARA: The advantages of requiring some form of community work are many. Firstly, as only two days of work each week are required, the person will still have three days of each week and weekends left over to search for other work. So, in almost no way will it hinder the finding of a job. The scheme will also keep people in what we could call the work habit. It is human nature that if we go for a long period of time without working many of us get used to that type of behaviour and find it very hard to motivate ourselves to start working again. I am sure honourable members opposite would know what I am talking about! This is a very important factor which should never be underestimated.

Thirdly, it will give the hard-pressed taxpayers of this country value for their money. At present they are getting none. Virtually no taxpayers mind assistance going to the genuinely needy, but they resent their money being poured into permissive welfare policies such as the present dole scheme. The workers of Australia have to turn up and do five days work for five days pay and most of them believe it unfair that others in the community are given two or more days pay for no days work. A work for the dole scheme would also restore dignity to the unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good point!

—It is. In many ways, this would prove to be the most important benefit of all. Most people on the dole are genuinely unemployed and I have seen the degrading effect that getting that welfare cheque has on many of these people. However, if they have to work for that cheque like everyone else in the community has to work for their cheque, when they go down to the pub or wherever at the end to cash their cheques they will not have to slink in. They can hold their heads up high because they will have earned it. It means, of course, that the degrading term `dole bludger' will disappear from our language for ever and all the shame and all the resentment that go with that term will vanish also.

SPEECH.PARA: Another remarkable advantage to this working for the dole or work force scheme, as it is sometimes called, is that it weeds out all the cheats and pretenders in the system. One of the greatest criticisms of dole payments is that so much goes to people who have jobs or people who illegally collect more than one dole cheque, or people who could get a job but do not because they are getting enough to live on compliments of the social security system. Every government has largely failed to correct this. In practice, it is impossible to stop it. The best intentions to clean the system up only nibble at the edges. I doubt that even the proposed identity card or Australia Card, whatever we like to call it, will help much either. I estimate that 30 to 40 per cent of recipients in my electorate of Parkes are cheating the system. Most of the cheats who get the dole are also working elsewhere. I have been into small businesses in my electorate with, say, 30 employees and been told by the employer that half of these are collecting the dole. However, I found that people are reluctant to dob others in. It is hard to track down false names used and a whole host of impediments arise to prevent any of these people ever being charged, let alone convicted in a court. Even from the handful who are convicted the taxpayer almost never sees a proper return of any of his money.

Let us face it. The only way we will ever stop this sort of thing going on is by a work for the dole scheme. If these people had to turn up for two days work before they got paid, they could not be in two places at once and all cheating would stop stone dead. It would also weed out the bludgers from the system. I am referring to those who could find jobs but do not try and those who turn up for job interviews in thongs and stubbies and with tired looks on their faces, hoping that they will be refused.

TALK.START.PARA: —And reeking of marijuana.

—How true. We all know about those who get a job and leave after a few days to go back to the dole because that is easier. In some cases, a married person with a few kids is actually better off on welfare than working, especially when tax and the cost of travelling backwards and forwards to work, work clothes and so on are taken out. The stories are legion and we have all heard them before. My scheme would eliminate all of that overnight, and I know of no other way in which it could be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me emphasise that putting these people to work will displace no one who already has a job, so the unions need not scream at this suggestion. There is ample work to be done in every centre I have seen right around Australia. Council work alone would accommodate nearly all of them if need be. The work to be done on roads is virtually limitless and the councils have had lots of experience in occupying such people in recent years with schemes such as the community employment program. With my scheme the councils would get the labour for nothing. They would be up for only the supervisory costs and other incidentals such as tools. With the CEP scheme the councils had to pay 20 to 30 per cent of the wage costs, so they would be much better off with workfare. Even if these unemployed people did nothing productive, the scheme would still be worth while. Just the fact that these people had to turn up would be beneficial by itself.

There is plenty of a productive nature to be done and the scheme could get more sophisticated as it got under way. At the beginning, the unskilled jobs could include road work, weed control, street cleaning, tree planting and maintenance, hospital grounds beautification, meals on wheels, mowing pensioners' lawns, parks and gardens maintenance and so on. No one would be put out of a full time job. All this is extra to what can be afforded now. The people in these schemes would have to be covered by workers compensation, but this would amount to only about $7 a day, a small cost to pay for the advantages that would follow. Even if the Federal Government footed the bill for the whole scheme, the cost of this could well be paid for three or four times over by the savings made by having the cheats drop out of the system.

Those genuinely on the dole would welcome it. Not only would they retain dignity and the work ethic, but they would acquire skills as the scheme developed. People could be given workfare job cards. When they did apply for real jobs, at least they would have something to show their prospective employer and he could see their record. The scheme would be especially valuable for the young. Of course, instead of workfare involving all physical work, some of it could be substituted by having retraining schemes, technical and further education courses and the like.

Some will cry that all this is forced labour and, therefore, breaches the International Labour Organisation conventions to which Australia is a signatory. Apart from the fact that I think we are signatories to too many of these international socialist treaties, let me assure the people who have such concerns that this scheme does not breach the ILO conventions. To begin, no one is forcing these people to work. We are told that these people are looking for work. Well, we are offering it to them and paying them for it. Of course, if they do not turn up for work they do not get paid. But what is unusual about that? If people with jobs do not turn up for work they do not get paid. Why should it be any different for others in the community?

What would be the public acceptance of a workfare scheme? I have floated the idea everywhere I have gone for years now and the response to my suggestion has been not only good but overwhelming. In fact, I found the most enthusiastic groups are the Labor-voting, pay as you earn taxpayers. They have had a gutful of being ripped off over the years, and justifiably so. This country cannot afford these payments any more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The story that underlines my grievance today is as unjust as it is disturbing. It related to the circumstances of a Mr Brian Cox, a resident of Newcastle and a former member of the New South Wales Police Force. Mr Cox joined the Police Force in November 1970. In 1972 he was cited for bravery for wresting a gun away from a man who was wielding it during a domestic dispute. He was transferred to Newcastle in 1973 as a constable on highway patrol duty. In April 1974, whilst directing traffic around an accident, he was hit by a car whose driver was drunk. He was carried on the bonnet of the car for some 60 feet, suffering several fractures of one leg, a dislocated shoulder, general injuries to the body and so on. He required extensive surgery to reconstruct his knee. He was placed back on full duty in 1976 and in 1977 was injured during a high speed car chase of a stolen vehicle. The police car suffered a blow-out and crashed into a concrete fence. Mr Cox's old injuries were aggravated as well and he was off duty for another three months.

SPEECH.PARA: On 14 December, 1979, Mr Cox was called to the scene of a very serious accident at Adamstown. He was directing traffic around the accident when again he was hit by a car whose driver was drunk. He was thrown into the path of an oncoming car and suffered serious head injuries and leg injuries. He had an operation for subdural haematoma and was off duty until 1982, when he was pensioned off as unfit for duty. Mr Cox subsequently went to the United Kingdom in late 1983 for medical treatment, then unavailable in Australia, consisting of laser treatment to heal scarring on his brain. It was aimed primarily at curing the epilepsy he suffered as a result of his injuries, but it also greatly improved his speech and other aspects of the dyslexia that had developed.

A few weeks before going overseas in 1983, Mr Cox had purchased a Jaguar car. He arranged for this vehicle to be shipped to the United Kingdom so as to have it available for his use there whilst undergoing treatment. He also arranged with the Australian Customs to re-import the car. During the time that he and his wife were making these arrangements Customs at no time indicated that he could either have Customs duty or sales tax suspended if he was to re-export a car without having driven it in Australia or that, if he bought a new car in the United Kingdom and kept it for more than six months, he would pay duty on its depreciated value. Be all that as it may, Mr Cox acted clearly in a quite straightforward way. He had owned the car for less than two weeks before shipping it across to England. He was at no time aware that there may have been more financially attractive ways of owning a car in the United Kingdom.

In September 1984, shortly before he was to return to Australia, he was a passenger in his own car which was being driven by an English policeman friend when it was involved in an accident to a degree that necessitated its being written off. The car was insured through Commercial Union who insisted that the value of the car was the English market value. After a great deal of argument the company eventually agreed to pay Mr Cox enough to allow him to buy a replacement vehicle-a sum of just less than #19,000 sterling or $38,000. The vehicle had cost him, in Australia, some $55,000, which included a significant amount of duty and sales tax. Mr Cox was a front seat passenger in this accident and was unconscious for nine days afterwards. He suffered a head injury, a burst fracture of a lumbar vertebra, a fracture of a facial bone and a fractured patella. He suffered extensive further hospitalisation and treatment and eventually returned to Australia in February 1986.

In June 1985, he had purchased a replacement Jaguar, which he was committed to do from the insurance settlement. This car has now arrived in Australia and Mr and Mrs Cox have had to mortgage their home to raise the $32,000 to pay the duty and sales tax, as well as a surety of over $12,000 to Customs. In effect, Mr and Mrs Cox have a Jaguar car that they can now drive in Australia. They outlayed $55,000 in 1983 and a further $32,000 in 1986 to have the privilege of driving a car which is probably worth some $60,000-that is, of course, apart from the shipping costs and so on. Quite clearly, a young man with an impeccable record of public service who has been left largely incapacitated as a result of injuries sustained in the course of duty is now financially crippled as well. I am sure that honourable members will agree with me that this is an intolerable situation and one that neither I nor Mr Cox should accept.

In July 1985, I wrote to the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology (Senator Button) seeking assistance with Mr Cox's case. In those letters, I requested that consideration be given to giving Mr Cox a credit equivalent to the value of duty and sales tax on the vehicle that he had exported against the duty and sales tax on the vehicle that he had imported as a replacement. In other words, I was suggesting that Mr and Mrs Cox had paid duty and sales tax and so on on a vehicle in Australia that they had exported very shortly afterwards and had been unable to reimport through no fault of their own. I proposed that the duty paid should be refunded as an offset against the duty that would be paid on its replacement. I also forwarded to the Minister a detailed letter from Griffiths and Bonallack, a firm of English solicitors acting on Mr Cox's behalf, outlining the circumstances of the accident and subsequent negotiations with the insurance company.

Senator Button responded to my letter on 16 October 1985 and indicated that there were no provisions within the Customs Act for writing off any amounts. He further indicated that there were provisions within the Audit Act administered by the Minister for Finance and indicated that use of such procedures was not a routine matter. On 12 November, I forwarded copies of the various correspondence to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and drew his attention to Senator Button's remarks. I lodged a request with the Minister's staff that I be allowed to discuss this extremely complex matter with the Minister prior to his making a decision. In late February, the Minister telephoned me to indicate that he would speak with me during the next session. I attempted to discuss the matter almost daily for the two weeks of the session in March and, apart from a few very brief words on 19 March, the discussion that a matter as complex as this necessitates never took place.

On the evening of the 20th, I approached the Minister and was told, without explanation, that the request was refused. I later telexed the Minister's office seeking a written explanation to the correspondence. I finally received a letter dated 24 March, which states:

I have been unable to identify any special factors which would justify my circumventing the necessarily very strict terms of the Customs Tariff Act by agreeing to waive collection of the duty and sales tax payable by them.

I find the response of the Minister to be absolutely abhorrent and unjustifiable. If special factors could ever exist, they must exist in Mr and Mrs Cox's case. This couple have suffered grievously through no fault whatsoever of their own. The case submitted is as strong and as detailed as one could ever imagine and to have it dismissed in just 11 lines does not do the Minister justice, let alone Mr and Mrs Cox.

I believe that the request to allow Mr and Mrs Cox a credit or an ex gratia payment equivalent to the duty and sales tax paid on a car that is no longer in Australia to be credited against the duty and sales tax on a car that they imported to replace it is not only reasonable but also humane. Not to do so for a man with Mr Cox's record of dedication in public service is an insult. None of the evidence put forward in this matter has been rejected or even queried. The response seems to be that the law does not demand that any action should be taken, therefore no action will be taken. The Minister has the legislative authority to assist in this case but has chosen, for reasons that I cannot perceive, not to use it.

I have made this speech because I fervently believe this matter must be aired. I believe Mr Cox is a victim of the system, of the procedures, of the red tape of all the facilities that are aimed and designed to protect our industries in terms of the importation of vehicles. I believe he is a victim of a system that was not meant to inflict this kind of damage. I have aired the matter because it is my intention to submit it to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with a strong request that the case be reviewed and because I cannot believe that this decision reflects fairly on this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the overwhelming-I repeat, the overwhelming-majority of Australians it is my privilege to extend a very warm welcome to Mr Caspar Weinberger, the United States Secretary of Defense, who is in Canberra for two days of talks at the highest level. Caspar Weinberger is without doubt one of the great men of our time.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member, a former Minister for the Army, for his comment. Mr Weinberger is especially a very long-standing and trusted friend of Australia, having first visited our shores during the darkest days of World War II when he was attached to the personal staff of General Douglas MacArthur. He served alongside General MacArthur right through to the ultimate victory. Mr Weinberger is a champion of freedom, as his distinguished record over more than four decades proves beyond any doubt. He is admired by millions and millions of people all over the world as a man of principle and commitment who stands up for what he believes in and who says precisely what he thinks. His character and integrity are acknowledged by even those who oppose him and his meticulously proper, truthful, honourable and scrupulously ethical approach to the performance of the duties of the high public office which he holds stamps him without doubt as one of the great leaders of the free world today.

SPEECH.PARA: Having recently been in Washington, during which visit it was my great privilege to meet Mr Richard L. Armitage, United States Assistant Secretary for Defense and universally recognised as Mr Weinberger's outstanding lieutenant, I believe it is appropriate that I speak today on the Australian-United States alliance so critical and fundamental for the preservation of our way of life in our two great countries and to ensure that the freedom for which we fought together and which we successfully defended in World War II is preserved and maintained without any qualification or reservation whatsoever. The historic alliance forged between those two great leaders of World War II, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Curtin, must be maintained and must be strengthened, not just for the present but to ensure the future for our children, our children's children and continuing generations.

In the light of the foregoing, it is absolutely imperative that the discussions which take place between Mr Weinberger and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and senior members of the Hawke socialist Government are utterly frank and completely candid. I have no doubts at all as to Mr Weinberger's position. My grave concern is in relation to the views which will be expressed to him by the Hawke socialist Government and in particular as to whether these views truly reflect the will of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unlikely.

—It is a problem the honourable member and I both agree upon. It has been said before and it gives me no pleasure to say it again today that the Australian-United States alliance, by accident or design, has been grievously weakened because of the actions of the Hawke socialist Government since it came to power.
—Hear, hear!

—In so many ways this Government-and I acknowledge the presence of the distinguished and honourable member for Franklin-the Hawke socialist Government has been guilty of weakening, white anting and downgrading this vital alliance to the dismay of Washington and to the obvious delight of Moscow. Through a combination of incompetence and blatant appeasement of the mad Left represented in this Parliament by those who occupy Moscow corner, we have seen Australia's standing as a trusted ally of the United States diminished. I do not believe that Washington today regards the present Australian Government in the same light and in the same high esteem in which it regarded the Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Fraser governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst Australia has not reached the depths to which New Zealand has sunk under comrade Lange, it must be said that if the lunatic Left in this Parliament gets it way that position could well be reached before the Hawke socialist Government's present term of office is brought to an abrupt end, at the next Federal election. I feel obliged to repeat today the remarks I made in this House on 25 February 1985. I quote verbatim:

The Hawke socialist Government . . . have betrayed Australia's interests in the international scene. The ANZUS Treaty fiasco of recent weeks has done more to damage the national security of Australia than anything else since World War II. For this to occur in peacetime is an appalling indictment of a Prime Minister who is prepared to put appeasement of party factions ahead of national interest. As the (then) Leader of the Opposition so eloquently stated on Friday, this is a Government whose actions in recent times have done enormous damage to the ANZUS alliance. I can see no difference in principle between the actions of comrade Lange and his Government and the actions of Prime Minister Hawke and the Hawke socialist Government. I am absolutely convinced that the United States will never be able to trust the word of Australia while the Hawke socialist Government remains in office.

We now see publicly exposed a Prime Minister who has let his country down. Quite bluntly, we now have a situation in which a second grade Prime Minister has tried to turn this great country-Australia-into a third world country in response to the urgings of fourth graders and fifth columnists. That is what the Government has done. The Prime Minister's recent visit to the United States was a disaster of unparalleled proportions. The headlines of the United States Press tell it all. Listen to this, Mr Deputy Speaker: `Australia balks on the accord to aid in United States test of MX; Premier cites split in Party' that was on the front page of the New York Times-`Australia takes middle position in the US-New Zealand dispute' . . .
The Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt), a future Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, said: `What paper?' I repeated, I said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should be aware that he cannot anticipate or revive debate in the House. If the member has something original to add as a contribution, he should do it. I ask the honourable member to cease reading what he has previously said in the House.

—Indeed; and, Mr Deputy Speaker, your timing, as well as your support for ANZUS, is impeccable because I was not going to quote myself any further. I was simply going to quote what Bernard Gwertzman, a leading American writer, wrote at that time. This was read by millions of our American friends. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke sought to put himself in a middle position between Australia's two allies in the alliance.

That was a fundamental error which is perpetuated today. To pretend that the Lange backdown is simply a matter between New Zealand and the United States is to completely misunderstand that ANZUS is a vital and fundamental tripartite defence treaty. It is like a three-strand cord. If we take away one strand it put increased strain on the remaining two strands. To Australia's great shame, we have not played our part in bringing New Zealand back into the fold of the ANZUS alliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I go there next month I might.

—The honourable member will be going there next month. Mr Lange and his Government have diabolically damaged the most fundamental defence treaty for this part of the world-not just for Australia and New Zealand but, as Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore has pointed out in the last 10 days, it is critical to the defence of this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The reports in the United States Press were obviously mirrored by the reports in the Soviet Press. I simply say, noting the presence of some interesting honourable members in the chamber right now, that it was no surprise that Pravda greeted with great excitement, joy and adulation the revision, as it put it, of Australia's position in relation to the United States. I simply quote as I think I should, direct from the Novosti Press Agency-APN-of Zubovsky Bulvar, 4119021 Moscow, well known to many members opposite, exactly what it said because it greeted with delight the situation that the ANZUS position had been revised. Really, as I said earlier, if anybody has been made happy over the last three years as to what has happened to ANZUS, it is Moscow. I am surprised that the agency has not put through an official signal that the Prime Minister from now on is to be paid in roubles, because quite frankly every time he has moved on defence or foreign affairs it has upset the United States, he has upset our allies and he has delighted Moscow.

Now good times are ahead, because when this Government goes out-as it will at the next election-an incoming Liberal-National Party government will do two fundamental things: It will restore and uphold ANZUS, it will bring New Zealand to boot and it will ensure that this three-fold cord, this tripartite treaty, is restored to the strength it had under Curtin and Roosevelt. Secondly, unlike those shimmy-shammy Moscow supporters opposite, we will support Australian participation in the strategic defence initiative because the SDI is vital to the maintenance of the free world. It is the only thing that will bring the Soviet Union to boot. We will not crawl around on the edges we will say: `No. We will be in it; we will give it total 150 per cent support.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I can bring the debate back into the realms of reality and talk about a real world, rather than the nightmares and the fantasies of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman).
—Go back to the Soviet embassy, Peter.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That there are difficulties in rural Australia is without question. We in this House may debate the intensity and location of this downturn. We can debate the reasons, though it is fair to say that it is difficult to debate anything in this House with members of the Opposition, who are concerned more with rhetoric than fact, and more with fiction and fantasy than with reality. Of course, we heard a great deal of that a few moments ago.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the matter which I raise today I feel sure will be supported by members of the Opposition; it is so simple that they will indeed understand the issues. I have in my hand a small jar of marmalade. It is only half full, because I have taken the trouble to sample the contents. The marmalade was made by W.A. Baxter and Sons Ltd and, as the label informs us, Baxters are the makers of Scotland's finest preserves since 1868. That is a claim I do not wish to dispute, for after all they are by appointment the Queen's marmalade makers. I have in my other hand a container of marmalade made by Kraft Australia. I can assure the House that while this container is unopened, I have sampled Kraft products in the past and they are excellent. Unlike Baxter's marmalade, Kraft contains Australian fruits and is made by Australian labour; and Kraft is not appointed by the Queen. There is no doubt that many members of the Opposition, knowing that the Queen enjoys her Baxter's, would reach for the same label, but I am concerned that the majority of honourable members would prefer the Australian product.

My concern is that the Baxter's marmalade was served to me whilst on a Trans Australia Airlines flight. The Kraft marmalade was served to me on an Ansett Airlines of Australia flight. In the same week I received the Baxter's I was served by TAA with a jar of raspberry jam made in France. It does little for the image of Australia to have a publicly-owned airline serving foreign-produced rural products when Australian farmers and Australian workers arguably produce a better product. It does not help that the European product can compete on price only due to unfair and anti-trade subsidisation. It is time that all Australians realised that European rural products are inferior to Australian-produced foods. Our preserves, our dairy products, our fruits are without question fresher and superior to their European counterparts.

The Livestock and Grain Producers Association and other similar farm groups in Australia can become as radical as they like and they can protest around the precincts of this House, but their radicalism will not change the international commodity market. We certainly do not see the Agricultural Council of the European Economic Community losing sleep over statements made by Mr Ryan, Mr Tooth or, for that matter, Mr McLachlan. My concern is the great malaise which affects this country when an Australian-owned airline, a publicly-owned airline, can serve, without question, foreign-produced goods. I believe that to be fundamentally wrong. Another matter which concerns me is the fact that TAA serves butter in a container on which the name of the manufacturer and the area in which it is produced are not listed. I firmly believe it to be made in New Zealand.

My attitude to this is very clear, and I hope that all members of this House and the Australian community will support me. I call on all honourable members here to tell TAA in no uncertain terms that, until such time as it serves Australian-produced rural products and Australian-produced foodstuffs on its aircraft, we will not use its airline. I, for one, will announce today that I will refuse to fly TAA until such time as TAA tells me that it has changed its policy and that it is not going to produce European jams or use New Zealand butter. As Ansett is using Australian-made butter and Australian-made jams on its flights, I will certainly fly Ansett; and I call upon every member of this House to do the same thing.

It goes beyond TAA; it goes beyond jams; it goes beyond dairy produce. One of my great concerns is that in travelling around Australia as a member of the rural task force I see Volvos and Mercedes Benz throughout rural Australia. If Australian farmers, who are crying out for changes in the tariff situation in regard to our balance of trade payments want to buy foreign-produced cars, they should be told they are only adding to the balance of payments problem this country has; and it is time every Australian started thinking seriously about where they are buying their products. That includes farmers. They also add materially to our foreign problems today. I hope that, by this speech, all Australians will start to buy Australian products-and that includes farmers and everyone else-so that in future we can recognise that our problems can be solved internally, that we can do a great deal to help ourselves and that we can do a great deal to help our Australian farmers by very simple techniques, very simple measures, which are of great importance to every producer, both secondary and rural, in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Trade. I refer the Minister to the question which I directed to him yesterday and to his answer. Why, last night, did the Minister initially deny knowledge of this mother's 30,000 Bell Group Ltd shares valued at nearly a quarter of a million dollars and later change his story, subsequently admitting that he did in fact know?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, of course, did not change my story. Perhaps I should say that when the ministerial committee was established I raised with the Cabinet the need to ensure that none of the members of that committee had a personal or direct interest in either of the companies involved. When I asked the Prime Minister to join that committee, because of the major contribution that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd makes to exports from this country, I naturally considered whether I myself had a conflict of interest. Having no shares myself or in any of my immediate family, I determined that I had no conflict of interest. While I was generally aware that my mother had an interest in shares in the Bell Group, I had no idea as the the magnitude of that interest. I knew that it had existed at some stage and assumed that it still did exist. But the fact that I was generally aware that my mother had an interest did not mean that I had an interest. Her shares were not my shares and that did not involve any direct or, indeed, indirect interest as far as I was concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I complied with the rules as established by the Prime Minister for Ministers and, indeed, the rules accepted by this House for members of this House. To say that my mother's shares constitute an interest for me is greatly to extend the rules, not for everybody but just for me on this occasion. It should be obvious to at least some members of the Opposition that Ministers are called upon on a daily basis to take decisions which may advantage or disadvantage companies. To say that it is necessary for Ministers to declare the interests, even those of which they are aware, of their extended families-where does it end: Mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts, cousins-and presumably those of the extended families' spouses as well, not to mention the interests of their business or professional partners, or even close friends, is to extend the rules unreasonably and, if I might say so, nonsensically.

I support the pecuniary interest rules, which is more than I can say for the Opposition. However, I insist that the rules need to be both universal and workable. If I might quote the authority of Erskine May, the following comment is made in the publication Parliamentary Practice:
. . . this interest must be immediate and personal, and not merely of a general or remote character.

Indeed, the committee of this House which looked at the registration of interests has referred to the problems involving the registration of the interests of a member's spouse. Those problems, of course, to the extent that they exist, are magnified tremendously the more remote the person who holds the interest becomes from the member or Minister. I am absolutely convinced that to extend the existing rules would cause chaos. Might I say that to have the suggestion that the existing rules should be extended coming from the Opposition, which does not even support the existing arrangements for registration, is little short of rank hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister indicate to the House whether the latest statistics confirm that there is continued strong employment growth?

—The labour force statistics for March were released today and they provide what the Government judges to be an accurate picture of the labour market at the moment, with the level of unemployment below 600,000 and with continuing growth in employment overall. Significantly, the level of unemployment in March rose by 27,200, bringing the total rise in employment since the low point of April 1983 to 617,600. The level of unemployment in March fell by 4,500 to 595,600. As an indication of the strength of employment growth in recent months, employment increased by over 80,000-80,100 to be exact-between December of 1985 and March of 1986. On the figures for this financial year, employment has now grown by 3.7 per cent, which is, as I think all honourable members will appreciate, very substantially beyond Budget projections. I am not suggesting that this very buoyant rate of employment growth will be continued for the rest of this year, but the general picture is one which I believe must continue to give very substantial satisfaction to the Australian community. The commitment of this Government to creating jobs is very clearly being sustained and the economic policies that the Government is pursuing will ensure that these results will be maintained.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to his previous answer. I again ask the Minister: Why did he at first deny any knowledge of his mother's ownership of shares in Bell Group Ltd and subsequently change his story?

—One of the reasons the Leader of the Opposition has a popularity rating of 30 per cent is that he persists with irrelevant issues such as this and has decided to get down into the gutter with other members of his front bench. To answer specifically the question of the Leader of the Opposition, as I said in answer to the first question that was addressed to me this afternoon, I did not change my story. A series of questions were put to my office at various times after Question Time yesterday. None of the questions was put directly to me. The story, when it was asked directly of me, was as I have given it to the House this afternoon.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Construction, refers to the agreement by the Government in relation to housing interest rates. I ask: Are the banks firmly committed to lending $6 billion for housing in 1986-87? What are the arrangements for the payment of the subsidy by the Government? Will the Government closely monitor the banks' lending performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The banks' commitments are firm and the Government intends to have them in written form as well as a commitment to a suitable effort to make low start loans available to low income borrowers before paying the first instalment of the envisaged subsidy. Continuation of the payment of the subsidy will be subject to review. Payments will be withheld if banks fail to meet their commitments. As members of the House will recall, the major savings banks are offered a maximum subsidy of $120m, equivalent to two-thirds of one per cent of those banks' deposits in savings investment accounts and statement accounts. The total of those accounts held by the banks is $18 billion. So the Commonwealth, as far as the four major savings banks are concerned, is committed to a maximum outlay of $120m and the banks are to meet the other one-third, that is $60m.

ANSWER.PARA: I inform the House that the Treasurer has already written to other savings banks that have made home loans available within the ceiling, offering them a subsidy payment on the same basis as the major banks on the condition that they also take early steps to lend more for housing and that they continue to lend their share of aggregate savings banks' lending of $6 billion for 1986-87. That picks up the State savings bank. This will mean a moderate increase to the Commonwealth's financial obligation as outlined in the package. We will be willing to pay 40 per cent of the total sum in the first quarter of 1986-87-that is, the June quarter 1986-25 per cent in the next quarter, 20 per cent in the next, and 15 per cent in the next.

The need to continue the payments will be assessed before the end of each quarter, taking into consideration interest rate developments and whether the banks continue to meet their side of the bargain. We intend to introduce as soon as possible legislation giving effect to the subsidy scheme. The first subsidy payments will be made after the banks concerned have given firm commitments to use that subsidy to provide improved deposit interest rates, to take early steps to lend more for housing in the present quarter, and to continue lending so that aggregate lending for housing by savings banks will be $6 billion in 1986-87. We intend that the legislation will provide the Treasurer with the power to withhold subsidy payments from any individual bank which does not fulfil the undertakings made at the inception of the subsidy arrangements.

Finally, with regard to monitoring, we will be using the resources of the Reserve Bank and the Treasury to monitor the use made by the banks of the subsidy, the rate of new lending for housing by each bank, and the availability to low and middle income borrowers of low start loans and other loans which are structured to meet the borrowers' requirements. We are confident that those arrangements will give a significant lift to housing construction in this country and will greatly assist in meeting the genuine housing aspirations of our fellow Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. In the light of his advice to the House that prior to the meeting of the sub-committee of Cabinet of which he had asked to be a member he had asked his colleagues to disclose whether or not they had any direct or indirect interest in shares in either of the companies concerned, did he at any time consider that the deliberations of that sub-committee could have a material effect on the value of the shares in Bell Resources Ltd in which he knew his mother had at least some shares, albeit he might not have known that they were 30,000 in number?

—I have answered the substance of the question. What I actually said was not quite what the Leader of the National Party of Australia said. It related to the personal and direct interests of those people who intended to be members of that ministerial committee. That was the case in relation to other Ministers. That was the case in relation to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. In a question addressed to the United States Secretary of Defense on this morning's Today show, the interviewer referred to the Government's defence capability review as advocating a Fortress Australia strategy. Is this an accurate characterisation of the thrust of the Dibb review or, for that matter, of the Government's defence policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker-
—Just say yes and sit down.

—I will say no and I will not sit down. That statement is not an accurate reflection of the Government's defence policy or of the Dibb review. The first thing I say about the Dibb review is that I do not intend to canvass its contents at this stage.
—The Bulletin did it very well.

—No, it did not. I intend to table a public version of the report in this place, make a statement on it, and allow a thoroughgoing debate on it in about four or five weeks. That is about the amount of time it will take to get that version properly produced and printed and a statement approved by Cabinet. The policy of the Government is one of defence self-reliance, and that is a very different matter from a policy of Fortress Australia. Over time, Fortress Australia has come to mean a country bristling with weapons, essentially unconcerned with anything beyond its borders. It is an extraordinarily expensive and also an extraordinarily selfish policy perspective. Neither of those elements are contained in the Australian Labor Party's defence policy and the policies that are being pursued by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We pursue a strategy of defence self-reliance, which means that Australia should be capable of dealing with threats which arise to its security from its own region or from across countries within this region, not in conflict with a major super-power. We regard that as a minimum condition for the proper exercise of national sovereignty. To do less than that, to be less capable than that, is both demeaning and potentially dangerous. We will not support policies which contradict that. However, we fully recognise that we have obligations in this area and that there are a number of countries in this area which seek reassurance from Australia both in the relationships we have with them and also the relationships we have with the United States of America.

We have an extensive defence co-operation program in place, both formally and informally, for exercising and for other purposes with most of the countries of our region. We are assuming very carefully and modestly additional responsibilities in the south-west Pacific. That is reflected in the way in which we have approached the obligation on us to provide some maritime surveillance in the area with our Orion PC3 aircraft and also to provide a surveillance capability for countries in the region with the Pacific patrol boat program. They are all important as indicators to the countries in that area that Australia regards their security problems as matters of concern to it. We do not pursue, therefore, an isolationist, selfish or inordinately expensive policy. That is what is implied by the term Fortress Australia.

I am glad that the honourable gentleman asked this question, because I do not think that it is going to assist the type of debate that will take place in this country if areas of honest agreement, disagreement or whatever, between various sides are going to be prohibited or in any way compromised by resorting to terms which simply do not represent the case that is being put before the community or the policies of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Trade answer a very simple question and answer it in a straightforward way? In light of the request that he made to his own colleagues to declare any interests that they may have had in Bell Resources Ltd or the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, why-and I repeat the question-did he not then declare the full extent of his own knowledge of the interest held by a member of his own immediate family in one of those companies? Secondly, when he went to the Cabinet, did he make any declaration at all at the Cabinet meeting itself or make any requests that other Ministers should make a declaration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not expect anything other than simple questions from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, but this happens to be simple-minded as well. He will get a simple answer from me, and that is that the rules as they have been determined and laid down, where they have been laid down in Australia, including in this House, define `immediate family' as being that of the honourable member, a spouse if one exists, and any children if they exist, that is, children who are dependent on the honourable member or the Minister. They are the rules which have been established by this Government and are not, I might say, supported by the Opposition. So if there is any allegation of hypocrisy, I would suggest that members of the Opposition look to themselves rather than to this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have complied with the rules as they have been laid down. As I said before, I have no interest. Anyone would think that this was the only occasion on which Ministers might be involved in decisions which affect the fortunes of companies, but contemplate for a moment the situation confronted by the Treasurer dealing with a Foreign Investment Review Board application involving a foreign takeover of an Australian company or indeed a recommendation from the Commissioner of Taxation relating to the taxation of a firm or collection of firms; the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce dealing with a recommendation from the Industries Assistance Commission to increase or decrease the amount of assistance available to a firm or firms; the Attorney-General dealing with a recommendation from the Trade Practices Commission or the National Companies and Securities Commission; the Minister for Resources and Energy in relation to a proposal to increase or decrease crude oil prices; the Minister for Trade in relation to the export price for coal; the Minister for Health in relation to the price of pharmaceuticals; the Minister for Communications in relation to media ownership; the Minister for Aviation in relation to the two airlines agreement; the Minister for Defence as he awards defence contracts-in all those cases one thing is absolutely clear and has been observed by this Government scrupulously and that is that the Minister ought to declare, in general terms publicly, and in specific terms to the Prime Minister, what his interests might be that would conflict with any of those decisions.

To extend that to require those Ministers to be aware or to declare the interests that might be held by their mothers, fathers, their spouse's mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles, cousins, brothers, sisters and so on would simply be extending the rules to an extent that would make them entirely unworkable, and I suspect that that is what the Opposition really wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: Secondly, I asked the Minister whether he made any declaration whatsoever.
—Order! The Minister has answered the question. There is no point of order.
—Madam Speaker, it is a point of order. Would you hear me briefly?
—If the Minister did not answer the question in the manner that the honourable member wanted, that is unfortunate.
—The point of order, Madam Speaker, that I still have not put is that I asked the Minister whether when he went to the Cabinet he made a declaration.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services tell the House what the Hawke Government has achieved in developing child care in North Queensland? Have government policies, including funding charges which came into effect a week ago, encouraged the expansion of child care in line with the Government's commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Nothing more marked the destruction of community infrastructure under the Fraser-Howard Government than its failure to meet the needs of society pertaining to adequate child care. When we came to office in 1983 there were only enough government care places for 4.5 per cent of Australian children under the age of five years. This was one of the major causes of difficulty many women faced either in staying in or getting back into the work force. It was also one of the major causes of poverty amongst sole supporting parents. That is why the Government made a major commitment to double the number of child care places. The planning, building and equipment for 20,000 places that this involves are well under way.

ANSWER.PARA: Agreement has been reached with all the States that these child care places are located in areas of greatest need. In areas north of Townsville the Government has approved a third more centres involving 160 new places. This includes four long-day care centres, two Aboriginal child care agencies and four outside school-hours care. In all, we have approved 12 new centres in addition to the 36 that were there before 1983.

The Government has been assisted in all of this by the advice of the honourable member for Herbert and his colleague, the honourable member for Leichhardt. This steady growth in child care will lead to an extra 6,000 jobs for teachers. nurses and holders of child care certificates around Australia. It will help all women, including sole supporting parents, to take their rightful place in society.

So it is very disappointing to see that, at the same time when the Government is trying to break down barriers for women, the Queensland Government is busy pushing the most reactionary and conservative of attitudes. All this week the Queensland media have been full of the astonishing views of the Minister for Welfare Services, Youth and Ethnic Affairs, Mrs Chapman. Mrs Chapman has a quaint commitment to rather old fashioned values and wants to stop payment to sole supporting parents after the first child. She asked: `Where else in the world does a taxpayer pay for someone else's love life? The male has his lap of luxury for the night and then nicks off. Every child should have a mother and father who share the responsibility of raising that child half and half'.

Mrs Chapman, who appears to live in at least the eighteenth century, reminds us that, once upon a time, if a child were born out of wedlock, the matter was kept quiet and the child was raised by the mother's family or else, as she suggested, the child could be sent to an orphanage or adopted out. In this afternoon's Brisbane Telegraph she says that she has a list of single mothers who are living on taxpayers' money.

These ludicrous views are typical of much of the hatred of the poor coming from the extreme right wing fringe behind the Opposition. I ask the honourable interjecting-the honourable member for Richmond, the spokesman for social security and other members of the National Party of Australia-to dissociate themselves from the kinds of comments that we have had from the Queensland Minister who belongs to the same Party as the Leader of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you hate little Australians?
—The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting at once. He will heed the Chair.

—It will be an almighty change. I think it is extraordinary in this day and age that when a Minister of the Queensland Government indicates those sorts of punitive and insensitive attitudes to the poorest group in Australian society no member of the Opposition, in either the National Party or the Liberal Party, takes the time to dissociate himself from those remarks. Let me say that this Government does dissociate itself from those kinds of attitudes. We hear about women who are unfortunate enough to be supporting parents, but nothing is said on behalf of the liable parents who are not carrying the load. The punitive attitudes of those people towards supporting parents ought to be rejected. We do reject them and we believe that the policy that I have referred to in terms of the provision of child care places is one constructive way in which we can seek to enable people who are in difficult circumstances to participate in normal community life.

—I ask the Minister for Trade whether it is a fact that, at the time when the meeting of the Cabinet sub-committee of which he was a member and which inquired into the Bell Group Ltd takeover of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd took place, there was a reasonable expectation that he would be a beneficiary to his mother's estate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that the honourable member for O'Connor has decided to drag my mother's name into this House. On the question of hypocrisy which seems to be exercising the minds of some members of the Opposition, I remind them that it was the Fraser Government which in 1978 established under Sir Nigel Bowen a Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest.
—You are not going to answer this one, either?

—Yes, I am coming to the answer, but I thought I would remind honourable members opposite of their former, more principled position. When the Committee reported and established what it recommended as a code, it stated:

ANSWER.PARA: When the interests of members of his immediate family are involved, the officeholder should disclose those interests to the extent they are known to him.

In the description of immediate family and dealing with the question of family interest, the Committee used the accepted terminology of `spouse and dependent children'. On 22 November 1979, the then Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, stated:
The Government has accepted the code of conduct in principle.

He went on to say that the Government reiterated the Committee's emphasis on the questions of privacy. The Committee established by the Fraser Government-the recommendations of which were accepted by the Fraser Government, a number of whose members now sit here, stagnating on the Opposition benches, and they are likely to stay there for some time-stated that the questions of privacy involving the interests of people other than the member, Minister or officeholder were to be given the greatest possible emphasis and those people were to be protected. Now, of course, not only do we have the Opposition, supported by the Leader of the Opposition, dragging into the public arena the interests of my mother-which I would have thought she was entitled to have protected, as indeed any person is entitled to have protected if not elected to public office-but we are being invited to speculate, apparently, on the contents of her will-

TALK.START.PARA: —And her demise.

—Indeed, the portent of her demise. From my point of view I can say that she is in very fine fettle. I have no idea what is included in her will and I would have thought that that was something quintessentially for her to determine.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he has noted a rather shrill article by David Barnett, presently a journalist with the Bulletin and sometime personal secretary, speechwriter, confidant and adviser to former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. Is there any justification for Mr Barnett's claims of unbalanced staffing between various branches of the Department of Foreign Affairs; that officers refuse hardship postings more often than in the past; that officers transfer in and out of the Department to speed their progress up the ladder, service ministerial officers and join political parties for advancement; and his declaration that homosexuality is a sin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly is true, as the honourable member points out, that David Barnett was chief speechwriter, confidant and adviser to Malcolm Fraser. Look where Malcolm Fraser ended up! The article is unbalanced and misleading and, more than that, it is mischievous and maliciously so. It has quite consciously distorted the facts, and I will give some of them in response to the points which were made in that article. I suggest before I start, however, that it is about time that Mr Barnett remembered that he is no longer working for a political party and that he should be seeking to disseminate information on a more balanced basis.
—Oh, you have got to be joking.

—The Leader of the Opposition is jumping around because he has a problem. He has saddle sores on his brain. Every time he thinks, it hurts. I will attend to some of the matters which were raised by David Barnett. In regard to staff deployments, all the branches and sections named in the article are better staffed now than they were in October 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: In particular, the United States of America Section has more staff now than it had in October 1982, while the Canada, Caribbean and Latin America Section has the same number as it had in 1982. The South East Asia Branch had 11 officers in 1982. It has 16 today. There are three branches-nuclear policy, disarmament and arms control, and peace and disarmament-in the nuclear disarmament area, not two, with a total staff of 20.

The number of staff in a branch or section does not in itself reflect accurately the state of relations with a country, nor does it account fully for the commitment of resources to relations with the countries concerned. For example, in the case of relations with the United States, for instance, aspects of the relationship relating to matters such as economic relations, civil aviation and arms control are handled in other areas of the Department. They make a demand on a fairly large number of our available resources. In the case of Japan, in addition to the officers in the Japan Section, the Japan secretariat has four officers and the Australia Japan Foundation has seven.

In considering resource deployments, account should also be taken of the number of staff in overseas missions. All of these things, I repeat, are relevant to points which Mr Barnett made. In the United States, in Washington, there are 153 A-based officers. In Canada there are 22. In all of Central and Southern America, where there are eight posts, there are only 58-fewer on average than eight per post. It is, of course, inaccurate to claim that Australia plays no significant part in nuclear disarmament affairs. To date, no overseas position has had to be left unfilled for want of an officer willing to take it. But there is no doubt that there are quite a number of overseas posts which by any measure are hardship posts. They are not attractive and it takes a great deal of dedication for an officer to be prepared to fill some of those posts.

It is also unreasonable to say that working in a ministerial office is necessarily a guaranteed escalator to promotion. An officer who worked for one of my predecessors for an extensive period, as far as I am concerned is one of the most highly regarded officers in the Department.
