I rely on his judgment, analysis and advice quite implicitly in those areas where he has represented this country. When he recently completed one post, I had no hesitation in moving quickly to appoint him to a very senior post at another place overseas. He has my complete confidence. I do not think that we ought to introduce that element into differences between us, because that is being unfair to professional public servants.

Mr Barnett seems to have discovered that it is a sin to be a homosexual. I think that this Parliament has debated that issue well enough previously. It is a matter of personal pride on my part that, in the early 1960s, before this issue became fashionable as being an issue to defend on behalf of a minority group, I raised this issue in this Parliament. I have no hesitation at all in maintaining my defence of the rights of all groups in our community, including minority groups such as homosexuals. Legislation has been passed by this Parliament, the Public Service Reform Act 1984 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, which in fact make it an offence to discriminate against people on grounds such as homosexuality.

The only other thing that I want to say is this: Policy decisions are made by the Government of the day. The political objectives of the Government certainly colour those decisions. That is understandable. Debates are conducted in this chamber between us in relation to those differences. In determining what our policy is, we go through certain processes and we then instruct the public servants as to what we expect to be done. In all my experience as Minister for Social Security and as Treasurer in an earlier Labor government, and now as Minister for Foreign Affairs, I have nothing but praise for the officers with whom I have worked. They have worked diligently and faithfully, and they have worked despite any political differences that they might have personally held. To the extent that those officers held those views or might hold them, I do not care; as long as they serve the government of the day and this country well and faithfully we cannot ask more of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the House that we have in the gallery the former member for Hughes, the present Australian High Commissioner to New Zealand, Les Johnson, and we welcome him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his statement of 22 September 1983 on the subject of public duty and private interest, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers had to make a declaration at meetings of the Cabinet or its committees of any matter which may give rise to a conflict of interest.

I suggest to the honourable gentleman that that is the only relevant point at issue in this matter. As the Minister for Trade knew of his mother's shares in the Bell company and that such knowledge may or might give rise to a conflict of interest on his part, and as he failed to inform the Cabinet sub-committee meeting of that knowledge, will the Prime Minister now demand the resignation of the Minister for Trade, or will he have the courage to sack him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question from the Leader of the Opposition is no. I have complete confidence in the integrity of the Minister for Trade. Madam Speaker, let us attempt to bring an end to this disgraceful episode on the part of the Opposition.
—We are going to have some simulated outrage now.
—Order!

—The facts are quite clear. Let me go through them. As I said in my brief statement last night, the Minister for Trade advised me yesterday evening that he had been generally aware that his mother held some Bell shares but that he was not aware of the details of the holding. Following my conversations with him, I repeated the immediate statement that I made after Question Time in this House yesterday, of my complete confidence in the integrity of the Minister. Now, Madam Speaker, let us look at the factual situation. The position in regard to Ministers-and it is in the context of that matter that I have spoken before in the House-is contained in paragraph 2.15 of a document under the heading `Declaration of interests'. The paragraph reads:

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from these formal declarations, Ministers at meetings of the Ministry, Cabinet and committees must declare any private interests, pecuniary or non-pecuniary, held by themselves or members of their immediate families in matters under discussion where those interests conflict or might possibly conflict with their public duty as Ministers.

That is the statement with regard to Ministers and their immediate families. That is reflected in the explanatory notes which were sent to Ministers. Those notes are headed `Return of Private Interests Explanatory Notes'. In that document, these words appear:
Note the need to include under all headings interests of immediate family members to the extent they are aware of them (Spouse including de facto spouse, and dependent children).

That statement as to immediate family is completely reflected in the recent statement on the registration and declaration of members' interests flowing out of the resolution of this House in 1984 and amended by this House on 13 February 1986, in which the reference is:
. . . the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (a) of the Member's spouse and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support.

It is quite clear that that is a sensible delineation of the proper area of responsibility of a Minister in these matters. I ask you, Madam Speaker, and honourable members of the House to contemplate, as the Minister for Trade properly has asked this House and the people of Australia to contemplate, where we go if we extend the area of delineation beyond that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the rest of it.
—Order!
—You did. Your side did.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.
—Well, he ought to answer the question.
—Order!
—He ought to answer the question.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition. If he continues to interject across the table, I will name him.
—Well, why don't you tell him to answer the question?
—Order! I call the Prime Minister.
—Why does he not read the rest of it?
—Order!
—Read on. Read the rest of it.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar! I call the Prime Minister.

—I ask the House to contemplate the stupidity, the unreality and the unworkability of extending that concept of `immediate family' to the area to which, by their questioning, these paragons of virtue sitting opposite would seek to extend it. Let me make it clear that in seeking to explain the stupidity of their position by this example I obviously intend no reflection on, no disrespect to and in no way do I raise any question of the integrity of the people involved. I simply go to this example to show the fatuity, the stupidity, of what has been suggested on the other side. I refer to the situation of my predecessor, Malcolm Fraser, who has a mother who, I understand, is a woman of reasonably considerable wealth.
—Holding attacked his father-in-law.

—Is it suggested that when Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister and any matter came before the Cabinet for consideration which possibly could have gone to some matter in which Mrs Una Fraser had an interest Malcolm Fraser should have said: `Colleagues, I'm sorry, stop. I cannot consider this'?
—He did. You are wrong; he did.
—Yes? Every time--
—Clyde Holding attacked his father-in-law.
—Order!
—You are wrong. That Minister attacked his father-in-law.
—Order!
—That is exactly what he did. You are wrong.
—Order!
—He can't get away with this. He is getting away with murder. You are wrong, Hawke.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—Clyde Holding attacked his father-in-law. You are wrong.
—I warn the Leader of the Opposition that he has now gone beyond what is acceptable to the Chair. At his next utterance, I will name him.

—It beggars description that in the case of either Malcolm Fraser or any of the Ministers in the previous Government when matters came before them in which their mothers or their fathers or their brothers or their sisters could have had an interest that the proceedings were interrupted on every occasion and that Ministers were jumping up saying: `I am sorry, I cannot deal with this matter because my mother, my father, my brother, my sister, the members of my extended family have an interest in it'. The fact is that of course that did not happen. It would render the processes of government absolutely impossible.

ANSWER.PARA: Just as it was not the characteristic of the previous Government that that was done by either the Prime Minister or other Ministers in regard to their non-immediate family members, neither is it required under the provisions of the Cabinet handbook to which I have referred. It is quite clear that it is not required. In the case of the Minister for Trade it is quite clear that he addressed his mind to this question and that he came to the conclusion, properly in my judgment, that there was no conflict of interest as far as he was concerned. The fact is that members of this Opposition from the depths of their hypocrisy, while rejecting for themselves and their immediate family the concept of declaration of interest-they will not accept it for themselves or their immediate family-in this case seek to extend it beyond the immediate family for my friend and colleague the Minister for Trade. They are nothing but a bunch of incompetent hypocrites and will be judged as such by the people of this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: GENERAL PURPOSE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to be able to inform the House that the Government has decided to continue with a program of untied grants to local government following its consideration of the findings and recommendations of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. In announcing the inquiry on 9 May 1984 the Prime Minister stated that the review provided `a unique opportunity for a historic reappraisal of Local Government functions and resources. The Inquiry should lay the foundations for a more stable, efficient and equitable system of resourcing Local Government's expanding functions'.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry was commissioned with a view to improving the program of general purpose financial assistance for local government. The program had not been publicly reviewed since its inception in 1976. There were differences of State practice regarding the distribution of grants to local government. The reasons and methods accounting for these differences were not evident to the Commonwealth; nor were the methods of allocation by the State Grants Commissions always clear to local government bodies. There were no criteria available to the Commonwealth for assessing the adequacy of the funding level for achieving the purposes of the program. The program warranted review.

The committee of inquiry undertook extensive investigations and consultations with the States and local government. It produced a comprehensive report which is an invaluable contribution to the future development of local government. On 13 November 1985; I tabled the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and indicated my intention to seek the views of the States and local government prior to the Government making any decisions concerning the recommendations of the report. These views were received at a meeting of the Local Government Ministers' Conference, in subsequent correspondence from State Premiers, and in consultations with the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. A considerable measure of agreement was reached on fundamental issues. The consultations were extremely helpful to the Government in its consideration of the report of the inquiry. I would like to thank the States, particularly my fellow State local government Ministers, and the representatives of local government for the spirit in which they responded in what was a necessarily tight time frame.

The overall finding of the inquiry was that the Commonwealth should maintain a program of general purpose support for local government, but that the character of the program should be changed in certain respects. The Government accepts this. We propose to replace the current Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act in this session with an Act that allows for the provision of a program of general purpose financial assistance to local government. The program will be funded on a base equal to the payments in 1985-86. Payments in 1986-87 and 1987-88 will be subject to a real term guarantee. Subject to that guarantee the percentage increase in payments to local government in each of these two years will be no less than the percentage increase in the sum of the general revenue grants plus general purpose capital assistance to the States in each of these years. In subsequent years, the percentage changes in the amount of general purpose financial assistance provided to local government will be no less than the percentage changes applying to general purpose and capital payments to the States.

The principal objective of the new program will be to provide financial assistance to those local councils who are most disadvantaged in respect of their ability to raise revenue and to provide services. That is, assistance will be provided principally for the purposes of horizontal equalisation.

At the same time, the Government recognises that local government, as a whole, has a restricted base from which to raise revenue to finance expanding functions. Because of this it is proposed to provide for a guaranteed minimum per capita entitlement to each council. This would be calculated using a base of 30 per cent of the funds available to each State. This will ensure that every council continues to receive benefits from the program. This will allow local government a stable financial base from which to develop its forward plans. It will eliminate the volatility that was characteristic of the previous tax sharing arrangements.

The Government has accepted the view that the basis of distribution between the States is now outdated. In the interests of simplicity, it proposes to phase in new relativities based on population distribution between the States and then to adjust these yearly to account for changes in population. Subject to the Northern Territory Government agreeing to a offsetting reduction in its general purpose assistance from the Commonwealth, we have also decided to include the Northern Territory under the new arrangements so as to place councils in the Territory on the same footing as those in the States. Provision will be made for Aboriginal local government in the Territory to receive funds under the program. I believe this is an important step forward and commend the Northern Territory Government for its initiatives in this area. An interdepartmental task force will be established to examine with the States and the Northern Territory Aboriginal issues raised by the inquiry.

The Government recognises the important role played by the State Local Government Grants Commissions and intends that they continue in their present roles of recommending the distribution of assistance to local government. Contrary to the recommendations of the national inquiry, the Government does not propose to make grants for local government conditional upon States maintaining their assistance to local government. Nor will the Government seek to interfere with State policies which limit rate increases. Should the Commonwealth act in these areas, it would only serve to penalise the local governments concerned for decisions in which they had no part. Maintenance of State assistance, however, will be one of the matters subject to future review. The principles under which the funds are to be distributed will be formulated by the States in consultation with local government and will be approved by me as the Commonwealth Minister responsible for Local Government.

It is the Government's intention to seek a greater uniformity among the States as to how the funds are distributed, while at the same time recognising that there are real differences in State local government systems which must be provided for by a flexible approach. It is recognised that in order to achieve a greater equity in the distribution of financial assistance some better off councils may receive less than under previous arrangements, while relatively disadvantaged councils will receive more. I share the concerns expressed by both the States and local government that any changes to be implemented should be gradual-I stress the word `gradual'-and not unduly disruptive to individual councils and the local government system generally. Consequently, it is proposed that any significant changes be phased in over a five-year period. The phasing arrangements and other details will be announced when the new legislation is introduced into Parliament later in this session.

I believe that the proposals that have been outlined today represent this Government's ongoing commitment to the strengthening of the local government system. They will lay the foundations for a more stable, efficient and equitable system of financing local government than operated under the previous personal income tax sharing arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Financing to local government became a matter of course when the Fraser Government introduced it in 1976 and the present Government's move for an inquiry by Professor Self into the proposition was well received by the Opposition, as there was no doubt over a period that certain changes were worth looking at. However, I am bound to say that the development of local government in recent years, which really caused the Federal Government to look at the question of funding, has been brought about by the imbalance in some areas between new areas of heavy capital commitment and some inability to raise the sort of rate levels necessary to fund the capital projects. This was noted and an arrangement was entered into to make certain contributions to local government. As time has gone by, it has become a practice in some local government areas to take up services which were normally the domain of State governments and, in some areas, of the Federal Government, and at the same time not to charge the appropriate level of fee for those services or, in some cases, not to raise the level of rates that would be most appropriate to the council concerned because the amount involved coming from the Federal Government was taken as the balancing figure rather than the overall amount.

SPEECH.PARA: The Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance addressed these matters and, in the main, I believe it did an excellent job. Certainly the background material and the presentation of it show the very wide interest there is these days in local government and its power within local communities. In the main, the Opposition welcomes the Government's response, but there are some notable problems coming from it. First, I think it is fair to say that the approach to funding has been more on the basis of seeking to salute what money might be available, rather than the principle of the Self inquiry itself. As a consequence, while funding is guaranteed on a real consumer price index basis, any extra amount of money will be wholly dependent on the performance of the State Premiers at the Premiers Conference, and whether they get the CPI plus 2 per cent, which is the current negotiated position with the States and the Federal Government.

The Federal Government has been making a lot of sound about cutting out the 2 per cent. I have heard comments expressed privately by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the effect: The Labor State governments have been re-elected, the Tasmanian State elections are over and there is only the Queensland one to come, so why should the Government worry about the 2 per cent? Anyone in local government who is sitting outside waiting to pick up the CPI indexed element of the reduced base figure plus 2 per cent should not hold his breath, because the writing is on the wall that that is going down the drain. By saying here that the amount is dependent on the performance of the Premiers, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has indicated that the Government is saying: `Oh, well, we tried, but blame it on the Premiers'. That is how the Minister has walked away from that one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not. We are following the Self inquiry's report which recommended that we should get the same as the State governments.

—Well, the Minister lost the first one. In relation to the other elements, element A of the proposed contribution has been endorsed. This is a total filling on a per capita basis. Element B of the grant extends to an equalisation factor. Some of the local government associations regard the application of element A in this fashion as nothing more than a crowding out of the effect on element B. That is the view of the Queensland Local Government Association. Without any doubt, there are some areas of local government which need more assistance than others, but the criteria of judgment of what areas are most disadvantaged will definitely vary from State to State. The elements within the north are different from elements within city councils. There is substantial infrastructure in the city areas; but, because of the socio-economic factors which apply in certain of these areas, the demands for money there are critically different from those that are necessary in a developing area or a rural area. Element B, when judged by the State grants commissions, will be something which I hope the Minister will bear in mind when he looks at the guidelines. I hope he will consider the differences there because they have a unique effect.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also noticeable that the Minister paid a fair amount of attention to his success in negotiating with the Northern Territory on the position of Aboriginal councils. I wonder why he did not mention the States. There has been no mention of what he intends to do about the substantial areas of Aboriginal councils in Queensland and in the north of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—Yes, as the honourable member for Maranoa would know; hence his concern in that area.
—It's only what the Northern Territory Government is doing, not what I am doing.

—There is no reference in the Minister's statement to what the States are doing. There are Aboriginal councils in those two States. It is interesting, and it will be more so in the future, to see exactly under what criteria the State grants commissions will be required to make decisions under element B. There is no mention of it in this statement. It is critical to all councils that something be done and that they know where they stand.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no attempt to deal with the question of rate pegging which is used by State governments to enforce upon certain shires and councils limitations on their ability to raise funds. At the same time as the State governments are saying to councils: `You must now carry out these services' the States are saying: `You must not raise your rates above a certain level'. The first on the phone to the Minister in relation to this item of the Self Committee report was none other than his friends in the New South Wales Government which practises this to an art form-starve the councils, send them to Canberra and let Canberra give money to the councils to provide more services than the State Government does. The Minister's own State machine is one of the greatest offenders in this area.

The Minister has also totally failed to address in this statement the question of what we do about rate exemptions in which there are millions of dollars of rates tied up. The Government has glossed that one over because it did not want to offend all its mates in the States. This Government would not require them to pay rates to local government. No, this Government would not do that. The State governments say: `What about the Federal Government'? Uncle Tom says: `No, we will not do that either. We will just not mention it; it is well written up in the Self Committee report; we will let that one go past so we won't bother too many people'.

I also wonder at this great term `to seek to enforce uniformity among the States in relation to funds'. This is another classic backoff that the Minister has involved himself in. The Self Committee quite clearly says in that report that a genuine effort should be made to enforce a standard procedure or a standard distribution. What has the Minister done? He says he is going to seek that. He does not say what `seek' means or how it might be sought. He has played with words and has backed away from the problem. Why? Because all the Labor local government Ministers have said: `Look here, this is not your concern'. They play with words on matters like the giving to them of constitutional recognition. They say: We will promise to do that in government; you will not, you have backed off again in this area'.

It is no wonder that those people in local government look in hope to the continuation of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. It is the only hope that people in local government in Australia have to stand themselves apart from the State governments which stand over them, which direct that they provide services, which peg their rates, which dismiss councils on occasions totally without reason, and which at the same time do not put their hands in their pockets but expect the Feds to pick up some of the differences in the funding of these operations. This Minister is about to recommend the dissolution of the Advisory Council. Therefore the last vestige of independence, the hope of local government, at which they can sit with their peers, with the Ministers for local government and the Federal Minister, and get some protection will disappear. But the Minister is going to walk away from that too because he has been told by the local State machines `We cannot have any of this interference. We must at all times look after the constitutional position of the local government associations in the States because that is the place where the powers are'-some very good deals in local government have been done in the Sydney area; some of those State Ministers would not like to do without that ability to handle those matters-`and because of that we will not go near those sorts of areas'.

The response to the report is piecemeal, halfway and has touched the areas that are easy to handle. Anything that has been difficult has been pushed to one side, and we now await the Act to see whether any of the elements that have been missed in this response will be taken up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should:
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr N.A. Brown,Mr Connolly,Mr Reith and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Lloyd,Mr McArthur and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Leo McLeay and Mr O'Neil.

PETITION.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to airship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government of Australia to intercede with the Government of Sri Lanka:
to desist from airship attacks and seek a military solution;
to offer refuge, under humanitarian and compassionate programmes, to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation to any Tamils who have sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
as a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Grace,Mr Price and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Teaching of Community Languages in Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are dissatisfied with the present Federal Government's policy on Community Languages.

And request that the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a policy for the teaching of Community Languages, on a permanent basis, in the day schools, in order to safeguard the linguistic and cultural heritage of all Australians.

Moreover, with the present petition, we request the Community Languages Resources Centres be instituted, to operate within communities, in order to assist schools in the implementation of Community Languages programmes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of certain electors of the Division of Gwydir respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
The parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hunt and Mr Nehl.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully sheweth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses:

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not `windfall gains', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the Flags Amendment Bill, 1984, as presented to the Senate and passed, which ensures that the Australian Flag cannot be changed except by referenda, be brought before the House of Representatives.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
Will ensure that the Flag Amendment Bill, 1984, will be presented to the House of Representatives at the earliest possible time and your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the May expenditure savings which introduced funding cuts to children's services will cause hardship to many low and middle income earners. Families relying on these vital services will suffer, as will workers within the industry. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in `Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any form of compulsory Identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of Identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory Identity cards.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned concerned Australian citizens respectfully point out:
That we recognize the Commonwealth Government's genuine concern and respect for United Nation's initiatives and policies.
We, your petitioners, humbly pray that your Honourable House will take notice:
1. That the U.N. Food and Agricultural Organisation has stated that ``All seeds and other plant breeding material is the heritage of all mankind, and should be freely available to all''.

2. That by the granting of Plant Variety Rights and Patents thousands of plant varieties and plant genetic diversity have been lost forever and many countries now regret having legislated for such patents and rights.
3. That we reject the principle that P.V.R. Legislation is either just, necessary or desirable for Australia.
4. That you will remember the U.N. statement as outlined above and reject any moves to have P.V.R. Legislation enacted by your government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that
in this International Year of Peace 1986, the world needs a nuclear test moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
And, to the Australian Government.

This petition of certain concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that, a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
Inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government (a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Arid Lands Botanic Garden, Port Augusta
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That there is strong support for the establishment of Australia's first Arid Lands Botanic Garden on a site at Port Augusta. Such a garden will be the only facility of its type in Australia and one of only a few in the world. Australia is largely arid and South Australia is the driest state. The development of the Port Augusta Arid Lands Botanic Garden has been recommended in ``A Report on the Collection of Native Plants in Australian Botanic Gardens and Arboreta'' compiled by the Royal Australian Institute of Parks and Recreation in October 1984, a copy of which was forwarded to the Prime Minister. Benefits of the garden would include:
1. Centre for research and study of all aspects of arid land flora.
2. Provision of appropriate extension and advisory service to pastoralists, councils, settlements, mining companies and individuals in arid areas of Australia.
3. Display both native and exotic plant material.
4. Valuable educational resource at all levels.
5. Significant tourism potential.
6. Creation of employment.
7. Ideal site available at Port Augusta which is the centre for a vast area of arid Australia, and readily accessible.
8. Ideal centre for production of seed of arid land plants on a commercial basis for local and overseas markets.
9. Display of plants used by Aboriginal people in arid Australia.
10. Ideal development in which to display and demonstrate technology appropriate to arid Australia e.g. solar power, desalination, appropriate building design, etc.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will take all possible measures to ensure that Australia's first ``Arid Lands Botanic Garden'' is established at Port Augusta as an urgent priority. We ask that all possible avenues of funding be investigated as this project will be a very important first for Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: The Petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia being residents of South Australia respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully seek a delay in the new funding arrangements planned for April this year for Subsidised Child Care Centres in Australia; and express total opposition to the cuts in child care which are beginning to have a deleterious effect on children's services in South Australia.
Your Petitioners therefore pray and urge the instigation of:
1. Urgent discussions with State Governments, peak bodies representing children's services, and the A.C.T.U.
2. That such discussions ensure that funding mechanisms are fully explored and ensure more appropriate funding guidelines.
3. That such discussion examine regulations for the quality assurance of children's services.
4. That such discussions be mindful of the need to retain high quality children's services and trained personnel to work in children's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney,Mr O'Neil and Mr Young.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the house to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free,Mr Grace and Mr Price.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system of Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Forces, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal the Bill of rights legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of Dawson respectfully shows that the proposed capital gains tax
- Penalises small business and farming enterprises,
- discourages long-term investment,
- hinders capital formation,
- will freeze existing investment patterns, and
- limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Parkes in New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the Total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade unions.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the right to work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade unions.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights
overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education, and private property,
is a basis for massive intrusion into State responsibilities,
establishes a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with powers similar to a court but without accepted legal procedures and protections for the accused, and
provides no avenue of appeal against decisions of the HR&EOC.

The petition further shows that fundamental protection of human rights is already to be found in the courts, in tolerance, in fair play, belief in democratic institutions, and in support for rule of law.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament will not allow the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to pass into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Mallee electorate respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: This petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws the attention of the House to the fact that amendments to the Child Care Act, by reducing operational funding to centres, threaten to destroy the existing high standard of child care.

Your petitioners therefore request that there be no changes to current funding arrangements until a full and proper review of the Children's Services Program takes place, which includes full community consultation and tripartite discussions between three levels of Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Land Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

The total disallowance by the Hawke Labor Government of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian business and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire and New South Wales respectfully showeth: That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Superannuation Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain members of the Nerang and Districts Business Community being both citizens of Australia and electors of the Division of McPherson respectfully showeth:

1. Whereas the Federal Labor Government by a decision of its Cabinet after consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions has indicated to the Australian public its intention to bring before this Honourable House a Bill for an Act for the introduction of a National Superannuation Scheme.

2. And whereas certain members of the said Nerang and Districts Business Community are desirous of expressing to this Honourable House their objection to and disapproval of the concept of a National Superannuation Scheme in the form of that proposed to be introduced by Bill by the Federal Labor Government to this Honourable House for its consideration.
3. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

(1) The Federal Labor Party in government will carry out a thorough review of the terms of any proposed Bill for an Act to introduce a National Superannuation Scheme and in the course of any such review consult with and have regard to the seriously formed opinions and concerns of the members of the Australian small business community and of representatives of employer groups with respect to the practicability and viability of a National Superannuation Scheme in so far as it relates to the future of Australia and Australian citizens.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:
Your petitioners pray that your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve;

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practice many of the principles that they have covenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in a centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for positive and constructive actions to overcome the economic and social crisis facing rural Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this matter of public importance has been the main thrust of the demands of thousands and thousands of people around Australia who have attended rallies. Last July 40,000 people attended a rally in Canberra. Hundreds of people have also attended a rally here in Canberra in the last two or three days.
—Four thousand at Wagga.

—Four thousand attended a rally at Wagga, and they were mostly women. These people want a fair go. They want the Government to take positive and constructive actions to overcome the economic and social crisis facing rural Australians. Not only the farmers and the farming families but also business people, the wives and children of people living in country towns and the work force in our rural centres, which is subject to the ever growing threat of unemployment, are facing a crisis. Let those people in the Australian Labor Party who are undertaking political analyses understand that it will not be just the farmers who will judge them at the next election. It will be the people generally-whether they are on farms or living in towns, working on farms or in factories, shops, service stations or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has failed rural Australia. In spite of the drought breaking rains in 1983, in spite of the fact that the economy of the United States of America staged a major recovery and in spite of the fact that the wage pause that was instituted by the Fraser Government gave a breathing space for inflation in this country, we have seen nothing but a deterioration of the economy in rural Australia. We have had three good seasons to enhance rural production. It is an outrage that the Hawke Government has embarked on a systematic program of slashing Budget outlays for farmers and, worse still, diverting resources from the sector by other more indirect and insidious methods. Despite its multi-billion dollar ripoff from the farmers, it now appears that the long awaited statement next Tuesday will return only about $200m.

Today net farm incomes have crashed, with the individual farmers earning one fifth of the average wage and paying interest bills double their income. A new major drought situation is now threatening to exacerbate the situation. Every Australian has a stake in the welfare of the farm industries, which provide about 40 per cent of Australia's export income. It does not matter whether people live at Bourke, Boulia, Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Perth or Adelaide. Every Australian, every trade unionist, has a stake in the welfare of rural Australia and our ability to be able to maintain our markets. Every Australian should know what the Hawke Government has done to our farmers. Every Australian needs to know what will happen to him personally if we have a wholesale national smash in agriculture. If this agricultural smash occurs, which I believe is almost inevitable if another drought plagues Australia, we can hold this Government as a principal culprit.

Listen to what the Government has ripped off the farm sector in its Budgets since 1983. The Hawke Government set out systematically to discriminate by cutting depreciation allowances, failing to renew the investment allowance, abolishing the in-out provisions of tax averaging, increasing export inspection charges by 200 per cent, freezing the diesel rebate for 18 months costing farmers $50m, gutting the income equalisation deposits scheme, imposing sales tax on wine, all but abolishing the petroleum products freight subsidy, imposing sales taxes on oils and lubricants used on farm and cutting outlays for rural and debt adjustment, to name just a few. Never forget that the cost to the farmers was $442m. This is an accumulated cost about which the Government should be ashamed. The cost of its additional measures to country Australians in general was $648m.

These anti-farmer measures are small fry against the deliberate manipulation of the money supply, increasing interest rates to record levels and giving the exchange rate a blatantly dirty float. In the past 12 months Labor policies have added to the farm bill to the tune of $750m in extra interest payments, $500m in extra costs from devaluation and $75m in extra fuel costs, despite handing back the full distillate off-road rebate. The future looks even bleaker with the prospect of the anti-farm tax package due to come into the Parliament within a month. Individual farm industries have been treated with contempt. This Government has tried to bludgeon the Queensland Government into a sugar industry price support scheme when no contribution was expected from any other State government for the steel or the multinational motor vehicle industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never been done before.

—Exactly. The Queensland Government has put up nearly $200m in loans and other assistance to the sugar industry, including $50m cash up front. Yet we are waiting to hear whether the Government will underwrite the price of sugar as it promised prior to the last two elections.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has led the dairy industry up the path. Prior to the last Victorian election, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) supported the general thrust of an industry plan to stabilise dairy production. Yet, after the election, the Government back tracked and attempted to introduce its plan, which would have had brutal social consequences on those people associated with the industry. Although negotiations have taken place, there has been no public statement from the Minister to give some security and stability to this industry. Yet, the Australian Dairy Corporation has advised that the industry is facing a desperate situation on world markets. The Hawke Government has not hesitated to subsidise our Big Australian, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the multinational car manufacturers and the major banks as a matter of urgency. But when it has come to farmers it has played a game with the same cruel intent as a cat plays with a mouse.

The Government's interest rate policy is probably the worst feature of Labor's record. It is Labor's worst blow to farmers. When speaking on interest rates at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference this year, the Westpac General Manager for New South Wales, Mr Chatterton, gave the following answer:
Undoubtedly the Prices and Incomes Accord must shoulder much of the blame.

Interest rates have fallen overseas but the farm rates in Australia have leapt 7 per cent in 12 months. It is crippling not only the farmers but also the small businesses. The small businesses in the front line of attack are in our country towns. Last year, when world interest rates were falling, the Government's reaction to the dollar's collapse was to push up interest rates to a record level, although not for home buyers in the western suburbs of Sydney or in the sand belt of Melbourne. While interest rates were falling, to 9 per cent in the United States of America, 7.5 per cent in West Germany and 4.5 per cent in Japan, farmers copped a 7 per cent increase on their record debt-an average increased interest bill per farmer of $4,425 in 12 months. Their average net income this year will be $3,800, and that gives some idea of the extent of the damage that has been done to the farm sector.

Labor's impact on the farm does not stop at interest rates or sky-rocketing debt. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics Director, Dr Andy Stoeckel, warned the closing session of this year's Outlook Conference:

Macroeconomic policies can . . . affect the exchange rate, inflation and interest rates, which have a direct bearing on both the total availability of resources to the export sector and the efficiency with which those resources can be used.
