The dirty float has resulted in a 2 per cent increase in export returns. I have heard it said so often that the farmers are lucky because of the devaluation, and nothing could be further from the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two per cent.

—There was a 2 per cent increase in returns, while farm imports rose by 25 per cent. The inflation rate of this nation is running at double the average of our main trading competitors. In the space of 12 months, we have slipped from being the country with the fourth lowest inflation rate to the country with the second highest rate of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member countries. Labor's policies have disadvantaged farmers at all levels of policy making. The Government has attempted to misrepresent its record on farm cost increases. Farm costs have risen 30 points, from 123 to 153, in three years while prices received have risen only seven points in that time. Never let this Government try to defend its record by saying that relative farm costs are down and by trying to make out that costs are better now than they were when we were in government. The truth of the matter is that at that time our level of inflation was at the low end of the OECD scale and now it is at the high end. The truth of the matter is that our costs are far worse than those of our competitors.

SPEECH.PARA: Next Tuesday's statement will be worthless if it fails to change the policy directions by fundamentally reversing the devastating impact of monetary, exchange rate, interest rate and wage rate policies. The Parliament needs to know from the Minister right now whether an attack on farm input costs is central to the Government's primary industry policy strategy. Once again, I recommend to the Government the constructive 14-point plan which I tabled in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good plan.

—I thank the honourable member. With regard to fuel, the full benefits of falling world oil prices should be passed on to all consumers, while fuel excise indexation must be abandoned, sales taxes on lubricants used on-farm removed and a more equitable freight equalisation scheme restored.
—Real assistance, not band-aids.
—I thank the honourable member for Barker. He is so right.
—A smart little medical fellow, too.

—He was right on the medical issues too. In particular let us scrap the capital gains tax, the farm loss quarantine provisions and the fringe benefits tax. Can any honourable member think of more idiotic, more discriminating, more selective or more destructive tax than the quarantining of farm losses, which will lock people into their debt situation, giving them no hope of selling their farms? Throughout New South Wales and elsewhere the market has been brought to a standstill because people outside the farm sector will not bother buying under those sorts of discriminatory arrangements.
—Next you will want them on the stock exchange in Pitt Street.

—The honourable member should think about the stock exchange and the rackets that have gone on-money being borrowed overseas, and so on. The 3 per cent productivity superannuation deal must go. Wages policy must be freed up, the dollar given a clean float and the economic strategy changed so that interest rates can drop from their record heights. The farm situation is so serious that substantial extra funds must be allocated for debt adjustment carry-on purposes and farm reconstruction. There must be steady, predictable cuts to tariff protection with those tariffs on farm machinery, chemicals and parts replaced by bounties. Taxation initiatives could include restoration of a more equitable income equalisation deposits scheme and the abolition of export inspection charges to producers. There are actions which would substantially reduce farm costs at a time when average real rates of return to capital are expected to be minus 6 per cent. There is little we can do in the immediate future to overcome the international scene, but there is a lot this Government can do to overcome the domestic price structure of the Australian farm sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I support the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee to examine and report on actions necessary to address the problems facing farmers in rural communities. However, it should not be used as a device to protect the Hawke Government from taking urgent actions to change its overall policies which are discriminating against rural Australia and bringing so much misery and suffering to hundreds and thousands of men, women and children, many of whom are spending their last cents to come down here and to go elsewhere to protest. It is an outrage. The Government needs to face up to it.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The alleged matter of public importance proposed today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for positive and constructive actions to overcome the economic and social crisis facing rural Australia.

I am quite happy to stand by that statement. I do not disagree with it. We have been doing just that and next Tuesday night we will continue to do exactly that, taking positive and constructive actions. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), means very well, but it is pretty obvious from many of his comments that he simply does not understand what is happening. I welcome very much what he had to say. I am very pleased that the honourable member has finally acknowledged on behalf of his Party, the National Party, the whole of rural provincial Australia. I believe that it would be a great achievement if the National Party could stick with that, because it has always approached the rural sector-that is, rural provincial Australia; the four million people living outside the major metropolitan areas-purely and simply in terms of agricultural policy. The assumption has always been that, if enough money is poured in and if one just listens to the agro-political leaders, problems such as rural poverty and rural unemployment will be solved. So I welcome what the honourable member said in that regard. The wording of the matter of public importance was pretty soppy. It was unspecific. It gave him a chance to repeat the National Party's 14-point plan. I think it was the 14-point plan of 14 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the latest?

—I think that is the latest plan. No, an 18-point plan was released on 28 February. That is all right. That is what oppositions are for. They must bring up their policies. It would be marvellous if they did. Let us have a look at the rural policy of the Liberal Party. Goodness, gracious me, I think it has five items. The Federal Liberal Party has never taken rural or agricultural policy seriously. Let us look at the National Party rural policy. The honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), when he was Opposition shadow spokesman on agriculture before the last election, to his great credit, came up with a policy. I think that is the first time that the National Party seriously applied itself to actually putting something down on paper. The Liberal Party has never done that. The Opposition is trying to capitalise on the presence of the friendly hordes outside. There is no way that I, along with the honourable member for Gwydir and many other members of this House, do not understand the problems, feelings and attitudes of those people in farm Australia, in rural provincial Australia today, because many of us have gone through it. He is trying to capitalise on that, trying to get a few Brownie points before next Tuesday, but it is rather transparent and not very convincing. If honourable members go out in the bush today they will quickly get some idea of the disregard and disrespect in which the National Party is held by many of the people. When times are tough people generally try to face reality. I think that the more people demonstrate, the more they come in contact with what is happening and with people in Government, who then get a better understanding of the problems. That is why I am heartened by some of the people who are coming forward. They have thought long and deeply about those matters, and I welcome some of the ideas put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Although I think a lot of people are very confused, one thing that is clear to me is that they are not concerned about attacking just this Government, they are concerned about attacking all governments, because they see the problem as having started quite some time before the Hawke Government came into office in 1983, and, of course, some of these demonstrations are effective. In other revolutions the peasants used to hang the aristocrats; now they sing songs to us. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) is becoming very switched on by some of the songs being sung outside his window. We ought to look at this matter very seriously because many processes have led to the situation with which we are faced today and they have been happening over a long period. The fundamental changes occurred at the end of the 1960s and in the early 1970s when the monetary agreements broke down. The speculation in currencies and commodities then became very pronounced. Through the 1970s we had two oil shocks. People sought to purchase land as a shelter and the price of land for agriculture in Australia went up by as much as seven times during that period. World trade in agricultural commodity prices peaked in 1979-80. That was a time when land prices were still rising and inflation was on the up and up, partially because of the oil price shock at the time, and prices were reasonably high.

The farmers were confronted with the 1982-83 drought after they had invested very heavily and there had been a fair amount of adjustment in the early 1980s. At that time some parts of the continent had faced up to four years of drought, but 1982-83 was certainly the drought year for the Australian continent. It took the previous Government about two years to react to that drought. As a result of the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, I hope that some of the ad hockery of the conservative parties is at an end and that they too have faced the reality of the situation and will not go for band aids, but will try to put forward policies in an overall setting, as the Government has been doing. The ad hockery of the past was rather staggering. I go back to the wheat problems of the late 1960s and the quotas the coalition parties put on, to the fact that they stood around dumbstruck by the wool industry crisis in the early 1970s, to the fact that they actually did nothing about the dairy industry, other than the continuous silly subsidy, when Britain entered the European Economic Community. When the Whitlam Government went out of office in 1975 the National Party and the Liberal Party were very big on promises about what they were going to do for the beef industry because it was in a critical situation. The beef herd went down from approximately 34 or 36 million to about 22 million in a short space of years. The coalition parties were going to do marvellous things, and it was not until good old Malcolm wanted an early election in 1977 that they cooked up the beef incentive payment scheme. In relation to the drought, they really stood around like stunned mullets for two years.

The honourable member for Gwydir said that we have been slashing the Budget, slashing the amount of money going to the primary industries. The figures simply do not stand up. There have been additional expenses in some areas, but there have been many other areas where there have been a lot of offsets. We heard the same old litany about some of those cuts, regardless of the general principles involved. I can go back to the Razor Gang for another tired old litany of where the cuts were and all that nonsense. The former Government savaged the wheat industry and the Wool Corporation. It tried to wipe out the Australian Wool Testing Authority, and it even thought that locusts could not fly across State borders. Peter Nixon was on the Razor Gang. The former Government was going to set up a soil conservation program in 1978. Poor old Kevin Newman was in this House promising all those things, and then his Party let him down rather badly.

Of course, one of the more important offsets has been the devaluation, which is still calculated to have given a gain to the farm sector of about $1.4 billion. The decision we took in the last Budget regarding import parity pricing in a full year is worth about $270m for a distillate. There are many other offsets. If I can address some of the points made by the honourable member for Gwydir, in relation to a drought, of course we are all very concerned about that. I am happy to inform the House that we believe we will have sufficient information over the next week or two to provide a decent sort of analysis as to whether or not we have on our hands some part of what is now known as the El Nino phenomenon. The 1982-83 drought was the worst in this century. With the El Nino phenomenon, people are now looking back through the statistics and studying surface temperatures, erosions, what is happening in Peru and other such matters. They are saying that there is this effect every four to six years. Given the intensity of the drought in 1982-83, statistically it is highly unlikely that we are heading into a drought anywhere near the severity of that one.

I believe that all political parties are in a difficult situation with the farm sector. There is an enormous amount of fundamentalism out there and a lot of wrong thinking. The fact that the farmers are just as disenchanted with the National Party and the Liberal Party is evidence of that, and there is evidence that we should put in place in this House policies that go beyond just immediate reaction. That is what this Government has been trying to do. There is plenty of evidence for this because there is a lot of talk about a new political party. I often think that the Government is not going too badly. We have some evidence of a Green Party, some of the disaffected are out on the Left, and out on the Right we have the Katharine Wests and John Leards and Des Keegans of the world trying to whip up a new party. We are right in the middle.

If honourable members look at the rhetoric of the Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Howard), it seems to be all 1950s Democratic Labor Party stuff. The National Party does not even believe in democracy in Queensland. I can understand why the farmers are pretty disenchanted with the conservative parties. As an example I take the wages policy. The state of the Opposition is such that, if it ever came up with a wages policy, no one really thinks the Leader of the Opposition will make it stick. Either the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) or someone else will break loose and the whole thing will fall down in a heap again. That is the great problem. What the Liberal Party really cannot handle is the fact that the accord is working and that it is doing something for employment, profitability and investment in this country. The Liberal Party cannot handle the fact that the devaluation is effective because of the accord. It does not want the people of Australia to remember that under its system there was a $39 a week wage blow-out for the metal trades in 1981-82, and that is when a move was made away from centralised wage fixation. I will not go back to the Transport Workers Union case, but that is what happened.

What has happened under this Government? The cost of wages, the real unit labour cost on an annual basis, is down by 7 per cent, or down by 11 per cent when comparing the peaks of 1982-83 with the current situation. Industrial disruption is the lowest it has been for 16 years and, instead of unemployment going up as was the case under the Leader of the Opposition and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), we now have 608,000 new people in employment, and the figures released today by the Prime Minister are even better. The accord is working and the Opposition cannot handle it. We have in place a very viable growth pattern in this economy. In the long run it will benefit all industry and all investment in this country, because one cannot run an economy unless one gets all the people in the economy back to work. That is what we are doing.

We heard all of the nonsense about the dirty float. The Deputy Leader of the National Party repeated the same tired old propaganda of the LGPA-the Livestock and Grain Producers Association-in New South Wales. What people and what the LGPA forget, of course, is that we should not look at the United States of America and Australian dollar rate that is fixed every day. For each commodity one ought to look at its effect from a trade weighted basis. So we have had a depreciation of about 30 per cent for the wool industry in terms of the basket of currencies faced by exports of that commodity. Even in the area of wool, in which we are a price maker, the rise in wool prices has been very low-about 2 per cent. That was pretty unexpected. But we are not running a dirty float. The Reserve Bank of Australia has been indulging in some operations because of the overshoot. But people must understand why interest rates drop when the exchange rate moves up a bit. They drop because there is an indication that the fundamentals are right. One could easily have much lower interest rates and have masses of imports, pushing up the prices of these imports, which are farm inputs. What would happen down the track? There would be another burst of inflation and one would lose one's international competitiveness. That is a nonsensical approach. It is true that the policy is hard to swallow. It must be tough, but it is responsible. Above all, this Government is responsible because we are taking steps that are putting in place the grounds for this economy to move onwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In March 1983 the bruised and somewhat beaten Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) panted up to the Press gallery and said that a drover's dog could have won the election. Mr Deputy Speaker, the drover's dog who won that election is currently having a great deal of difficulty in giving the flock for which he is responsible any direction at all. Australia is seeing no shepherding from this drover's dog. In fact, if the direction that the Australian rural industry is currently taking, continues, the drover's dog will have no flock left to shepherd. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) is to be congratulated for focusing the attention of the nation on what is a major problem, as he rightly says, facing every Australian. All we have heard from the Government is some sort of half-hearted concession that there is some sort of problem. We have had little more than a half-hearted concession, while the National Farmers Federation has been rightly critical of the Government's inaction. There has been little more than a half-hearted concession while the daily Press and television are full of the present rural demise and while the Livestock and Grain Producers Association has spent three days alerting the Government to the problems the farmers face.

SPEECH.PARA: During the grievance debate we had the astonishing spectacle of the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) talking about his cousin who, along with a majority of other Australian primary producers, happens to be facing some problems on the land. The honourable member for Lowe had the sheer effrontery and the audacity to say that the LGPA was engaging in `kindergarten antics'. He said that the demonstration currently occurring in Canberra was the silliest demonstration he had ever seen. Furthermore, he added that if these same demonstrators really had a problem they should be home on the farm. The farmers who are protesting in Canberra this week are not here because they can afford to be, but because they cannot afford not to be. The fact that they are here is a measure of their concern about the direction the nation is taking and the direction that agriculture is taking.

The honourable member for Lowe and all those who currently suffer from his urban mentality should come to grips with the fact that the present dilemma facing Australian farmers does not result from a lack of rain. They are facing a dilemma after what have been climatically good conditions. The farmers are not complaining about the weather-or at least, not yet. Their concern is not a meteorological one. Their concern is the cruel reality of the current economic climate. I stress that the farmers of Australia are not currently complaining because things are tough. Let me reiterate that point for the benefit of the few Government members who are here: Farmers are not complaining because it is tough. They are complaining because it is tough for them and not tough for the rest of Australia. They are complaining about the gross inequity of the present system which means that farmers carry the burden of Australia's economic mismanagement. The farmers of Australia do not even expect, as do the wage earners, an element of predictability. They are prepared because of their very lifestyle to tolerate unpredictability. What they cannot tolerate is the simple truth that they are currently the carriers of the bloated bureaucracy that this Government has inflated.

The farmers of Australia, as the honourable member for Gwydir eloquently said, are currently earning one-third of the average weekly earnings of most Australians. They do not have any sort of cost of living index, any sort of consumer price index adjusted weekly wage structure. Since 1980 they have faced a 40 per cent increase in farm costs and a 13 per cent increase in farm returns. That is what they faced to 1985. When the figures are issued for this year they will undoubtedly be much worse. As the honourable member for Gwydir rightly pointed out, this has a multiplier effect which is estimated to be to the tune of 14 to 1. So it is not only the farmers who are affected, but every member of the rural community. As recently as today's Australian there appeared an editorial which focused on the problems of costs in Australia, and which stated:
Each of these sombre documents provides further evidence that our products remain uncompetitive with those of our trading partners because our costs are pricing us out of international market-places.

Our costs are pricing us out. The farm dilemma affects not only the farmers but every member of the rural community. A feature page in the Australian ran an article on what is currently happening in Nyngan. Anthony Hoy reports that in Nyngan farm retailers are suffering a quandary almost as real as that facing the farmers. In the heart of my electorate, in an area where it always rains, there are farm retailers who are facing the simple reality that they have sold nothing in the way of tractors or four-wheel drive utilities, even though there is not a drought. They have sold nothing because the farmers cannot afford to buy anything and the farmers have no confidence in the capacity of this Government to solve their problems.

The Opposition's call in this matter of public importance is a call for constructive action. All we have had from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his comments on the matter of public importance was a promise that he will continue the action. What action? The farmers are in the streets because there has been no action. This matter of public importance calls for some commitment from this Government which will provide relief for our beleaguered farm industries. The Minister claimed in his response to the matter of public importance to understand the rural dilemma. But what illustration have we seen of this understanding being expressed in action? The Minister has the audacity to stand here and be critical of what he says is the Liberal Party's absence of policy and the National Party's absence of policy. Let me remind honourable members opposite, few as they are, that as recently as last Friday I sat in a hall with Mr McLachlan from the National Farmers Federation, at which time he commended the Opposition parties for the work that they were doing on policy development.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite may well scoff, but he did that at a public meeting and it is on public record. Furthermore, he commended the parties for having what will be one policy document, as they did before the last election, and not two documents, as has been mischievously alleged by the Minister for Primary Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister had the audacity to say that there was no such thing as a dirty float, although he did mention that the Reserve Bank of Australia had been `indulging in some operations because of the overshoot'. What are we playing? Is it archery? There is a dirty float, and it is in place solely because of the cosy arrangement between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That dirty float is forcing up interest rates, as the honourable member for Gwydir has said, estimated by the NFF to cost the average farmer $3,500 a year. If it costs the average farmer $3,500 a year, in fact what is it costing those farmers who are most in debt? We are on our feet because this Government has been imprudent in its stewardship of the national economy. These have been good climatic years for Australia's farmers, but government borrowings are up. If we cannot reduce government expenditure in what have been good years, how on earth can we survive the difficult ones that might well be around the corner? The coalition Parties are committed to reducing government expenditure. Our record is one of reduced government expenditure. Our record is one of fewer people employed in the Public Service. That is the commitment that we give to the farmers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate. I note that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) was the first on his feet to support the discussion today of `the need for positive and constructive actions to overcome the economic and social crisis facing Australia'. The fact of the matter is that the Government agrees that there is a need to overcome these problems-and the Government is addressing the problems. I must say that I am absolutely astounded that the Opposition should raise this matter in the House today. It can only be some cheap politic-king because this week farmers are demonstrating around Canberra. There can be no other reason for Opposition members to so blatantly expose their weaknesses in the area of agriculture. Before I refer to the wide range of things that the Government is doing to address these issues, I want briefly to outline a little of the problems and to help honourable members opposite understand the reasons for some of the problems.
—Go slowly for them.

—`Go slowly' my honourable colleague says, and I agree. This is a very serious matter, Mr Deputy Speaker. The heart of the problem has been the failure of the previous Government to understand the problems of the rural sector and to come to grips with them. I am pleased to note here in the chamber today so many members of the Government's Primary and Provincial Affairs Committee, and also members who are appointed to the Prime Minister's special country task force, which is getting right down to talking with rural Australia and coming to grips with the problems that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard some discussion today about the need for policies, in particular the need for the Liberal Party to develop policies in this area. I note that in answer to a question without notice asked in the House yesterday the Minister for Primary Industry referred to the range of policies that are around at the moment from the other side of the House, from not only the Liberals and the Nationals but also outside organisations which have chosen to start voicing policies because of the absence of anything substantial coming from the other side. We now have 10-point plans, five-point plans, 17-point plans and 18-point plans. We have a range of groups which are purporting to speak for the Opposition on rural policies. What is the need for the development of this range of policies? It is because honourable members opposite do not have policies, they have not developed policies and there is now a need for them at least to have a face that they understand. I must say that that need was acknowledged as recently as 4 April by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in a speech to the Liberal Party Rural Seminar in Adelaide. I quote from the notes of his speech. He said to that gathering:
Never before has it been more important for both the Liberal and National Parties to understand and intelligently respond to the concerns of the people living in rural Australia.

I could not agree more. The Leader of the Opposition then went on to praise the National Farmers Federation and to point out that the NFF is out there doing the job. In relation to the NFF, the Leader of the Opposition said:

I welcome the higher profile and greater aggression which has been shown by the National Farmers Federation recently. I welcome it because the National Farmers Federation and its President, Ian McLachlan, have been clear and responsible in what they have been saying.

First, why would the Liberal Party feel so confident about the position of the NFF? I refer to the now infamous and incompetently leaked document. When talking about competency, I cannot help referring to the note on the front of the document, which states `carefully selected, the chance of a leak should be small'. It should be remembered that this document was written within the Liberal Party secretariat by a consultant on lease from the National Farmers Federation to the Liberal Party. In relation to the NFF, it states:
If you wish I can arrange for the support of the NFF and also that of its commodity councils and State member bodies.

That is a very interesting disclosure by the Liberals. Of course, that has deeply embarrassed the NFF. That statement led Mr McLachlan to say at the Liberal Party Rural Seminar held at Adelaide-and I am quoting again from a Press report of his speech:
The coalition had not formed policies to provide a suitable alternative.

He also said that `the coalition was not a credible alternative to the Government'. So, with that little piece of incompetence the Liberal Party has forced the NFF to say clearly that the coalition is not a credible alternative to the Government, and I could not agree more. So, the reason for there being such an emphasis on policy is that the coalition knows that it must develop an understanding. I also note comments made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt), who has led this debate today. He also exposed one of the aspects of the Opposition's approach to the problems that exist. There was rhetoric but not substance. In a speech at a meeting of farmers at the Biloela RSL Club on 4 April this year he said, in a nice little bit of juicing up to start his speech:
We have the world's most efficient farmers. We have more potential to produce agricultural products at competitive prices than most countries in the world.
No one has any argument with that, but having buttered everyone up with that sort of stuff, he then said:
Rural Australians in general have also copped severe cuts to funding programs such as roads, aerodromes and water resources.

Let us look specifically at those three areas that he mentioned. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) made it clear in the House just a couple of days ago that, since the present Government came to office, there has been an 85 per cent increase in government expenditure on roads, and that has occurred primarily in the rural and arterial roads sector. When we came to office an amount of $22m was allocated to country Australia for the water resources program. Under our Government this year some $38.3m has been allocated for rural water resources. Just this week in my own electorate we announced three more programs to improve water resources for country towns in central Victoria. Here is the substance of the argument: Members of the Opposition go out and talk rhetoric about things such as efficient farmers but then bucket the Australia Labor Party and the Labor Government with straight out lies. That is what the Opposition has been serving up. That is the sort of stuff that country Australia has come to realise it is not interested in hearing any longer.

Last Christmas the Federal Government was called on by the United States Government to boycott live sheep exports as part of the Libya deal. The Cabinet took the view that we could not isolate one particular sector of the economy, that we could not knock-off live sheep exports as part of a boycott. We agreed that live sheep exports were vital to small farmers. We expected to be supported by the Liberal and National parties on that. What did they do? They came out and criticised the Government. They engaged in cheap politicking at the expense of small farmers. That is why I am far more prepared to listen to the farmers, with whom I meet daily, to my colleagues on the rural task force and the rural and provincial affairs Caucus committee, who are out there meeting the farmers on a day to day basis, and to our Ministers at both a Federal and State level who are out there talking to farmers, than I am to listen to them.

The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) raved on about interest rates. An article on the front page of today's Australian Financial Review is headed `Rates fall to lowest level in six years'. Our farmers need high quality economic management. They need a government that is economically responsible and which will not just give them band-aids and sops of cheap rhetoric. That is the sort of government Australia has in power at the moment. That is the sort of government that will stay in power in Australia. That is the sort of government that rural Australia needs, and which it will continue to get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (PROPORTIONAL PORTABILITY OF PENSIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the first report for 1986 of the Committee relating to the construction of a new telephone exchange building for Telecom Australia at Dalley Street, Sydney. I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recommendations and conclusions of the Committee's report are as follows. The Committee accepts that there is a need for new generation equipment and services to meet the current and forecast needs of Telecom Australia in the northern sector of the Sydney central business district. The Committee agrees that it would be impractical and uneconomical to upgrade the existing telephone exchange building in Dalley Street. The construction of a new telephone exchange building is necessary. It should be built alongside the existing Dalley Street telephone exchange. The proposed three elevated cable bridges to link the new and existing telephone exchanges at second floor level will ensure compatibility of operation and cost savings by utilising the existing cable chamber. The design and construction of the proposed new telephone exchange building at Dalley Street appears satisfactory. The estimated cost of the proposed building is $13m at June 1985 prices. I might say that the project is well within the parameters of conventionally and, accordingly, the Committee recommends construction of the work in this reference. I thank the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for flocking into the chamber to hear my contribution as we resume debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. In my discussion of this Bill I intend to deal with its application in higher education institutions and its likely impact on employment opportunities for young women-both matters which are part of my shadow portfolio responsibilities of education and youth affairs. This Bill will have one positive effect. It will raise employers' and employees' consciousness about the position of women in the Australian work force. It will not cause a revolutionary transformation of the position of women in the work force, but it will remind everyone that a large and talented pool of women exists-women who are just as capable as, and in some cases more capable than, the male half of Australia's population at performing a diverse range of occupations diligently and professionally.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make my own position clear. If any society denies itself the creative energies and talents of 50 per cent of its population such a denial not only is morally indefensible in respect of the individuals; it is also socially unjust and plainly economically stupid. Under this legislation higher education institutions will be the first group of employers required to implement the equal employment opportunity program and to report progress under the Act. It is supremely ironic that this should be so, for it is in the higher education sector that the limitations of the Bill's effectiveness will be most clear. The internal labour markets of higher education institutions are amongst the most highly regulated sections of the labour force. The strictures of tenure and existing Federal Government constraints on the growth of the higher education sector have combined to create the worst of all possible worlds for high quality potential academics seeking employment within it.

In my comments on tenure I differ markedly from the contribution made earlier today in this debate by the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb). Fresh, young, vigorous and well-qualified scholars of both sexes currently are unable to obtain academic posts or are relegated to minor positions for extended periods because of the lengthy queue of tenured academics jamming up the system ahead of them. While many tenured academic of course are able and productive, there are some who provide a much poorer return to the students they teach and the institutions which employ them than might be provided by young scholars who are currently being shut out of our higher education institutions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you well know that tenured academics enjoy a clear cumulative advantage over non-tenured and unemployed academics. Having obtained tenure, they are in a position to maintain an exclusive grip on the upper echelons of the academic tree until retirement, with all its attendant benefits. Individual academics can, in some cases, occupy tenured positions for three or four decades if they are appointed sufficiently early in their careers. The downside of this cumulative advantage is felt most keenly by young scholars of both sexes. This Bill will assist talented young female scholars to get a fairer share of academic employment opportunity, in theory-I repeat, in theory. In practice, however, the virtually non-existent employment growth in the higher education sector, combined with the high proportion of lifetime tenured academics, will allow for only the most marginal advances for women in the near future. The new academic job opportunities which would need to be created if this Bill were to have a truly positive effect on the position of women in higher education are simply not in the pipeline and are not likely to be under the education policies of this Government.

As a result, statistics on the employment of women in the higher education community will continue to look very sick until well after the turn of the century unless the generation of tenured academics, overwhelmingly male, presently cemented into the system, relinquish its right to continuing employment until retirement age. Arguments for the dismantling of the tenure system seem to be generally regarded as reactionary and an attack on the continuance of academic freedom. Members of the higher education community who hold what is, in my view, that unfairly simplistic outlook, would do well to reconsider their position. In the case of equal employment opportunity, much more decisive advances could be made by pursuing the option of dismantling tenure than will be achieved by pursuing incremental improvements within the present arrangements. By spilling the system open in this way, by the removal or overturning of tenure, the representation of women in the academic ranks would be bound to improve as the talented amongst them replaced the dead wood of the present incumbents.

As to academic freedom, that could be equally well guaranteed under an employment system based on medium term contracts. Certainly, the higher education community would be more vigorous, more dynamic and genuinely based on merit if a better balance could be achieved within institutions between the need for institutional flexibility and the need for effective mechanisms to protect academic freedom. Ideally, new arrangements which would more effectively satisfy these goals should be worked out within the institutions themselves, by the academic community itself, rather than being imposed legislatively by governments. On this side of the House, we believe fervently in the sanctity of the higher education community's autonomy and independence. In government we will encourage institutions to develop and embrace more effectively progressive policies from within, rather than legislating for such change from above.

In summary, the Bill we are now debating addresses a matter which requires attention, namely, the need for a heightened awareness of the value and talents of half our population-the value and talents of Australian women. As such, we do not oppose the Bill. Despite the defects of the Government's approach to promoting equal employment opportunity, the reminder it will provide to the academic community in particular of the talents of its female scholars, many of whom are locked out of the current higher education system, and their worthiness of promotion compared with those who are currently in our institutions is very worth while indeed.

Before closing, I wish to comment briefly on the impact of the Bill on young women entering the work force for the first time. One of the prime reasons for the lower average earnings of women in the work force, compared with men, is what is known as occupational segregation. This is the concentration of women in a fairly narrow range of occupations and industries. There are encouraging signs and success stories of women breaking out of the occupational bounds of recent labour market history and entering a wide range of occupations in which traditionally they have not been employed. The present pattern of occupational segregation has developed because of a number of factors, not least of which is the activity of male dominated trade unions which have regulated access to many occupations and industries. There are a number of occupations in which one simply cannot be employed without a union ticket and union officials have been as guilty as anyone in cutting women off from the range of employment opportunities which should be open to them.

Let me be very clear about my own view and that of the Opposition: There should be no occupation from which any women would be excluded by virtue of her sex. It will be a measure of the Government's genuine resolve to establish equal employment opportunity in Australia if the unions are pushed as much as employers are being pushed to improve their employment policies. We on this side of the House will be vigilant in examining the position and comparing the Government's rhetoric with its actions. We will wish to ensure that the pressure being applied by the Government for change applies equally to both parties which are at present the major forces in the Australian labour market, namely, the employers and the unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to contribute to the debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, a very important piece of legislation. This Bill concerns equal employment opportunity for women-it is not legislation that promotes women; it is legislation that ensures that they can obtain promotion on the basis of merit. Essentially, it takes the form of a reporting system and, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his second reading speech in this House, it records yet another milestone in the Government's record of improving the status of women and is evidence of the Government's firm commitment to enhance women's job opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill requires certain employers to have an affirmative action program for women and to report their progress to the Government through the Director of Affirmative Action. The objects of the affirmative action program will be to eliminate discrimination against women and to promote equal employment opportunities for women. Initially it applies to universities and tertiary institutions and then to large employers with more than 1,000 employees and so on, year by year. A pilot system of affirmative action for women has been operating to promote recognition that women are not just people to be employed in the lower echelons, but that they have a right to a place on the boards of management and among the directors and in all the professions. My attention has been drawn to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 February 1986 which talks about `Hawke's blow for women'. The summation of the editorial writer is that this is at least a valuable first step. Women may feel that it is not going far enough but it is a valuable first step and is an action to eliminate discrimination and promote equal opportunity for women.

I do not wish to canvass any of the ground traversed already, but will try to introduce some new matter in relation to opportunities for girls and women. My researchers have turned up the 1984 figures for enrolments at universities, which are the latest figures available. Those figures show that the pattern in tertiary institutions in Australia is that girls and young women are not entering some professions, such as engineering. The total number of students studying engineering in 1984 was 14,406. Of that number, 13,330 were men. The situation is the same in architecture and agriculture. Regrettably, even in medicine there is a male domination-6,600 men to 4,800 women. In law there is also a slight bias in favour of males. When one looks at the fine arts, teaching and similar professions there is a heavy domination imbalance of women.

I have talked to principals of government and non-government secondary schools in my electorate. I have asked the principals of girls high schools why the girls go into teaching and not chemical or civil engineering, where they would be assured of employment. A bright girl should have access to any profession she wishes. I believe, from my conversations with principals and educational authorities, that it is not the fault of the schools. The girls are bright and they have access to the higher levels of mathematics. I have been told that one problem, particularly with ethnic families, is that there is no expectation that the girl will do anything other than something traditional, such as teaching or nursing. There are also peer pressures and there is a need for girls to have more confidence. In this regard I contacted the Catholic Education Office in Sydney, and the Director, Brother W. X. Simmons, made a submission to me. His summation is that the girls are competent, but need confidence. The acting head of the Burwood Girls High School said that some girls just need convincing that they have the ability to go into something such as engineering, law, medicine or dentistry. One principal told me she thought that the girls are hesitant and frightened to do something a little different because they do not want to stand out from the other girls.

Today the students from Concord High School in my electorate visited the Parliament. The students asked me what was happening in the Parliament, because they could not quite follow the debate before lunch. Concord High School is one of only two co-educational high schools in my electorate; the other 20 are single sex high schools. I said to the girls that because they are female they should not be excluded from any occupation. I told them that when I visit factories in my electorate and talk to the directors and management, I see no females; it is a totally male world. Women must be brought forward to have the opportunity to advance into managerial positions, into accountancy, engineering and all the other areas that are dominated by men. I said that to the students and they were very responsive. I feel that it is a matter of time, and that girls need more encouragement at the school level.

Brother Simmons, a Christian Brother of great experience, indicated in his submission that there should be more Government funding for female counsellors in Catholic regional or diocesan offices to assist schools enrolling female secondary students with information and advice on subject options, career paths and academic options. His point is that if we are to make an all out effort to get girls into jobs that have been traditionally the preserve of the males, there needs to be a bigger effort in counselling and career advice. This need not necessarily be in every school, but certainly in the State and non-government systems there need to be people who can advise teachers and career advisers on the facilities and opportunities which are available.

I want to touch on the matter of large companies in industry that will have to report on the composition of their work forces. They will have to reveal how many males and females are employed and their status. I have discussed this problem with the Minister for Education and Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan), because in my electorate I come upon women who are working in very menial jobs and have great trouble with English. The Minister has assured me that companies will be encouraged to teach English in the work place and employees will be encouraged to learn English and become fluent in it. The real problem arises when one is dealing with people who are not able to read or write in their own language, let alone English. I have taken the opportunity to talk to Mr Jules Weinhausen at the Adult Migrant Education Service in New South Wales, which is totally funded by the Commonwealth. Mr Weinhausen admits that if people are illiterate in Roman script and their own script, there are problems in teaching them English. Considerable funds need to be made available for language classes because such classes cannot have more than 10 students.

I have found, through constituency interviews in my electorate, that a number of people, often older women, cannot sign their own names. It is very sad and they are embarrassed, but I try not to embarrass them in any way. Through no fault of their own-because of such things as wars and poverty in the many countries from which they have come-they are illiterate. These people tell me that they wish they could read and write English, but teaching them to read and write is a problem if they are illiterate in their own language.

The Adult Migrant Education Service in New South Wales runs about 200 classes in which there are some 3,000 students. About 50 per cent of the people in that program are women. The classes held in industries are attended mainly by men, because the classes are held mainly at the State Rail Authority, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board. The only industry-based classes where women dominate are those in hospitals which run English language programs or in the hotel and catering industries, where there are a number of women in menial jobs who are encouraged to learn English. It appears to me that there must be a commitment to funding for the teaching of English, particularly to women who have had no opportunity to learn written English and who, I believe, will have an enriched life if they have the opportunity to learn it.

Several honourable members have mentioned the problems of child care. In my area I have extracted figures on the number of places available for long day care for the children of women who wish to work or have to work. Many women in Sydney go out to work because they have to. Homes are more expensive in Sydney than in the rest of Australia, and women have to work to meet the large mortgage repayments. There are only 370 child care places in the whole of my electorate for children of five and under. The 1981 census showed that there were 7,481 children in my electorate so about 5 per cent have the opportunity to enter a long day care centre There are some wonderful centres in all municipalities in Lowe, except the one in which I live, Drummoyne. There is no long day care facility in that municipality, yet some 30,000 people live there. I know that the Council and the Mayor are very concerned about this. Community centres have been moving to obtain long day care facilities. It highlights the situation in New South Wales. Sydney is historically short of long-day care centres, unlike Victoria and other States where child care was promoted in the 1950s and the 1960s, and more recently.

The lack of child care facilities is a very serious problems in my own electorate. There is a lack of before and after school child care facilities. The option has to be given to a women who wants to work. I see women who want to return to work, who must return to the work force because they need to pay their mortgage or they need to buy a home, but there are no long-day care facilities. I have made my views known to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). He is doing everything possible and I am expecting additional funding to create new facilities in my area. I will not delay the debate but I say again that I hope that this legislation, which is quite epoch-making, will encourage industry, education and all the areas which are training, employing, and giving women the opportunity to realise that they cannot be denied advancement and promotion, that industry is no longer a male preserve and that the professions are no longer a male preserve. I commend the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education for bringing this legislation forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure today to oppose the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. In doing so I point out to the House that I believe there are many more serious problems confronting our society today than affirmative action. We had today the matter of public importance dealing with the problems of farmers. Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, a National Party senator, has been in Wagga today addressing 4,000 concerned women from the farming community.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party of Australia supports the family unit. The family unit has been torn to shreds by this Government and by some of the legislation that has been put through this House in the last five to 10 years. We have only to look at the statistics and see the enormous costs that are imposed upon taxpayers today to see how that problem is propped up. The family is concerned about its financial plight and here we have the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) saying that all women in Sydney have to go out to work to support themselves and to buy themselves a house. Of course they have to do that, for the Government has just increased the interest rates by 2 1/2 per cent. Why would they not be out working? They are suffering the highest real interest rates that this nation has ever experienced. Australian women and men are suffering from these interest rates now. The honourable member for Lowe has the audacity to say that these poor women have to go out to work. Of course, some of them have to work. I do not believe they should be forced out of the home to work. They should be encouraged to stay at home and to look after their families. That is what the National Party is on about; we are on about supporting the family and giving women incentives to stay home to look after the family and to bring up young Australians as they ought to be brought up, not in some socialised, ratbag, Russianised-type childminding centre set up at the factory door. That is what the Government wants. The Government is giving tax incentives to factories to build childminding centres; yet it is not prepared to give any tax incentives to the mother who is at home looking after her family.

What is the Government going to do? It will flatten the tax rate on child endowment. It will reduce the amount of money paid for child endowment. It will reduce the encouragement given to women who are prepared to stay at home and look after their children. That is what the Australian Labor Party is on about. It will reduce the amount of money paid to families in this country. That is what honourable members opposite are on about. It is an absolutely disastrous policy. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. They should not be governing; they do not deserve to govern. What do we hear about the financial crisis? The Government talks about jobs. What jobs? We have seen the number of jobs in the Australian Taxation Office increase by 3,000 since the Government came to office. People are paying record interest rates to keep themselves in business.

Many speakers have spoken before me on this nonsense. I have never seen such a wank of a Bill in all my life. Why on earth do we need this sort of legislation? Why should women be encouraged to go into the work force? Fifty per cent of women in Australia are in the work force now, for God's sake. How many women do honourable members opposite want in the work force? What about the men these women are displacing who need a job as well? What about the unemployment figures? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has the audacity to tell this House that the unemployment rate is down. What a lot of nonsense! The real unemployment figure has gone up substantially since this Government has come to office. In 1981, 5.6 per cent of our work force was unemployed. The current rate is 8 per cent. The real rise in unemployment since you characters came to office is 2.4 per cent. The Prime Minister has the audacity to tell us that the employment figures are up. What absolute nonsense! There are 600,000 Australians unemployed. Thirty-three per cent of those people are aged between 15 and 24 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member that he is discussing a Bill which relates to affirmative action. I ask him to return to the subject of the Bill.

—The unemployment figures are very much tied in with the affirmative action Bill because what the Bill does is fine companies for not employing women. I put it to the House: When we have such a high unemployment rate, particularly among young people, why should women be forced into the work force when their own children are home without a job? That is the problem we have in Australia today. That is the social problem we have and the Government will not fix it by forcing more women into the work force and by compelling employers to take more women on, and by fining employers if they do not take women on. If employers do not put in two reports a year to the Director of Affirmative Action they will be fined-shades of Russia. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), the leader of the left wing in Victoria, knows all about that. I will not withdraw that statement. Employers are required to allocate staff and resources to carry out this program and to put in annual reports. Statutory officers will be employed, with five-year appointments; a staff of 25 will be set up in Sydney-all this nonsense. Farmers have been here in Canberra once again today screaming their heads off for help, yet we see this Government creating another bureaucracy; more people to be employed in Sydney. It is a pity the Government could not decentralise its work force a bit. Why does it not set this thing up in the electorate of Calare? Even Maranoa would do. Why does everything have to be established in Sydney, for God's sake? Companies will be named in this Parliament. What is this? It is like the statement by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) that we heard all about today. Companies will be named in this Parliament. What absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Most members of the Confederation of Australian Industry do not support affirmative action. They say it is unnecessary. Of course it is unnecessary. Why would it be necessary if half the people in the work force are women? What does the Government want-80 per cent? The Australian Council of Trade Unions considers all employers should be covered by the legis- lation. The Prime Minister says he will start at 1,000 employees and work down.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Mrs Cameron think of this?

—She thinks I am the best thing since sliced bread. As the House knows, I have had a few things to say about this Bill prior to making such a fantastic speech on it here today, and I have been involved in a little bit of controversy, but it is amazing how many people throughout Australia support me on that stand. I received three letters and phone calls from people who were opposed to what I said. I also received 30 responses from Ministers, women's groups and all sorts of people across the nation who were in favour of what I said and who supported me. They were not opposed to what I had said. They supported my stand on the family unit, about which we on this side of the House are so proud.

SPEECH.PARA: The married people in this place get sick and tired of what is going on. I have four children. I am sick and tired of working my guts out and paying taxes which are used to support unmarried mothers. I support our Minister in Queensland who said yesterday that it is high time we cut off this nonsense. I would not even pay an allowance for the first child. I do not believe that unmarried mothers ought to be encouraged to have any children out of wedlock. The fathers do not get paid. I ask honourable members opposite to give me one example of an unmarried father who is collecting a pension. I have never heard of such nonsense. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) ought to know better. It is absolute nonsense.

Of course, this Bill is quite unnecessary for a number of reasons. I have mentioned that the cost for the first year will be $1.5m. That figure will blow out to $5m or $10m before we know where we are. Companies will have to waste millions of dollars of funds to provide for the cost of providing the facilities alone. We have to take into consideration the bureaucracy that will be involved. All this legislation is about is giving more power to the trade unions. The Australian Council of Trade Unions runs this country and the trade unions will be given more power. We are sick to death of paying our taxes to the trade union movement. We are not only opposed to paying for affirmative action. We are also sick to death of paying for all the other nonsense, such as superannuation, that the Government is putting up. We cannot afford to do it and we are sick to death of our taxes being used for these purposes.

What about a bit of affirmative action for men? What about the nursing and the teaching professions, clerical staff and others? Practically 90 per cent of flight attendants are women. I do not see anything in the Bill about men who are missing out on jobs. Jobs are not being created for them. I believe that a Bill of this nature should cover these areas. Although I am personally opposed to the present Bill, I believe that if we are to have this sort of legislation there should be a little bit of equality.

As I said previously, women who choose to stay at home are downgraded under this legislation. There is no freedom of choice and democracy will be impeded. I wonder where members of the Australian Labor Party stand on this matter. The National Party of Australia has always encouraged women to be members of the Party. We have not needed affirmative action legislation to do this. Sixty-five per cent of members of the National Party in Queensland are women. There are 56 women's branches of the National Party throughout Queensland. The women have an annual conference which attracts 300 to 400 women delegates. I would just like to explain to honourable members opposite that without any of this nonsense and cost to the taxpayer we have involved women in our process for many years. Women are completely absorbed into the National Party in Queensland. They play a tremendously important role in politics in Queensland without the need for affirmative action legislation.

The Government should be committed to giving support to the family and encouraging one parent to stay at home with young children. According to the latest figures, 31.4 per cent of children under 12 not at school and 46.9 per cent of children under 12 at school are looked after by persons other than the family or close relatives or not at all. These facts come from a publication entitled `Facts on Women at Work in Australia-1983'. I ask honourable members to think about the fact that 46.9 per cent of children under 12 at school are looked after by persons other than the family or close relatives or are not looked after at all. As I said, the only thing the Labor Party wants to do is to reduce the family allowance which was introduced by the Fraser Government. We should also be concerned about the money that is allocated to child centres. The rate of growth in Australia is down. Two days ago we saw the latest move by the Labor Party, which was to increase immigration. What is wrong with encouraging more Australians-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you against them?
—No, I am not. However, the Government is not encouraging the family in Australia. That is what it should be doing.
—We are.

—The Government is not. The figures show that child endowment is down. The population figure is down. No encouragement is being given to the family. The real cause of unemployment has been the number of married women in the work force. According to the population figures, the average number of children per family in 1961 was 3.5. The average number now is two. Therefore, the population is down. As a means of increasing the population the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) is now going to increase immigration, for God's sake! What is wrong with encouraging Australians to have a few more kids? One of the reasons why the population has gone down is that so many women are going out to work. They are not prepared to stay at home and look after children. We ought to be giving them some encouragement to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I note you have been very patient in allowing me to say what I wanted to say. My Whip has been winding me up. He seems to think that I have not been going strongly enough on this Bill. Actually, I am just getting wound up. However, I think I had better sit down and give another member a go. I would just like to say that, of course, I am very vocal in opposing this Bill and I will not be supporting it.
Debate (on motion by Ms Mayer) adjourned.
