DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad we have had a little interlude of sanity after the overexcited contribution of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). If ever there was a demonstration of the need for affirmative action legislation, the House has just been treated to 15 minutes of a superb demonstration of that. In fact, so well did the honourable member for Maranoa demonstrate the absolute need for the legislation that it hardly seems worth while carrying on the debate at all. We should all be taking as read that the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill should be approved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been really interested in listening to the debate, particularly the contributions from some Opposition members who seem to want simultaneously to support the Bill and to throw it out. It is a classical case of wanting to have a foot in both camps while having principles in neither. I would like to quote from a study that was done in 1975 by Westgaard and Resler.

In any society, the pattern of people's lives and their living conditions take the form which they do, not so much because somebody somewhere makes a series of decisions to that effect; but in large part because certain social mechanisms, principles, assumptions . . . are taken for granted . . .

The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill challenges those take it for granted mechanisms and assumptions and requires that they be put to the test of planned and deliberate change. In spite of what the honourable member for Maranoa says, the evidence is overwhelming that employment and promotion practices have largely discriminated against women. In many cases this has not been an articulated policy or the subject of an explicit statement of preference; it has occurred because of the assumptions made about the preferences and abilities of women in the work place.

Supporting the legislation will be a number of government projects. I mention the Girls into Engineering project and take up some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). A while ago I had the pleasure of attending a maths and work seminar at Sydney University for Year 9 girls. Part of the seminar included giving to the girls who were there an opportunity to partake in a problem-solving project normally given to first-year engineering students. I am happy to say that some of the girls there came up with a solution to the problem which had so far eluded the first-year engineering students and demonstrated quite conclusively to me that girls have a very good place in the engineering profession. I am glad we are going to encourage them in that regard.

I think some of the assumptions that are made about women, their preferences and their abilities are very well illustrated in a pleasant little book put out by the National Times which contains a collection of its `Women's Role' snippets. This is a good one which came from the Australian Computer Bulletin:
Now, a brief comment on what the impact of computer technology will not be in 1984-
or 1985 or 1986, perhaps-

Management will not be talking to `electronic' secretaries. Dictaphone usage will advance and the typewriter will give way to the word processor, but the `lovely ladies' who answer the phone, organise luncheons and business trips and buy anniversary gifts for the wife will remain a necessity the way they always have.
That is an employer's notion of the place that women have in employment, the need for this Bill is fairly conclusively demonstrated. I have one more choice one to offer:

Increasing numbers of women graduates in medicine require special training if they are to be productive members of the workforce and competent family doctors whilst, at the same time, fulfilling their childbearing and domestic role in society.

The item continues and remarks that women now comprise about 45 per cent of medical graduates. I ask honourable members to understand and note from that statement that there is some confidence that women can fulfil their careers, their roles as domestic people and their childbearing roles at the same time, and all they will need is a little extra training. It is possible to try to achieve change by encouragement, expostulation and argument, and some time this side of the year 3000 change may take place. The evidence is, however, that change is made to occur by action and not by argument. There needs to be a reason to make change. However convincing the argument for change, that alone does not supply the energy. Legislation is one way of providing a reason to act. This Government is very firmly of the opinion that the nation will benefit if the `taken for granted' mechanisms are replaced by objective and considered change aimed at making the best use of available skills and experience. Dame Roma Mitchell, a woman of great achievement, recently said:
I have no doubt that had I been asked twenty years ago whether affirmative action was necessary or desirable I would have replied in the negative.
I no longer believe this.

The Government shares with Dame Roma that lack of belief in the undesirability of affirmative action. However, the Government is taking a path, not of authoritarian prescription, with heavy sanctions for lack of compliance-a type of action so dearly beloved by some in the Opposition-but rather the path of legislation which provides a framework for change with built-in checks of progress. Those who prefer the do it or else approach may find themselves uncomfortable with the legislation, but their discomfort is a penalty which they will pay for being unwilling to examine their own assumptions, actions and motivations.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), in his speech last night, seemed to have some problem with the name of the Bill. He might be able to understand that the use of the phrase `affirmative action' is a message to Australian women that the Government is prepared to view women positively and that it affirms its belief in the competence and skill of Australian women and the already great value of their contribution to Australian life. `Affirmative action' is a title which implies that a positive attitude is expected from all concerned towards the idea and practice of change.

The importance that the Government places on being positive is demonstrated by the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) introduced the Bill. The Prime Minister has consistently supported measures which recognise the value that this Government gives to improving the status of women in the Australian community. The Prime Minister also this year introduced the National Agenda for Women. The three aspects on the Agenda are: Giving women a choice, a say, and a fair go. Women cannot be given a proper choice, or a fair go, if employment and promotion practices give an advantage to male employees. The choice of women, then, is indeed very much a Buckley's choice of take it or leave it at low standard employment.

For too long women have been expected to pay a career penalty if they chose to bear and nurture children. That seems to be a version of choice which assumes that having a family is less important than being in paid employment. The experience that women gain if they make that choice is ignored if they wish to continue working after time out of the paid work force to fulfil a role, the importance of which is recognised more by rhetoric than by reality. We need to affirm the value of that experience by accepting rather than penalising it, and understanding that bearing and raising children is as demanding and responsible a job as any other, and in fact more demanding and more responsible than most, and provides a worthwhile work experience.

The Affirmative Action Bill provides a framework for women to be given a real choice and a fair go in employment. It is impossible to quantify the loss to Australian commerce, industry and education of skills and resources which has probably occurred through biased employment and promotion practices. If we look at the statistics that show the place that women have had in employment and promotion and more particularly in employment in industry and commerce and also in a higher education, we can get some idea of the real loss of capacity which Australia has suffered through its employment practices. Now that we recognise that such a loss has occurred, we know that it should no longer continue. Were that recognition universal, this legislation would not be necessary, but it is all too clear that such recognition is still limited. One has only to examine the gender make-up of tenured positions in higher education institutions to find that women scholars seem to disappear, somewhat unaccountably, between the lower level untenured positions and the more secure and higher status tenured positions. The honourable man for Canning (Mr Gear), with his statement on the sanctity of the independence of higher education institutions, seems to hope that a light will shine from somewhere or other and will provide enlightenment for the present incumbents of those tenured positions which have been so overwhelmingly taken by men.

I think it is pointless, however, to blame employers for following practices which were acceptable in their experience and the experience of their peers; however, it can be only beneficial to question that experience and to examine its assumptions. Changing the thought and behaviour patterns of a lifetime is a very big step to take, and the legislation recognises the size of that step by providing for a clear program to be undertaken, most of which will provide information as important for the employer as it is for the employees and government. The consultation provisions which are written into the legislation provide for an exchange of ideas for the appropriate implementation of the legislation within an organisation. It is also fairly widely recognised by those of us who have had some reason to have a look at this question, and by plenty of those who have not had too much reason but have done it anyway, that the best employment practices include consultation and those which include consultation bring about far better productivity. That is something I think is important to all of us.

One of the honourable members on the almost exclusively male Opposition side seems to be scandalised that employers should be required to report on their employment practices. I wonder whether the women employees who have seen less experienced and less qualified men preferred for employment and promotion would be so scandalised. I wonder whether the honourable member has any idea of the damage that can occur to productivity when employees correctly perceive themselves to be unfairly treated by the employer. I wonder whether honourable members have any idea of the whole series of minor irritations which, in total, form an unpleasant working environment for women. Those irritations are the result of a lack of understanding and respect for women as working colleagues.

I could cite a number of examples, but let me cite the one I have from my own working life and that is being addressed as a bloke. I do not mind being one of the fellows, I suppose, but I would like it recognised from time to time that there are those of us in the House who, by and large, are not blokes. Another irritation is being addressed as `love' by all sorts of people who seem to assume that, because I am a woman, I do not mind being addressed in a very familiar way by people who would not even dream of addressing any of the fellows as `love'. I hope that one of these days they try it and see what happens.

The bogy of paperwork was raised as a reason for failure to legislate for change. I think that that is quite peculiar. The proposition seemed to be that, if you had to report to government about what you were doing, then you could not have the legislation because reporting to government was unreasonable. If we have affirmative legislation that requires people to report to government, I for one would be very, very interested to hear those reports and I think it is a very good motivational operation.

I find the pious statements of support for equal employment opportunity for women while at the same time bemoaning the necessary requirement for changing unequal employment opportunities hypocritical in the extreme and I am very sad to see quite young members of this House indulging in that bit of hypocrisy. It seems to be a case of having 100-year-old heads on 20-year-old shoulders.
I would like to quote from a conference paper prepared by Dr Anne Summers and Ms Valerie Pratt when they were talking about employment, who is employed, and for what reason. They stated:

Increasingly young married working women are applying for maternity leave and returning to work. Many older women, their child-rearing responsibilities completed by their early 40s, are preparing themselves for a return to the workforce with a degree, qualification or skill. They return with high motivation, energy, vigour, maturity and new ideas-energy which is being recognised and harnessed by more astute employers.

I think we will still find that those same energetic, mature, vigorous and creative women are at the moment suffering because they did something which, according to some employers, was unforgivable: They had families. However, in the light of that statement perhaps some honourable members may care to re-examine their fear of change and recognise that affirmative action legislation is long overdue recognition of the value of the choices being made by the women described above.

The Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry have been quoted as being opposed to the legislation. That may be true. Nevertheless, those two organisations recognise the need for change. They have formed the Council for Equal Employment Opportunities and have invited the Government to be represented on the Board of the Council. The Government has accepted the invitation and has asked me to be that representative. The Council recognises that employers will need assistance to introduce new concepts into their employment practices and plans to provide that assistance. I wish to pay tribute to the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry for the positive way in which they are responding to the perceived need for change, and I look forward to being involved in their important work.

I also wish to pay tribute to the work of the companies and higher education institutions that took part in the pilot program. In some cases the previous experience of those companies was a valuable resource in determining the way in which affirmative action programs could be implemented. I believe that this Bill will have a wider impact than ensuring that women have more equal opportunities in employment: It will eventually promote much greater respect between men and women as people equal in their capacity and equal in their worth. I congratulate the very committed and competent Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) and the talented and hardworking people in the Office of the Status of Women on their achievement. This legislation is yet another step by the Government towards improving the status of Australian women, in giving Australian women a choice-and a proper choice, not Hobson's choice-and in ensuring that this country does not waste half of its resources. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that in a speakers list of over 40, at the last count I made, six women will be speaking on this Bill. It was not very long ago when, if such a Bill had been considered in this House, no women would have spoken because there would have been no women members. There are those of my male colleagues who seem to believe that, because I am here, there are therefore no barriers to women entering Parliament. The fact that I am the only one here shows that there are indeed barriers to women entering Parliament. It is also a fact that there are amongst my male colleagues those who resent my pointing out those barriers, both in parliament and more particularly outside it. They point their finger at me and say: `You are here. Doesn't that show that it can be done?'.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many reasons for my being here but, despite most of those reasons, I would not be here if it were not for three very particular ones. Firstly, when I was being educated in the 1950s I had enlightened parents who did what parents in the 1950s because of social attitudes generally did not do. They educated their daughters right through tertiary education, at great expense and sacrifice to themselves. In order to do that my mother was one of those first working wives. Although I was still at primary school when she undertook that course, I was not abandoned. I trust that there are those who do not think that I prove the argument that, if mothers go to work with primary school-age children, no good will come of it.

The second reason is that I went to a girls school. I was interested to hear an earlier speech by the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), who in his speech paid particular attention to the subject of the education of girls. I have no doubt at all that, if I had not gone to a girls high school, my own attitudes and aspirations would have been quite different. I say that confidently, because in my primary schooling I went to a co-educational school. I could give many examples, but time will not permit today, of the difference in treatment of girls at a co-educational school in those days versus the encouragement that was given to girls in single sex schools, not the least of those encouragements being that all the teachers were female and my role models in my quite impressionable adolescent years were successful professional women.

The third and most significant of the three reasons-the two previous ones I have mentioned are not essential-is the fact that I am childless-not through choice but just because of the hand fate dealt me. If I had had to take time out of my professional life and career, as I would have for the bearing and rearing of children, I have no doubt at all that I would never have overcome the disadvantage at which that would have put me in competing with men in any attempt to pursue a political career. In other words, my conditions in life have not been that of the average woman. However, I recognise that, and I believe that I can appreciate the position of the average women or, rather, the average situation of women. I would appreciate it if my colleagues did not use me as an example of why this legislation and similar legislation is not necessary, because I-of all people-am only too aware of how important it is.

I welcome the interest of so many members in this subject. I have to admit that, despite 12 years in this Parliament, I was unaware of this remarkably high level of interest in and concern about the subject of barriers to the fair employment of women in Australia. In particular, I welcome the participation of so many of my coalition colleagues in such large numbers in the debate. I look forward to their future contribution on directly related subjects, such as the unreasonably restricted access to child care in Australia.

On that point, I refer very briefly, and I hope not unkindly, to the speech by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). I fear that the honourable member for Maranoa must be unaware of the statements made by my parliamentary Leader this morning when he spoke on this Bill. The honourable member for Maranoa quite rightly expressed concern about the position of children who had no adult to care for them during working hours because the adult or adults in whose care they were, were at work. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in his speech this morning gave at least one excellent example of how this can come about. He gave an example of rigidity of approach to working hours and inflexibility of attitudes of people involved in the arbitration and industrial system as a contributing factor. He gave the example of an inner Sydney suburban company where the women employees requested a change in their working hours, to start earlier and take a shorter lunch time so that they could finish earlier in the day and be home by the time their children finished school in the afternoon. The employer agreed. However, the Arbitration Inspectorate stepped in and the employer and employees were forced to go back to the laid down pattern of hours and, as a consequence, those women could not be at home with their children after the school day finished. It is that sort of situation and that sort of work structure that equal employment opportunity is about.

It is unfortunate that many of the people who have made contributions on this Bill-and I am not necessarily talking about contributions in the House, but also contributions outside the House-simply do not understand what equal employment opportunities are, or even what affirmative action is, if one must call it that. I do not mind calling it affirmative action, provided the term `positive discrimination' is understood to be the term that refers to employment quotas. However, affirmative action used to be synonymous with quotas and people still have that concern about it. So we will leave that one alone and I will talk about equal employment opportunities.

Many people simply do not understand what this subject is. Figures are put forward from time to time, contributions are made, examples are given, such as the example given by the Leader of the Opposition this morning, and the reality of life for many women is not understood. The phenomenon of an increased percentage of our workforce being married women-not only married women, but married women with children who are still what we would call of dependency age-has been the matter which has brought this very much to the fore. It has been the growth of the women's movement in the last 15 years, its articulateness and its ability to organise itself, which has brought forward this issue as a priority issue. The reasons that married women enter the work force are of course, legion. I gave the example of my mother, to whom I am enormously grateful, whose reason was to pay for the education of my sister and me. However, when that need no longer existed my mother chose to stay in the work force as a professional, as a nursing sister, because she enjoyed her work. She particularly enjoyed work which gave her personal satisfaction. It is really quite futile to be looking in this debate at the reasons why people go to work. I do not think it is a bad thing that people have to go to work to get money. We expect that of men in the community. We call young men who do not want to do that `dole bludgers'. No one would approve of that attitude to work. I do not really think that that is the issue.

I believe there are many more women who would want to go to work, and not be in a position of dependency on government, if there were suitable programs showing an understanding of their needs. There has been some debate in the last couple of days on the subject of the supporting parent's benefit. That benefit goes to a number of categories of people. Some of it goes to men who are widowers or divorcees who are rearing children. Less than 10 per cent of recipients come into that category. Not all of the rest of the women recipients are divorcees or unmarried mothers. A number of them are widows, and that is a substantial category. Nevertheless, the most substantial category is female divorcees, followed by unmarried mothers. I do not intend to join in the debate on that subject as it has presented itself in the last 24 hours. But I do want to say something on the subject of the position in which supporting parents, particularly women, find themselves.

I am deeply concerned about the hundreds of thousands of children in this country who are being reared in welfare families. I have a particular concern when that is a one parent family. They grow up, frequently surrounded by families in the same position, and their understanding of life in the end is that the wherewithal for sustaining life comes through the letterbox. I understood through my childhood-I was fortunate enough to have a secure and stable family-that the wherewithal for my life came from the fact that my father went out the back door at eight o'clock in the morning to travel to work. I understood that. Nobody explained it to me. I absorbed it through the pores of my skin. I am concerned that hundreds of thousands of Australian children are not observing and learning that fact, namely, that a family's needs are paid for by earning money through work. I am not saying that this large percentage of women who are rearing children on a supporting parent's benefit ought to be pushed out the door to work; not at all. It is a matter of individual situations.

I know that many of them would like to go out the door to work but because of structural barriers they cannot do so. One of those structural barriers is often the absence of adequate child care facilities, but that is not the only problem. There is a legacy of a generally low level of employment and training of young women in Australia which means that when a woman who is still young-say, in her thirties-suddenly finds herself without somebody to be the breadwinner, and with dependent children of primary school age to rear, she simply does not have the skills that are relevant to today's work force. If she ever had good skills they are out of date. Because of the number of years she has been out of the work force she lacks confidence, as the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) said earlier. Many of those women would dearly love to go to work, to get more money, to have the prospect of getting more money and to have something other than young children as the total part of their company and life, as much as they love those children. A lack of access to education, training and retraining is the reason that so many of those women get locked into welfare and the supporting parent's benefit. By the time their children are no longer dependent on them to be there when they leave for school in the morning, when they come home from school in the afternoon and during the school holidays, many of them feel it is too late, and in psychological terms, for many of them, it is too late.

I feel very strongly that there are many delinquent fathers in Australia who ought to be making a contribution to their children's care and upkeep, whether or not they have been married to the women who bore those children. I wish some of the men who run the State governments and this Federal Government would put it higher on the list of priorities of their governments. A lot of words are spoken about it. But all of those bodies which need to get together to organise a program of action to do something about it simply do not act. I hope Mrs Yvonne Chapman has a quiet word with her Premier some time this week and suggests that he might lift it up the agenda of the Queensland Government so that not only will the taxpayer receive some relief but also those mothers who are trying to be good mothers will have the prospect of receiving some relief in the future.

There are many assumptions enshrined in patterns of work that go back many years and are even more than 20 years out of date. When one considers that the high percentage of members of the work force who are mothers of school age-children but that very little change has taken place in working hours, working weeks and working conditions-the patterns of those conditions being essentially the same as when nearly all the work force was either male or single females-one might start to have an inkling of the difficulty.

Mr Deputy Speaker, time is short and there are a couple of things to which I particularly want to refer before concluding my speech. Many matters, of course, could be raised. One thing I wish to refer to in particular is that there has been some mention in this debate and outside the Parliament of the cost of implementing equal employment opportunity programs. In fact, one of the speakers in the debate has made this statement:

The Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University has told us that affirmative action will cost his university alone $450,000 a year in additional affirmative action staff, superannuation advertising procedures and so on.

I am aware that there have been some Press reports to that effect, and some time ago I checked up on just where that figure could possibly have come from. I could not understand how it could cost a university $450,000 to implement affirmative action programs, given that in my profession before entering this Parliament I was a university administrator. So, I could not understand that figure, given that it related to an area that I know something about. On checking, I found that the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University had written for the University of Sydney News of 10 April 1984 an article in the `Comment' column about the cost to the Sydney University of complying with the anti-discrimination legislation in New South Wales. I would like to refer to some specific points that he made, because they are good examples of what concerns people who support equal employment opportunities legislation. Because of limited time I can refer to this only briefly, but he states, in part:

The costs will be for additional advertising, for more elaborate administrative processes than at present in respect of appointment and promotions, and for more elaborate forms of grievances procedures.

At present not all academic positions are advertised; for example, temporary appointments and certain research assistant posts may or may not be advertised. Few non-academic positions are advertised externally because, by arrangement with the union, vacancies are advertised internally and external advertisement follows only if no suitable internal applicant is available.
He refers to `no suitable internal applicant' being available-not to the best person for the job, but to there being no one who could possibly cope with it. That is really astonishing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like a closed shop.
—Yes, it is, thanks to the employers and the unions. Referring to the effect of that, he states:

SPEECH.PARA: A universal policy of advertising all vacancies, except the most temporary, will more than double our advertising costs. At present they amount to about $90,000 a year; they are likely to be increased by $100,000.

So, that is $100,000 out of the $450,000. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard some tables relating to employment patterns in tertiary institutions in Australia. These tables come from Parliamentary Paper 201 of 1984, the appendix to the discussion paper on affirmative action for women. I have not yet shown them to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) but I have mentioned them to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tables show for example, that there has been very little improvement in the position of women employed at universities and colleges in both the non-academic area and the academic area from 1977 to 1982-the time span that is used for this table-it may just be because the universities were not advertising vacancies. If an institution's employment pattern is heavily biased towards one sex or the other and promotions and appointments are made almost exclusively from within the ranks of existing employees, particularly for more senior positions one would expect it to take a very long time indeed for changes in the percentage of women employed by that institution to occur. In this context when in the past employment has been overwhelmingly male, that requirement to advertise is an essential one. I wonder how many men who have involved themselves in this debate knew that or had any thoughts about the implications of that aspect. That is what equal employment opportunity legislation is about, that is, affirmative action programs.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, the program referred to by the Vice-Chancellor was one brought on him by very strong anti-discrimination legislation in New South Wales, and this example is only part of the type of behaviour covered by that Bill. I am aware that several other universities will incur costs amounting to about 20 per cent of the estimate made by the University of Sydney, as a result of the legislation that we are debating today. Those costs will arise from the employment of a couple of people and on-costs. However, those universities are already advertising vacancies and have been doing so for some time, so at least the cost of advertising vacancies is one special to a university which has overlooked for a very long time something very basic to equality.

Before concluding, I want to make one further comment in relation to a point that some people have latched on to. I think the provision for reporting to Parliament is a good one. Those people who have said that it is weak, that it is not good enough-that is it is somehow meaningless-have completely overlooked the fact that it is the device we use to make the Ombudsman effective publicly; they have completely overlooked the fact that it is the device that is used to make consumer affairs bureaux in the States effective. Of course, in the end it will depend on who are-or are not-up there in the Press Gallery. It will depend on whether those who write stories on parliamentary reports choose to give this subject some priority. I hope that they will do so, and I expect that they will.

I believe this piece of legislation is indeed a very mild version of affirmative action. Whilst late on the Opposition will be critical of some of its details, it has, I believe, sought to accommodate the views of those who have considered this matter. It is quite reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with very great pleasure that I follow the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for Chisholm (Mrs Mayer) in this debate. I am very pleased to rise today to speak on this Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. It represents a major government initiative designed to remove existing obstacles which prevent women from fully participating in the Australian work force, it is the culmination of an exhaustive process of consultation and discussion and it incorporates the lessons learned from the pilot program which finished in July last year. During the pilot program the participants agreed that affirmative action made good business sense and that it was sound personnel practice. It certainly makes good common sense to me and to many women and men in Australia. Our Government believes that it is important to encourage all employers to conform to the principle of equal opportunity for women in employment. The measures contained in this Bill are similar to those required to be taken by Commonwealth government departments at present. I understand also that appropriate mechanisms are being devised for the same sorts of measures to pertain to Commonwealth statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will require private sector employers of 100 or more employees to promote equal opportunity for women in employment by developing and implementing an affirmative action program. Higher education institutions will also be required to comply with the terms of the legislation. The Bill is based on a program of phased-in implementation and will have only a minimal financial impact on industry. Its effect on women, however, will be significant because it has the capacity to remove the structural barriers which currently confront them in many areas of employment and which limit their potential for advancement. Preceding speakers on both sides of the House have spent a considerable amount of time already on outlining what they deem the Bill to be. Therefore, perhaps I can better employ my time by using some of it to dispel a number of myths surrounding the Bill and to emphasise what it is not.

It is not a punitive approach to affirmative action. On the contrary, the Government seeks to foster the development of affirmative action programs in a climate of co-operation between employers and itself. The only sanction in the Bill is the power of the Director of Affirmative Action to name in a report to Parliament any employer who fails to lodge either a report or further information on request. I commend the honourable member for Moncrieff on her comments in that area. I, too, believe that that is a very important sanction in the Bill.

Further, the Bill is not a proposal involving reverse discrimination or the use of quotas. Objectives and forward estimates are self-determined by the company or the institution concerned and therefore reflect the requirements of the individual employer. They are not imposed by an outside body, and are not rigid or fixed numbers which must be met regardless of all other factors. They simply represent the employers' own views of what is achievable within a determined time frame. Furthermore, the setting of objectives and forward estimates does not undermine the question of merit. This legislation is based on the merit principle. Sub-clause 3 (4) of the Bill states that nothing in the Bill shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit. As Senator Susan Ryan said in the past:
. . . critics who claim that the affirmative action program will destroy the merit principle have failed to grasp the fundamental principles of affirmative action and equal employment opportunity.

They also present the concept of appointment and promotion on merit in the present system as value free and clearly defined. That is not so. This legislation is not an attack on the family. Criticism of this kind is completely unwarranted but it does provoke legitimate concern amongst those who are genuinely committed to the welfare of children. Contrary to the comments earlier today of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), no woman will be forced into the job market as a result of this legislation. On the contrary; the Bill may actually help her access an opportunity for better pay or conditions in the employment she currently holds, to the ultimate advantage of her family and herself. Of course, it is the case that where mothers are more involved in paid employment fathers may become more concerned with child rearing and domestic duties, although this does not necessarily happen. Such a change in parental responsibilities is something which needs to be worked out according to the circumstances of each individual family and ought not to be regarded as necessarily detrimental to the welfare of children.

In some families the father may be unemployed and the mother may be able to obtain a job. In others the mother may be a sole supporting parent. Whatever the particular situation of a family, no general rule of thumb can be, or should be, applied by this Parliament or anyone else to the question of the women working. The individual concerned has a fundamental right to freedom of choice. Surely those women who choose to work or who need to work ought not to have to contend with outmoded prejudices in respect of their role, or to suffer harsh judgments of their capabilities as parents.

The Bill is not totally or primarily concerned with women moving into senior or middle management. The affirmative action program is designed to examine all areas of the work force, all occupations and qualifications and all types of work, and to develop strategies to ensure that women in all occupations and industries are included. Under affirmative action legislation such as this, and the programs it will generate in the longer term, barriers which have prevented women from moving across occupations or divisions of any organisation will be examined and, where possible, dismantled. This rethink will enable the employers to utilise fully the skills available in the organisation's work force, both male and female. In devising training courses and selecting the individual employees who are to attend them those sections of the work force which traditionally have been forgotten or overlooked will need to be considered. Naturally, keyboard and clerical staff will be included in any such review. However, I emphasise that no pressure will be applied to force women wanting to work in these areas to change their occupations or to seek promotion when that is not their wish.

A reappraisal of occupations which are traditionally female is vital for any strategy aimed at changing the structure and recognition of women's work. Another area which requires close examination by employers concerns the introduction of women into what are seen as non-traditional female jobs. It is hoped and anticipated that affirmative action programs will reduce some of the difficulties confronting women in non-traditional employment and make it less unusual for a woman to be employed in these areas should that be her ambition, inclination and aptitude. Obviously, if we are able to effect a labour market in which women can realistically aspire to any job for which they are qualified we need to ensure that our education system does not continue to stifle girls' expectations for themselves, as the present system often does. As a parent of two daughters I am anxious that this situation be addressed seriously by governments and educators generally across Australia.

The spirit underlying this legislation is not new. Nobody on this side of the House pretends that it is. It has existed for many years and has motivated many eminent figures in our country's history-many of whom have been female. Among these was Edith Dircksey Cowan, after whom my electorate was named. Edith was a fighter for the advancement of women in Australian society and for the recognition of their ability to contribute equally in every field of endeavour. Edith Cowan was firmly convinced of the need for women justices of the peace, lawyers and jurors. In 1915 she became one of the first five women magistrates appointed to the Children's Court at a time when women were still debarred from becoming justices of the peace or from practising law. In 1919 the Government finally legislated to enable women to become JPs. In 1920 Edith campaigned through the Press on the Government's failure to implement the Act. Not surprisingly, later that year the Government appointed nine women JPs, including Cowan. She was also awarded the Order of the British Empire in 1920 for her war work.

As I mentioned in my first speech in this House, Edith Cowan was the first woman in Australia to gain a seat in Parliament. She was involved in and benefited from the post-war agitation of women's organisations to end the legal bar to women entering Parliament. Legislation was passed in 1920 and in the 1921 elections Edith was one of five women candidates. She successfully contested the Western Australian Legislative Assembly seat of West Perth, defeating the sitting nationalist Attorney-General. In 1923 Edith Cowan introduced a private member's Bill relating to the legal status of women. As introduced it was similar to the Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act passed in the United Kingdom in 1919. It laid down that a person should not be disqualified by sex or marriage from exercising any public function, from holding any civil or justicial office, from practising law or from entering any other profession. However, the Bill was amended to outlaw exclusion only on the ground of sex. Marriage remained a permissible ground for the exclusion of women at that stage. Nevertheless, this Bill, which became the Women's Legal Status Act 1923, was a major breakthrough in enabling women to enter law and other professions. I am indebted to Marian Sawer and Marian Simms, who wrote a book called A Women's Place, from which I got some of that information.

Edith Cowan was an independently minded nationalist and a pioneer of women's involvement in public life. I am certain that she would applaud the passage of the legislation we are presently debating-although she was never a member of the Australian Labor Party. Likewise, I am sure that many of the working women in my electorate will approve of this Bill, as undoubtedly will many of the men. In concluding I wish to congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Susan Ryan for their persistence and their commitment to this historic legislation and for their endeavours to maximise community and employer agreement on the provisions it contains. I proudly commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding to my speech on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill I must say that I feel a little overwhelmed, because if the records of this House are examined it will be seen that not many male speakers have had the privilege of following three very eloquent lady speakers who have delivered the views of different sides of the House. It is somewhat amusing to find the Government introducing this Bill which is designed to promote the rights and status of women while it is currently demanding of male parliamentarians that they treat their wives as mere appendages when detailing publicly their extra-parliamentary pecuniary interests. I mention that in passing.
—And their husbands.

—And their husbands, as the honourable member for Cowan has pointed out. The Government claims proudly that this Bill is a milestone in our nation's legislative history. I can think of a number of reasons why this Bill should cause disquiet in this place and in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding declarations to the contrary which have already been made in a number of speeches here today, the Bill ignores policy lessons from the United States which have been documented since the early 1960s. The United States saw policy progress from commitment to equal opportunity, to affirmative action based on informing disadvantaged groups of flexible employment policies, to presumption of employer guilt based on statistical under-representation, to the creation of specific rights legislation and bureaucratic policing bodies and, finally, to the imposition of penalties, quotas and damages. This can be seen very clearly by anybody who cares to make a study of the literature that is available. The United States started out with targets; but, through the incremental growth of legislation and specialist bureaucracies similar to those we are now creating, it ended up with quotas and positive discrimination. Employers in the United States came to know, as employers in Australia will soon come to know, that failure to reach targets was seen as evidence of bad faith and discrimination. They knew that, if they wished to avoid adverse publicity, costly inquiries and loss of government favour, the solution was quotas.

The Bill reflects either a lack of proper preparation or an intention to mislead by claiming that there will be no sanction facing an employer who receives an adverse report from the Director of Affirmative Action. To make this point, I would like the House to consider the following scenario: In scene one, an employer fails to submit a report to the Director or refuses to develop a full or partial program and receives an adverse public report. In scene two, individual women, a group of women acting as a class, a trade union and the Commissioner for Sex Discrimination, having been alerted to this employer's discrimination-assumed in this Bill-by the adverse report, lodge complaints with the Human Rights Commission under sections 5, 14, 50 and 51 of the Sex Discrimination Act. In scene three, an inquiry is undertaken by the Commissioner or an officer of the Human Rights Commission and the employer is required to attend a conference, to submit certain documents and to submit actuarial and statistical data concerning employment patterns. He refuses all three demands and so faces personal fines of $1,000 and corporate fines of $5,000 for each refusal under sections 87 to 89.

In scene four, the matter is formally referred to the Human Rights Commission by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and an inquiry is held. A summons is issued for the employer's attendance and for certain documents under section 90. If the employer refuses, he again faces fines. If he agrees, he faces either a private or public inquiry where he is cross-examined by the Commissioner's counsel and he must answer all questions or face fines. He is disallowed even his own legal representation. In scene five, the Commission makes a determination finding the respondent guilty under sections 14, 50, 51 and 87 to 90; recommends that the respondent develop an affirmative action program as restitution; and publishes the facts, many of which, whilst supposedly confidential under this Bill, cannot be withheld under the Sex Discrimination Act.

In scene six, the Commission instituted proceedings in the Federal Court to enforce its determination. In addition to such pressures, the employer faces industrial action and, in certain cases, similar complaints and inquiries under the proposed Bill of Rights legislation. He can avoid the adverse publicity, cost inquiries, industrial action and loss of favour with the Government if he just develops a program and meets its targets, which he knows are best achieved by watering down the selection criteria and by preferential employment practices.

I believe that the Bill fails to define or defend the principle of merit and can be interpreted only as part of the trend to water down that principle. Let us consider the impact of targets, which are wrongly called `forward estimates' in the Bill, on the principle of merit. A target can be meaningful only if it results in appointments of women in addition to those appointments based on normal merit criteria and that could be achieved only by watering down the qualifications required for a position, which is a way of disguising preferential employment. Let it be clear that by requiring targets the Bill establishes henceforth an unspoken, unadvertised criterion for any selection panel or personnel officer who will not be able to resist pressure to prove good faith in reaching the target. The Bill reflects, in the words of Dame Leonie Kramer, an obsession with numbers and the concomitant equation between equality of opportunity and numerical equality. It also reflects the assumption that under-representation of a group statistically is proof of discrimination and assumes in its definition guilt for all relevant employers.

The Bill not only reflects a rejection of the possibility that statistical under-representation is the result of social, educational or other circumstances for which the employer is not responsible at all, but also reflects the view that employers should bear the burden of ameliorative schemes. The Bill rejects the possibility that, even without discrimination, skills and interests might be unevenly distributed between men and women; it is confused by the possibility that uneven representation might reflect legitimate and informed choices by individual women. The Bill fails to consider the economic and social significance of work undertaken by women in the home and so fails to develop policy to support women who choose that job opportunity and who wish to pursue excellence in that field. It reflects the attitude of this male dominated Cabinet that work in the home is not real labour. The Bill indicates the failure by the Government to make a judgment as to whether there is a socially preferable mix of home duties, occasional child care and casual employment for a woman in the first years of her responsibility as a mother and whether an appropriate review of government policy would encourage such a mix.

This Bill is not a milestone, it is a millstone; and this Parliament, the business community and that very group for which it was mistakenly drafted-women-will rue the day that it was placed around this country's collective neck. Of course, the Australian Labor Party could abandon the Bill in favour of an action of far greater symbolism if it really wanted to influence popular consciousness. It could assist Senator Susan Ryan, for example, to gain a safe seat and elect her leader and therefore Prime Minister. But, of course, such an outstanding example of affirmative action-obviously Senator Ryan merits such elevation and is handicapped only by structural discrimination in the ALP-will never come to fruition--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Ms Jakobsen?

—Despite the interjection from the honourable member for Melbourne, this will never come to fruition because the right wing of the ALP-I am not blaming the left wing as the honourable member for Melbourne might think-will not give the overriding weight to gender that it demands from private employers. Similar discrimination was revealed by the left wing of the ALP when it worked to have someone other than the Right's choice proposed as Speaker of this House, notwithstanding the social significance of the election of a woman as Speaker, irrespective of ideology.
—She was unopposed. What are you talking about?

—I am talking about the activities that led up to her being unopposed. I conclude by saying that the Government will not retreat from this Bill, as we all know, and the Opposition has indicated its intention to allow the legislation to pass, notwithstanding its concern as to its inadequacy in certain instances and excesses in others. This being the case, I can only hope that the Government or the Australian Democrats in the Senate at least support the Opposition's proposal to include a sunset clause in the Bill. I believe that such a clause will be the most appreciated aspect of this Bill within months of its proclamation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we can safely say that the Opposition has reached rock bottom over this piece of legislation. I thought that that point had already been reached, but I was wrong. The Opposition continues to slip and slide as it makes up its mind on what it is going to do. The Opposition does not know whether it is coming or going over the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. One Opposition speaker says he supports the Bill and the next speaker says he is opposed to it. What an extraordinary way to run an Opposition. Half of the coalition supports the Bill and the other half says it cannot tolerate the legislation. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and another honourable member-I have not heard him speak yet, so I will not mention the one at whom I am looking-are opposed to it. The simple answer is for them to have the guts to come in here and oppose the legislation, instead of making all these flowery speeches; but they are frightened of the electoral backlash which would result if they voted against it. They should let the people of Australia, particularly the women of Australia, know exactly what they really think of them. The reality is that the people who have made those speeches are opposed to women furthering their opportunities throughout the broader society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that not all honourable members on the other side share that view, I concede that, but a substantial section of the members on the other side have expressed views, one after another, of opposition to the advancement of women in any area. They have made that perfectly clear. We have heard some amazing contributions. We are lucky in a sense-I am sure the Australian Broadcasting Corporation appreciates it-that this is a broadcast day, because the people of Australia have heard at first hand what some of these people have uttered. If they have not heard it, they can ring their local member of parliament and get a copy of Hansard to read the quite extraordinary comments that have been made, particularly by the members of the National Party of Australia. Those comments should be read and taken note of when people cast their next vote.

In discussing this Bill it is worth examining in some detail the sad and sorry history of the coalition's attitude to this issue. It helps us to understand why the coalition is in such a confused and unhappy state on that side of the House. It is a history which, not unexpectedly, involves numerous twists and turns. We should begin with the Opposition's response to the Sex Discrimination Bill in 1983-84. As is well known, the then shadow Minister responsible for the status of women, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), failed to exact bipartisan support for that legislation, even after the affirmative action proposals were removed. In the subsequent free vote, most National Party members and a number of Liberal Party dries voted against that Bill. The response of the dries in that instance indicated just how socially conservative their political philosphy really is. Behind the rhetoric about the free market is a basic philosophical approach which, in essence, accepts the traditional division of labour between men and women. That approach is premised on a market role for men and a domestic-motherhood role for women.

For the ever diminishing group of wets in the coalition a small victory was achieved just a year after the sex discrimination legislation was passed, when the Opposition endorsed the Government's Green Paper on affirmative action and agreed to participate in the pilot program. Given the forces arrayed against them, this was a remarkable achievement, and I pay tribute to those members of the Opposition. However, the victory was short lived. Wham-in came the conservatives! The dries had suffered only a minor setback and by September they were ready for the kill. The newly elected Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) wasted no time in clarifying the directions of the coalition. At a Press conference soon after he had disposed of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) he set the record straight on a number of policy areas, including affirmative action. The Leader of the Opposition said then: `I would be extraordinarily sceptical myself, and opposed, in fact, to any kind of prescriptive action.' That was the end of the honourable member for Goldstein and those people who supported him.

This position of the coalition was confirmed by Senator Peter Baume, the Opposition representative on the affirmative action working party, who, by this time, had replaced the luckless member for Goldstein as the Opposition spokesman on women's affairs. It was a tragedy for this Parliament that that occurred. Senator Baume issued a minority report on affirmative action legislation in which he made it quite clear that the Opposition totally rejected the introduction of prescriptive legislation. The reason for rejecting the legislation was not because he and the Opposition had doubts about whether legislation was the best course of action to adopt in an area involving attitudinal change. No, it was much simpler than that, and I want Opposition members to listen. I do not think even the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) could understand this. It was because Senator Baume and the Opposition considered such legislation to be unnecessary regulation of the private and tertiary sector. So the Opposition way back then, opposed any advancement of women. Let us not beat around the bush, because that is quite clearly the position of the Opposition. Opposition members can butter it up and make flowery speeches in here, but that is the overwhelming majority position of the Opposition.

This response is a perfect example of the dogma of economic rationalism being employed yet again to protect and justify the continuation of sexual inequality and mainstream social conservatism. Once that opposition to legislation became the official line, some of the more neurotic fringe within the coalition ranks let fly with what they really believed about the place and role of women in society. We heard some of that today from the honourable member for Maranoa in an extraordinary speech. I hope it was covered by the media. A number of the Press came in and took notes, and I am sure that they will publish it. Then we had from the honourable member for Franklin another pearl. He will be best remembered for his late night television interview after a recent wedding in Tasmania, where he-

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a point of order. Is it in order for one honourable member to refer to another honourable member as a fool?
— I thought the honourable member said `a pearl'.
—I said `a pearl'. You are so damned ignorant in Queensland that you would not know the difference between a fool and a pearl. Perhaps if you looked in the mirror you might see it.
—I take a further point of order. I resent the inference in that statement and I ask for it to be withdrawn.
—The honour- able member for Melbourne will withdraw.
—That he is a pearl or a fool? I will withdraw both and we can reach our own conclusions on what he is.
—The honour- able member for Melbourne will withdraw.
—I withdraw. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: Before I obviously dented the pride of Opposition members, I was attempting to remind them of what some of their people had said in relation to this Bill. I am interested to see the shadow spokesman on affirmative action from the other place here to hear about the appalling performance by some of his colleagues. The honourable member for Maranoa said that the solution was to spend more money on kitchens and to keep women in the kitchens. He was answered by a close relative of his who put him straight the next morning on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation AM program I understand that it was some time before he went back to Queensland because he had some explaining to do about what he really meant. He was also severely criticised by Senator Vanstone, a Liberal Party senator, for his actions. If people would like to read his speech they should contact their local member and get a copy of it. He is a man who I understand is pushing hard to take a more senior position on the front bench for the National Party and is engaged in the leadership tussle in that group. He made some of the most outrageous comments about women. This should be clearly understood.

The honourable member for Franklin talked about his challenge to the leadership. This happened late at night after a wedding when he was interviewed recently on the 60 Minutes program. He was reported as making some quite extraordinary comments, that women are not physically fit to carry out certain things, that they cannot stand the sight of blood. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) is another person who made an extraordinary speech. I hope all the women in his electorate read what he had to say. It is quite clear that his attitude to women is back somewhere in the nineteenth century. We are trying to bring him out of that time into the modern day type of thinking. We are trying to educate those honourable members opposite. It is extremely difficult but we are prepared to try so that when they represent their electorates they will have a great understanding of the needs of women.

Time is very short in this debate and I did want to continue at great length about what those honourable members opposite had to say, but it is hardly worth it. The fundamental question must be asked: Will the National Party oppose this legislation? Is it going to vote against the legislation? I hope members of that Party do not make these great speeches because they are on air and let the people back in the electorate think that they will oppose it and then come in here and not have the guts to have their names recorded. I want to see members of the National Party vote against it, so that we can show the people what their real position is.

I think an interesting phenomenon has occurred in this debate and it is this: An inverse relationship has developed between knowledge of affirmative action and outspokenness. By and large the loudest and most virulent opposition to affirmative action legislation has tended to come from individuals who have the least knowledge and understanding of what it will mean in practice. The examples I have given demonstrate this clearly enough, but the following definition of how the legislation will work by none other than the honourable member for Maranoa-and I have to keep quoting him because he is such a good spokesperson for the National Party's position-says it all. He believes that if a factory has a 100 men, it has to employ a hundred women to balance the 100 men by dragging more women out of the house. What a ridiculous, stupid statement to make. That is not what the legislation says. Members of the National Party come in here, mouth off and do not even take time to read the legislation. The honourable member for Gippsland was a classic example; he was pulled up a couple of times during the debate because he obviously had not read the legislation. That was an example of the National Party's poor contribution. People ought to read what some honourable members have had to say. National Party members did not take time out to read the legislation. They just parrot off and think that that is going to win them votes in the electorate. Quite clearly, it will not.

Much to the horror of some honourable members, the Opposition has officially shifted its ground. Shifting ground is a very difficult thing for the Opposition. Honourable members opposite are normally considered very slow, but on this issue they have outdone even their normal performance. One day they will support it, the next day they will not, then they will again. Then we hear undercurrents; we hear of little secret meetings of the National Party and threats to roll the leader. Then they put out the gem of all; a joint statement by the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) saying that they have overcome their difficulties and will speak against it, move the odd amendment and vote for the legislation. Today they have all come in and have rejected the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). They have turned their back on the old leadership-they are gone. The Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party have been rejected. Members of that Party have rolled the agreement they made with the Liberals and they are going to vote against it. What a shambles.

How do the Liberals feel about this? They have to justify this lunatic fringe within the Opposition. I wonder how much longer the Liberal Party can afford to carry around such liabilities as the honourable member for Maranoa and the right honourable member for New England. Obviously the right honourable member for New England is a liability because members of that Party will not abide by his agreement with the Liberals. I am quite sure honourable members on this side will join with me in supporting their continued presence in the Opposition for a very long time-the longer the better for Australia. I think that becomes clearer every day. Their outbursts are an almost watertight guarantee that the Labor Party-that is this side of the House in case those honourable members opposite do not know-will remain in office for many years.

I address my remarks to the substance of some of the amendments to this legislation to be moved by the Opposition. One of those proposed amendments seeks to change the title to `The Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill'. The purpose of the Bill is for equal opportunity and should be so specified. The Government completely rejects this proposed amendment. If that concept of affirmative action is removed, the very guts of the Bill will be destroyed. The Opposition obviously knows that and that is why it intends to move such an amendment. The Opposition pretends that it supports a fair go for women and that it is committed to tearing down the barriers against women. We have heard that we should tear down the barriers, to quote Senator Baume. But when the means of achieving that outcome is put in front of honourable members opposite they reject it, undermine it, attack it and drag it down. They drag down any advance that is being attempted for women in our society. They come in here and pretend to do otherwise.

There is an exceptional group over there, members of which are known to the Parliament and to the people, such as the honourable member for Goldstein, and they have a good record on this issue. It seems to me that honourable members who oppose this legislation either fail to understand the concepts involved in affirmative action or they understand them very well but are completely dishonest when they say that they support equal opportunities for women. The Opposition has claimed that the title of the Bill is dishonest. I contend that those who oppose the Bill quite clearly are the ones who are dishonest. The reality is that affirmative action provides the means for remedying the pattern of the disadvantages experienced by women in the labour force. It is not only consistent with equal opportunity but is essential to its achievement.

For the purposes of the legislation, affirmative action involves the introduction by employers of positive programs which are designed to overcome the sometimes hidden and systematic discrimination found in apparently neutral employment practices as well as addressing the more obvious forms of discrimination faced by women. This is not a piece of social engineering. It will not impose unnecessary regulation on employers nor lead to greater inefficiencies. The very opposite is true, as thinking members of the Opposition know full well.

The Opposition will also move to amend the provisions relating to the trade union consultation and to lighten the so-called regulatory burdens imposed upon the employers. Those proposed amendments are completely at odds with the establishment of effective affirmative action programs. The regulation imposed upon employers could hardly be described as heavy-handed. Any further reduction would basically create a voluntary system which is, of course, exactly what the Opposition wants. Such a system is completely unacceptable to those on this side of the House. As for the proposal to exclude trade unions, what else would we expect? God, strike these people opposite would not know how to make a boss angry. Almost none of them has had to work on a factory floor. Those opposite would not know what it is like to work in a canning factory or a textile factory. Most honourable members opposite would not know what it is like to start work at 11 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would be very wrong there.
—I said `most'. Most honourable members opposite would not understand what it is like to work at home all day and to work in a factory at night.
—Nonsense.

—The honourable member would not know; so he should not say he does. He is privileged. Most honourable members opposite have had a privileged spoon-fed life. To say that the trade union movement of women should not be allowed to have these sorts of changes is a total outrage. Those opposite will be condemned at the ballot box for their performance in this House. They have engaged in two-faced, slick politics, and they do not even have the guts to say in their contributions that they will vote against it. They come in here mealy-mouthed and pander to a conservative electorate back at home. The women in those conservative electorates will vote against them because on this issue they are wrong and they will be proven to be wrong. Consistently in this place there is a feud over there. The feud is about conservatism versus progression in the Liberal Party. The honourable member for Goldstein and the people who support him will win because the people of Australia will keep us here in power for a very long time. The conservatives are trying to attack the leadership of the National Party. God help us-it is a measure of how bad things are going when they try to roll someone as conservative as that lot. The honourable member for Gippsland is destined, like Dad's Army that sits behind him, to grow old in opposition. He will be there for a long time. He will probably never move to this side of the House and he is 21 1/2 years of age now.

—It is indeed a sad day for this country when we find this bumbling Government bringing this sort of legislation into this Parliament. It is a sad day when the Government of Australia is not game to stand up and bring into Parliament the legislation it threatened this nation with such a short time ago in relation to affirmative action. We in the National Party of Australia are 100 per cent in favour of equal opportunity. No doubt our opponents will endeavour to suggest that our commitment to equal opportunity is less than complete. But that is incorrect. Indeed the most sexist party in Australia today is without doubt the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: We were elected to represent our constituents in the House of Representatives in the Federal Parliament. It is a tragedy that we are being asked to support bad legislation under the threat of being branded as being anti-women. It is outrageous legislation. We do not apologise for being in favour of-and I will repeat this over and over again-equal opportunity because we believe that in today's society it is the right of anyone, regardless of gender, to be able to seek and obtain a position on the basis of merit. We find that this legislation endeavours to say that we should discriminate in the cause of anti-discrimination.
Honourable members interjecting-

—It's a great speech.
—I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for his perceptive remark.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed to this legislation on a number of grounds. Firstly, it is constitutionally dubious. Secondly, affirmative action is reverse discrimination and incompatible with true equal opportunity. Thirdly, I am opposed to the cost to business and increased bureaucratic regulation which will result from the implementation of this legislation. It is of note that the Government is desperate to grasp every possible constitutional head to try to justify this legislation becoming part of the law of the Commonwealth. One has only to look at clause 5 of the legislation to find that the Government has gone from the corporations power right through to broadcasting. It has even hit upon the external affairs power. The Tasmanian dams case resulted in a win for the Commonwealth on the basis of a 4:3 majority in the High Court of Australia in regard to the external affairs power. With the current change in composition in the High Court-and the High Court, of course, changes in composition from time to time-it is by no means certain that a future High Court deciding a case on similar grounds would come to the same conclusion. So this Government has been grabbing at every straw in the wind to try to justify the basis of this legislation. The treaty power-the external affairs power-is contained in clause 5 (a). It states:

By virtue of this sub-section, this Act has the effect it would have to the extent that this Act is appropriate to give effect to, or carry out the purposes of, the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, a copy of the English text of which is set out in the Schedule to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

The people of Australia are sick and tired of this Government endeavouring to subvert the Constitution by signing an international convention and then crawling into this chamber to say that Australia must give effect to its international obligations. We believe that it is wrong to try to circumvent the Constitution by dubious means. It is quite wrong for the Commonwealth to expand its area of legislative power by signing conventions and then trying to use those conventions as the basis for taking legislative authority away from the States. So there is a question as to whether this Bill should be debated in this Parliament at all or whether it is a matter which is appropriate for discussion in the State parliaments of this country. It could well be, because of the extensive litigation which will no doubt result following the forcing of this Bill through the House and through the Senate, that it will be an expensive exercise for the people of Australia.

I am pleased and proud to be able to stand in this Parliament and join my National Party colleagues in opposition to this Bill. This legislation, in fact, initially affects universities as from 1 August this year. It affects businesses or corporations with more than 1,000 employees from 1 February 1987. It affects businesses with between 500 and 1,000 employees from 1 February 1988 and business with between 100 and 500 employees from 1 February 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where will it end?

—Who knows where it will end? The Confederation of Australian Industry has stated that it is opposed to small business being included. Small business is not included at this stage. But will it be next on the Government's hit list? Are the small businesses of Australia, which are presently languishing under the highest real interest rates in 50 years and which are going bankrupt at an unprecedented rate as a result of the disastrous policies of the Hawke Labor Government, to be the next on the Hawke Labor Party's hit list? What is going to happen next year and the year after? I believe that this legislation is simply the thin edge of the wedge.

Indeed, the people of Australia who are listening to this broadcast will no doubt realise that the National Party has, in the various parliaments throughout Australia, the greatest representation that it has ever had. We saw the cowardly and sordid attack today by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the Queensland Minister for Welfare Services, Youth and Ethnic Affairs, Mrs Yvonne Chapman. It is a sad day when a man comes in here and attacks a lady who is without doubt one of the best Ministers we have in Queensland. She is in fact the first woman ever to be appointed to the Queensland Cabinet from any party.
