SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House recognise the role of women. We do not knock women in the way the Australian Labor Party seems to in so many ways. We have in the National Party Senator Lady Bjelke-Petersen. She is a person who would not have an enemy in the world and who is making a tremendous contribution, not only to Queensland but indeed to the whole of Australia. I ask honourable members to contrast our attitude to Senator Flo with the attitude of the ALP to Dame Leonie Kramer, the lady who was in charge of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation until she was given the chop by Labor. Is that affirmative action on the part of the ALP? Is that the approach which it would have us believe it supports? The lady did a good job. She competed on an equal basis against the whole world, and the people who gave her the chop were in fact members of the ALP. It is a tragedy that that happened. The people of Australia recognise the tremendous contribution of Dame Leonie Kramer. I am certain that they will not forget the treatment she received at the hands of the Hawke Labor Government.

This legislation is opposed by wide sections of the Australian community. The Confederation of Australian Industry is opposed to it and, quite appropriately, has drawn our attention to the confusion under which the Government seems to labour. It gets mixed up between equality of opportunity and the goal of equality of outcome. The CAI has pointed out that it is opposed to the Government's legislative approach. The Country Women's Association of Australia is also against what the Government is trying to inflict upon the men and women of Australia. I wish to read into Hansard the text of a letter dated 20 February 1986 from Miss Dorothy D. Ross, National President of the CWA. She said:
My dear Prime Minister,

The Country Womens Association of Australia is concerned with all matters affecting the welfare of women and consequently has made an exhaustive study of the Affirmative Action Legislation. In the process we have consulted with both men and women in country and city areas in order to arrive at a balanced judgment. Members of the Country Women's Association from throughout Australia have considered the matter having been following the matter since the release of the discussion paper in May 1984 and Volume 2 in June 1984.

The Country Womens Association of Australia does not support the proposed Affirmative Action Legislation. Details of our objections and reactions to the proposals are set down in our submission. No legislation can alter attitudes and the dangers of efforts to enforce employment of women by private business with threats of punishment if the laws are infringed is seen by us to offer up more problems than the legislation can solve.

That is the attitude of the CWA. The Business Council of Australia is also opposed to the legislation. That very important group of women-members of the National Party Women's Section-are 100 per cent opposed to what the ALP is trying to impose upon the people of Australia. I mentioned the Confederation of Australian Industry has made its opposition clear. I quote from the CAI News of March 1986:

CAI has made clear at all times its unequivocal opposition to affirmative action legislation. Legislation of this nature is unnecessary and divisive, and in the long-term will be completely counter-productive. It will involve the imposition of further cost burdens and regulatory requirements on industry at a time when the inflation rate is double the level of that of our major trading partners, and when Australia has severe balance of payment difficulties, and excessively high interest rates and levels of unemployment.

The Government could well take note of what the CAI has said. The Government should note that inflation in this country is not coming down the way it has in other places. The Government should take note of the bankruptcies which are being forced on business in Australia, and it should change its policies. But what does it do? It crawls into this Parliament with yet another Bill which involves not less regulation but more regulation of business and more costs. Businesses will now have to report to a person called the Director of Affirmative Action. We are told that it will cost $1.5m in the first 12 months to run the office of the Director and 25 people will be employed initially. We all know how the bureaucracy tends to grow and grow and grow. The people of Australia will note what the Government is doing in this regard.

What will happen if the companies in this country refuse to go along with what the Government is suggesting? They will be named in the Parliament. We will have shades of McCarthyism. The Government will come into this Parliament and it will name those people who refuse to go along with what it is advocating. There will have to be more consultation with the trade union movement. What we should be talking about is the right of a person to join or not to join a trade union, but the Government is enshrining yet again into legislation the obligation to consult trade unions.

We in the National Party are strongly in favour of equal opportunity. We remain strongly in favour of equal opportunity, but this Government seems to have a down on those women who have made a contribution to Australia, those women who chose to remain in the home and raise their families. We believe that a woman should have the right, if she wants to, to stay in the home or, if she wants to go to work, she should also have that right. Margaret Thatcher, who if she lived in Australia would be a member of the National Party, recognised the role of women in the home. She stated:
Any woman who understands the problems of running a home will be nearer to understanding the problems of running a country.
We know the tremendous amount of good Mrs Thatcher has done in the United Kingdom and we should recognise this fact once and for all.

We have been elected to represent the people of Australia. This legislation is garbage legislation; it is rubbish legislation. It fails to achieve its aim of equal opportunity and it should be consigned to the scrap heap. I have no hesitation in joining my National Party colleagues in opposing this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a brilliant exposition of the kind of moronic objection that any type of legislation of this sort will attract from the people from the side of politics of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). We heard that women ought to have the right to stay at home, as if this legislation involved any elimination or reduction of that right. Really, what this legislation seeks to do is to remove-
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I object to the honourable member for Sydney calling the honourable member for Fisher a moron and I ask that the remark be withdrawn.
—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I did not refer to the speaker as being a moron. I referred to the remark as being moronic, and there is a distinction.
—I think that there is offence taken on the other side of the House. I would ask the honourable member for Sydney to withdraw it.

—I withdraw. This legislation really seeks to remove the impediments to women taking their proper place in the work force and having the same access to employment opportunities as men have. It does not make any statement about whether or not women should stay in the home. It was the honourable member for Fisher who made the statement that existing impediments to women's advance in the work force ought to remain and, therefore he is the one who is seeking to place an impost on women. The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill is a continuation of the Government's commitment to equal employment opportunity for women. It follows on from the Sex Discrimination Act, which was introduced in 1984 and did not include affirmative action provisions. That was quite deliberate at the time in the sense that it was felt desirable that the maximum possible consultative process should be gone through before this legislation was adopted. Since that time we have had the operation of a pilot program and a most extensive consultative process. I do not think anybody could object to the processes which have been adopted in order to introduce this legislation and the processes leading up to its being placed before the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of concerns have been expressed about the legislation. Far from it being seen as some kind of draconian attack on the family, there has been quite cogent criticism of the legislation coming from such women's groups as the National Women's Consultative Council, and also from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which feels that the Bill has not gone far enough. It cites a number of aspects where it thinks the Bill could go further, and I mention three. Firstly, it believes that the Bill ought to cover private companies with fewer than 100 people. Secondly, it believes that the penalty provisions ought to be somewhat tighter. As things stand, really the only sanction is the possibility of being named in Parliament. Thirdly, some concern has been expressed by the organisations to which I have referred about the length of time for first reports from private companies. For example, companies with between 100 and 499 employees do not have to produce their first reports until 1 February 1989. So in fact a number of objections have been expressed by organisations representing women on the basis that in some respects the legislation lacks teeth.

I believe that this Bill is a step in the right direction, and the sort of processes that have been followed in the formulation and development of the legislation, particularly the consultative processes, have been very good. The object of the Bill is to assist able women to have real opportunities in the pursuit of their employment and careers. The Green Paper, and I refer to Volume 1, page 3, defines affirmative action for women in employment as follows:

A systematic means, determined by the employer in consultation with senior management, employees and unions of ensuring the achieving of equal employment opportunity for women. Affirmative action is compatible with appointment and promotion on the basis of merit, skills and qualifications.

I think the reference to the merit principle is worth emphasising. It is simply not the case that this legislation seeks to place women in positions for which they patently might not be qualified. The legislation does not constitute discrimination against men or discrimination in favour of women. What the Bill does have as its underlying principle is a recognition that women have been and currently are discriminated against in their employment and that methodical, deliberate and positive steps need to be encompassed in legislation in order to redress this unacceptable situation.

The Bill recognises that women are disadvantaged in the work force because in Australian society they are, firstly, differently educated from men, generally to their detriment in employment; secondly, the child bearers and, almost invariably, the child rearers of the family; thirdly, the ones who carry the major burden of family responsibility, whether or not they are in paid employment; and, finally, are less likely than their male counterparts to be promoted to managerial positions. The Bill attempts to ensure that these factors are taken into account by employers rather than being used against women. Where possible, and in a gradual manner, work place programs and practices would be altered to accommodate women's situations. For example, where women leave the paid work force to have children, this period would be recognised by the employer as being valuable and therefore credited to her work history rather than being seen as time out from constructive labour. Surely the educational, planning and managerial skills that are strictly necessary for the successful running of a home and the rearing of children should be acknowledged by employers, because these skills are certainly to their advantage.

In relation to this issue, specifically as so many women and their organisations constantly point out, women cannot possibly have equal employment opportunity and affirmative action without readily available, good quality and flexible child care. The Government is working actively on this and is making excellent progress towards its goal of 20,000 more child care places by 1988. This Bill, quite rightly, is not about quotas, because they have been proven in the United States and elsewhere to be counterproductive in that they sometimes mean that unsuitable, inappropriately or inadequately skilled people are appointed to positions simply to satisfy quotas. Generally, this was to the disadvantage of both the employer and the employee. However, the Bill is about realistic goals and objectives which will be set by the employer in consultation with management, employees and appropriate unions. I think it is worth emphasising the point about quotas. Certainly, when the matter was discussed a few years back within the Australian Labor Party-I can recall the National Conference in 1981, which carried a resolution favouring the introduction of affirmative action-we saw the adoption of a program that talked about making available to a woman one safe seat in each State per parliamentary term. A few of the advocates of affirmative action in the parliamentary party turned distinctly pale at that suggestion and, as things turned out, nothing further has been heard of it.

Quotas have the effect of devaluing the positions that women obtain on the basis of merit and, far from establishing desirable role models, they tend to create a situation where positions which might have been obtained by women on the basis of merit are devalued and the view is taken that those positions were not legitimately obtained. I think quotas would be directly counterproductive. This legislation seeks something rather different from that situation. It seeks to adopt positive programs that will have the effect of removing the impediments to women's advance in the work force. As such, I think it is perfectly reasonable legislation, and the screeching we have heard from the ultra-conservative section of the Opposition needs to be dismissed with the contempt it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not affirmative action in terms of the 1981 Sex Discrimination Bill of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). That provided for affirmative action in both public and private employment and was favoured by Article 4 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. The United Nations Convention talks about temporary measures aimed at accelerating de facto equality between men and women not being considered discrimination; that is, actual discrimination against men should not be regarded as such. The Government sensibly dropped the affirmative action proposals from its 1983 Sex Discrimination Bill. The Government's Green Paper outlining the need for affirmative action was then issued as a prelude to public debate and the introduction of the legislation now before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be remembered that it is the strongly held position of private sector companies, including the 28 companies in the Government's much-publicised pilot program, that legislation is unnecessary. It should also be recognised that the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill now before the House can only touch a minority of the work force in the private sector. Sixty per cent of employees in the private sector, of course, work in businesses which have fewer than 100 employees. These businesses are the backbone of the nation. The 28 companies participating in the Government's pilot program made a joint submission to the Representative Working Party on Affirmative Action Legislation in which they said:

We believe that a voluntary self-managed approach for business is a practical and viable alternative to legislation. We believe there are a number of advantages in the Government showing strong support at this stage for the voluntary approach. Such an approach would be widely accepted by the Australian community. It would be consistent with government policy on deregulation and it would create a positive environment for women in the promotion of equal opportunity ideals.

The advantages seen by the companies in continuing with a voluntary, self-managed approach included: It would be more appropriate to the current economic climate. A voluntary program would be more acceptable to the electorate and some union members at a time of high unemployment. A voluntary program would be cost effective. It would not require a bureaucratic enforcement process, nor would it impose rigid and inappropriate demands in particular circumstances.

I should like to contrast these views with those expressed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in a series of motions which were passed at a Special Unions Conference on Affirmative Action in October 1984. These included:

That in the event that a company involved in the Government's affirmative action pilot project fails to properly consult with the appropriate unions on that company's program, the ACTU will assist those affiliates involved to mount a campaign to ensure that adequate consultation occurs.

That the ACTU and its affiliates as part of their involvement in the Government's affirmative action pilot project, give priority to the unionisation of those work places covered by the project where eligible employees are not members of the appropriate union.

The ACTU, in its submission to the Working Party on Affirmative Action, said it saw affirmative action as an industrial relations issue. The ACTU sought, and has been granted through this legislation, the ACTU's requirement that compulsory consultation with unions by employers be embedded in the Bill now before the House. It is akin to the head of John the Baptist being handed to the ACTU on a plate! The very organisation which sees affirmative action as an industrial relations issue, which demands that employers consult with unions on this issue, will frequently find itself locked in consultation with itself. And why? Because women in the union movement are notable by their absence from the top levels of the union movement in Australia.

Australia's wage fixing system has been developed, since 1906, on concepts put forward by a male dominated trade union movement, and assumptions that the full time male breadwinner had a dependent female and children, and should receive an adequate wage. Australia should be looking to a more flexible approach of setting wages and conditions, with the objective of accommodating the aspirations, and often the dual roles, of women in the work force. All too often the conditions of work are set with a nine to five, five days a week mentality, whereas a more flexible and practical rearrangement of hours and conditions could make women's lives easier, more satisfactory, and provide much greater job opportunities. For instance, the application of a basic hourly rate would assist women to gain either part time or full time employment.

I am pleased to see that the Bill makes it categorically apparent that the employers have the right to make jobs available on the basis of merit. This important criteria is contained in the legislation and set out quite clearly in Clause 3 (4), and I quote:
Nothing in this Act shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.

It is interesting to note that the Women's Electoral Lobby has stated that it sees 10 dominant issues in 1986, starting with affirmative action. WEL's list of priorities ranges across issues as diverse as equal pay for work of equal value, child care availability, legalised abortion in all States and a Bill of Rights. Last on the shopping list is education opportunities for women, including technical and computer courses for girls in schools.

This list of issues is, of course, upside down. In my opinion, the creation of education opportunities for females is the major challenge, not only for this Government but for all governments. If women are to enter and compete in the labour market on an equal footing with men, they must be educationally equipped. They must be prepared for the roles envisaged by this piece of legislation. The business community wants to employ the best people for particular jobs. That usually means people with the best skills. It does not matter what sex they are; it does not matter what their ethnic origin is. What is important is that Australia uses its human resources to the greatest effect in order to maximise its economic and social potential.

Adequate education for females, the right education, must therefore be the foundation on which any equal opportunity program for women is built. Without an affirmative education program for females, all the rhetoric about women making up 40 per cent of our work force, but holding only 2.5 per cent of the administrative, executive and managerial positions, will come to nought. Helen Hughes in the 1985 Boyer Lectures identified this educational problem and brought it sharply into focus when she said:

The training of women is dominated by outdated attitudes. They are not entering highly paid trades such as plumbing or electronics in significant numbers. It is rare to see a female crane driver or commercial pilot. The Air Force has difficulty in recruiting women for its electronic maintenance needs.

In tertiary education women still enter predominantly women's occupations such as nursing and teaching, and they are not well represented in engineering, economics or graduate studies. A large part of the Australian education system still encourages girls to opt for second class citizenship. They do not take their career prospects seriously. Many are still afraid of appearing to be `too clever'. Schools are not doing enough to prepare girls and boys for a society of equals.

Most Australian girls now in school are going to spend 40 years or more in the paid work force. They need training for the same occupations as boys. If they miss out on education while at school their work will be largely in `women's' occupations, earning less than men of equal ability.

The equal employment opportunities Bill, introduced to overcome so-called discrimination in the work force, will not in fact affect the availability of jobs. That is determined by the distribution of job opportunities throughout the community. The availability of jobs for women is the main deterrent for women seeking jobs. For instance, there has been a reduction in the number of jobs in the traditional female dominated areas of clerical, administration and retailing, by the introduction of new technology such as computers, word processor and photocopying equipment. Nor will this Bill lead to a large number of females in the work force realising their full potential. That will only be achieved when governments in Australia-both Federal and State-acknowledge that the doors to greater job opportunities for 40 per cent of Australia's work force cannot be opened fully until the wage fixing system is freed up and a full range of educational opportunities created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to go over again the details of the legislation as referred to by many previous speakers. Rather, I feel that it is necessary to give an indication of the reasons that this legislation is necessary, in view of the negative comments and attitudes expressed by members of the Opposition in relation to the need for and effects of affirmative action legislation. In brief, affirmative action is necessary because women are still extensively oppressed and discriminated against in our community. The aim of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill is to provide encouragement to employers by means of mild legislation-and I stress that it is mild-to employ women in more representative numbers in senior middle level positions rather than allowing the process to take its so-called natural course. It is felt that this so-called natural course would be far too slow. The argument one often hears against affirmative action is that women should continue to wait and that over time they will be occupying senior positions in proportionate numbers. The question is, however: How much longer do they have to wait? One estimate is that, without programs such as the one we are discussing, it would take another 200 years for women to achieve full equality with men in the work force. At the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference held in Canberra in May 1984, Leoni Still and Jennifer Jones claimed that anti-discrimination and equal employment opportunity policies had made very little difference to the position of women in the labour force, especially in relation to management positions and that if present trends continued without further action the year of equality would be 2180! The Government believes that is not good enough. Numerous studies of employment statistics in this country have demonstrated that, despite women possessing equal skills and qualifications, in the majority of cases they are not able to reach levels equivalent to male employees, in private enterprise as well as in Public Service and educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: A Sydney academic, Dr Gabriel Moens, has written a book entitled Affirmative Action-The New Discrimination. In it he says that, if concerns for the rights of minority groups and women is carried too far, affirmative action could lead to reverse discrimination, that is, discrimination against males. We have heard that kind of prejudicial comment made in this House over and over again, but the fact is that that is not the case and it does not apply to this legislation. Unfortunately, however, there have already been intimations within the Public Service of a male backlash, and that has been due to a lack of understanding of the aims of the affirmative action philosophy. It is not intended to give women-and nor do women want it-any unfair advantage. The intention of programs such as affirmative action is rather to remove the structural barriers which exist and which discriminate against women achieving any greater representation in the upper levels of bureaucracy and industry. (Quorum formed)

Before that nonsensical quorum was called I was making the point that, without affirmative action legislation, it would take 200 years for women to achieve equality in the work force; that is the reason that this legislation is absolutely essential. Jane Elix, the national Co-ordinator of the Women's Electoral Lobby, said:

Affirmative action is making sure that the merit principle is held to-that the person who is the most qualified for the job gets it . . . they are not going to promote women over the head of men who are more qualified. All it means is the removal of barriers to equal employment opportunities. It is not going to mean that men are going to be losing their jobs and women are going to be taking over.

This, of course, is contrary to the foolish comments of honourable members opposite. As I have said before, there are various forces which act against women in achieving their full employment potential, beginning with the educational system, which has been shown to militate against equality for girls and culminating in the structural factors within the work environment. The Government is taking steps to alleviate these disincentives within the education system by means of the participation and equity program being implemented by the Commonwealth Department of Education and the development by the Commonwealth Schools Commission of a national policy on education for girls. Further, there is the problem of breaks in continuity of employment due to child rearing acting against seniority and promotional opportunities. It has been suggested that there is a need to do here what is done in some other countries in relation to credit for years of service, whereby the years taken off from employment for child rearing are counted as equivalent years of service experience. Our failure to do this is an indication of our society's undervaluing of women's skills. The skills required for managing a household should be taken into account in considering a person's total experience. Obviously other factors operate to deter or delay women continuing to contribute and to utilise their academic and vocational training. One of the factors involved is that the time that women spend away from the work force for child rearing purposes delays their careers and in some cases completely deflects them from those careers. As a nation we cannot afford to allow half the population, in whom a considerable economic investment has been made in terms of education, to waste their skills.

Of course, some women prefer to remain out of the work force for family support reasons, and it is their right to choose to do this. However, those who do not wish to follow that course of action must not be deterred, as they have been, by the existing employment circumstances. To a large extent, allegations of unreliability due to absenteeism by women can be attributed to the lack of provision of universally available child care facilities. The Labor Government has made a commitment to provide 20,000 new child care places in subsidised centres throughout Australia by 1988. But this will still mean that less than 10 per cent of children under five years of age in this country will have access to full day child care. We must recognise that in 1983 an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey found that 37 per cent of females who wanted to work would have done so had adequate child care facilities been available.

Further, we must recognise that this country cannot afford to underutilise the intellectual and vocational capacity of 51 per cent of its population. In the affirmative action discussions that have taken place I note that consideration has been given to work based child care as a partial solution to this problem of impending heavy expenditure by governments for child care places. However, I point out that surveys that have been carried out on this matter have indicated that the majority of women-and parents-still have a preference for child care centres to be located near their homes rather than near their places of employment. I feel it cannot be stressed too often that the provision of child care facilities by government is absolutely fundamental to any program of the kind we are discussing. It is a waste of time establishing any such program if the matter of child care is not taken into consideration and given due prominence in rearrangement of the working conditions which women face. The Age editorial of 22 February, referring to this legislation, stated:

The legislation is admirable. However, it would make more sense if it was also accompanied by a more effective and extensive child care program. There is not much sense in asserting the right of women to enter or work their way up in the workforce if their family responsibilities prevent them from exercising that right.

I therefore support the extension of child care as a very important part of achieving the goals of this legislation. These are some of the structural barriers against women: Firstly, a system based on seniority rather than merit; secondly, a system which relies on continuity of service as an indication of performance and capacity to achieve; thirdly, a system within which until only 20 years ago, for example in the Commonwealth Public Service, it was required of women to resign after marrying and to convert a permanent position into a temporary position if they wished to continue their employment; fourthly, a system which did not, until recently, recognise the need for adequate child care.

That structural barriers against women do exist can be extrapolated from the discrepancy between the academic performance of women at secondary and tertiary levels and the final result which they achieve within their employment. For example, in 1983 females represented 41 per cent of law students. However, the percentage of lawyers who are women is only 11.4 per cent. Some 42 per cent of students of medicine were women but only 17.6 per cent of medical practitioners are females. Within the work environment factors such as selection procedures need to be altered. It is not sufficient simply to have one woman on each selection panel, even though this minimum requirement is often very hard to achieve in itself. This can be held to be tokenism. There is a need to achieve attitudinal change in order to avoid this situation, often the only concession to affirmative action. It is often said: `Okay, we have a women on the panel in a middle management position-on the board of directors or in Cabinet-therefore, we do not need to have any more. We have made our gesture'. There is a need for ongoing monitoring of the situation and for going beyond sheer tokenism.

I commend the Victorian Government's approach. In order to overcome the lack of applications from women for important positions the Government of Victoria and the Premier, Mr Cain, have developed an action plan wherein names of women considered suitable for senior positions are provided to departmental heads. Mr Cain has said that a big problem in moving women into new Public Service positions is that in 34 per cent of advertised positions there are no women applicants. The Victorian Government now has a register of the names of 1,500 female public servants held on computer at the Equal Opportunity Unit of the Public Service Board to provide potential candidates for senior positions. It believes, not that there is discernible bias against women at the interview stage but that the problem was obtaining applications from them. Under the new system, if there are no women applicants for a position the head of a department can invite women on the register to apply. The action plan for women in the Victorian Public Service, since its establishment in July last year, has resulted in a increase in the numbers of women in senior executive positions from 5 per cent in 1983 to 13.5 per cent in 1985. In the coming year the action plan will be extended to the full public sector to overcome the lack of representation of women on Government boards and authorities. The Victorian Government sets the example for all governments in this country in its implementation of affirmative action for women.

Permanent part time employment provisions such as those affecting Commonwealth public servants, which are in the final stages of legislation at present, will be of great benefit to women. I commend them. In November 1984 79.8 per cent of all part time workers were women. To date part time employees-most of them women-have been most seriously hampered by the non-availability of superannuation, the lack of workers compensation cover and the loss of promotional opportunities due to breaks in service. Part time workers so far have not had access or entitlement to study leave or participation in management training programs. Peter Wilenski, the Chairman of the Public Service Board, is reported as saying of this program in the Australian Financial Review of 22 January:

In discussions of this program, distinctions must be drawn between targets and quotas. This legislation does not require the imposition of quotas, which are mandatory, and require selection of a certain number of people from a particular group regardless of merit.

Targets are an estimate of the number that might be selected if barriers are removed and positive steps such as recruitment and training programs are undertaken. Selection for each job . . . continues to be based on the relative merit of the applicants.
In speaking of the opponents to legislation of this kind, Peter Wilenski also felt it necessary to say:

It is relevant to ask why these new found defenders of non-discrimination remained silent during years of massive discrimination against women and disadvantaged groups in the workforce. This discrimination (now often of a more subtle and systematic nature) still remains a major barrier to efficiency and equity in Australian workplaces.

This is the question that needs to be asked of members of the Liberal and National parties who have made speeches here today and said: `We are really in favour of equal opportunity for women. We don't really want discrimination, but this Bill is discriminatory'. I ask them where they were for the many years when they were in government. Why did they not do anything to help promote opportunities for women in these areas? They now sit in this House and pretend that they believe in equal opportunities for women. What a nonsense. Those honourable members who have spoken against this legislation are full of hypocrisy in their claims that they believe in equal opportunity. As soon as we introduce anything in an attempt to achieve these goals they are totally opposed to it.

The response by participating organisations in the working party on affirmative action legislation in general has been favourable. In fact, the Australian Council of Trade Unions stated that the legislative proposals were not as strong as it had advocated. Did honourable members opposite hear that? It said that they were not as strong as it had advocated. It considers that all employers should be covered by the legislation and that a range of sanctions and penalties should apply to employers failing to comply with the legislation. The ACTU welcomed the Government's legislative proposals as an important step towards the achievement of equal opportunity employment for women, but it certainly did not get its own way as claimed by the many speakers in this debate from the National Party. Even the Business Council of Australia stated:
. . . equal employment opportunity for women is a social change issue critical for Australia's future growth and well being.

It identified the need for critical steps to be taken to reassess and upgrade the status of women in business and to eliminate obstacles and influence attitudes which had in the past limited their opportunities. Overall the Government's initiative in establishing this program was welcomed by the Business Council. In academic areas, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee supported the legislative proposals and recommended that all universities be covered by Commonwealth legislation. The Australian Committee of Directors and Principals of Advanced Education agrees with these views, as do other education bodies.

I repeat my opening remarks: Affirmative action legislation is necessary. It is necessary because women are underrepresented in the middle and higher levels of bureaucracy, industry and management. The United Nations Decade for Women is now over, but this should not mean that women no longer need to be given equal employment opportunities and it is no reason for men to think that women will stop demanding them. The legislation goes some way towards redressing these inequities in the social system and employment environment which prevail in this country. I strongly support this legislation and urge the House to do so.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Every woman in Australia needs to know that the Government thinks so little of affirmative action that it has just voted to close the debate. The total hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party is such that it has neither the wit nor the capacity to perform. Government members have all the will to try to pretend that they believe in the causes they affect, yet not one word of what they say is worth two bob. The Labor Party is so retrograde in its attitudes, so backward in its views, and so inadequate in its expression of them, that it has brought into the House legislation which it regards as a symbolic measure but which means nought. The Government has come in here with a bode of ill will which is designed not to advance the cause of women in our community, but to pretend that there are a few women in this community who really have been working hard in order to establish their place in society. The Labor Party in government could not give two bob about them. If the Government is prepared to close the debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, it really does not have either the wit or capacity to pretend to get the support of even that 50 per cent of our population whom all on this side of the House not only regard highly but also believe participate more than equally in everything that goes on. The first amendment stands in the name of the Opposition spokesman on this matter, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 1, page 1, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Short title
``1. This Act may be cited as the Equal Opportunity in Employment Act 1986.''.

This amendment is designed to ensure that those who for the time being, albeit briefly, are in government accept the fact that this is not an affirmative action Bill, nor is it a Bill designed to implement anything like equal opportunity; it is designed to pretend that the Labor Party at last cares. Government members have gone out wearing their hearts on their sleeves and have neither delivered nor performed. It is about time that they lifted their game and started to perform instead of pretending.

I suggest that in the title we should delete the words `Affirmative Action' so that the pseudonym of the Bill will be the Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill 1986. We might then get a little closer to the realities. This piece of legislation should never have been introduced into the Parliament, not because we do not believe in the cause but because the Bill does not even pretend to implement that cause. We on this side of the House believe that the cause can be achieved properly if people are honest and genuine in representing women in this place. Unfortunately, the Labor Party does not accept the idiocy. What it calls the affirmative action Bill is a Bill which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said would be inadequate. The Government presented this Bill only because it was unable to have what it wanted accepted by Caucus and the Parliament. The only way in which we can impose reality in this situation is to delete `Affirmative Action' and replace it with the new title of Equal Opportunity in Employment Act 1986. I suggest that is more what this Bill seeks to achieve.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said in the debate earlier today, if this objective had been achieved by voluntary means, without the obligations that regulations impose, we would all be a lot better off. Far too many costs are imposed by the sorts of measures this Government wants to take. We have to look only at the farmers, small businesses and home owners in this community to realise what the Labor Party is imposing on them. It is about time the Government started to deliver instead of talking about it. The least we can do is to modify what is supposed to be an affirmative action program to something that is a little more symbolic of what it is supposed to be. I do not believe that the Bill is necessary or that it will promote equality between the sexes, but let us at least call it what it pretends to be-the Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill 1986.

-Order! I draw the attention of honourable members to the Standing Orders, which indicate clearly that honourable members are entitled to be heard in silence. For an example of where affirmative action is needed, let us look at the universities. It always amazes me that the media pick up just one speech.
