The Chair is inclined to accept that the honourable member for Denison was using those terms, together with the term `hypocritical', which is coming into increasing use, in a rhetorical sense. However, I would urge him to express himself, as he is well able to do, in parliamentary language.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I am grateful. The point has hit home. The strongest argument against this clause is the argument that the title is a deliberate fraud and misrepresentation.

SPEECH.PARA: People ought to know that we are not permitted, during the Committee stage, to speak on the whole ambit of the Bill. I certainly do not intend to rise on every single clause. However, 22 members of Her Majesty's loyal Opposition wanted to speak on this Bill to put views both for and against its varying provisions. Because we cannot, I conclude by supporting the amendment proposed to clause 1. The Bill is a fraud. It does not achieve the purpose for which it was brought into this place and which the Government said it would achieve. It will further regulate employment in this country, it will add costs to industry and it will keep thousands and thousands of decent women out of the work force. It is totally counterproductive and fraudulent legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Committee with a great deal of enthusiasm which is stimulated by my deep inherent respect for women. I do not want women changed. The people opposite have over the years exploited certain sections of the community to their own political advantage. Whether we call the legislation before us the opportunity in employment Bill or whether we call it the affirmative action Bill, the motives of members of the Australian Labor Party are similar to those they have demonstrated in the past. First of all it was Aboriginals. I can remember sitting at the table on duty as a shadow Minister and listening to the the then Leader of the House, still a very well-known figure who is in public life, saying at 2 o'clock in the morning when someone got up to speak on some Aboriginal Bill or other: `Oh, bugger me. There is not a vote left in the bastards'. They are the words that were used.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party then exploited pensioners. However, pensioners did not fall for that because they remember that during the Great Depression of the early 1930s-I admit that another one is looming-the Labor Party reduced the pension. So honourable members can see that the Labor Party has used pensioners as well. Now it is the turn of our womenfolk and so-called equal opportunity. My purpose in addressing the Committee is to point out what will happen as a result of the greater incentive for women to get into the work force. God bless women. I think we began the whole operation to recognise women, their rights and their status. The person on my left, the Serjeant-at-Arms, Lyn Simons, is the greatest proof of all. I do not think there is a person in the House who could disapprove for one moment of the fact that our Serjeant-at-Arms and our Speaker are women. I say-and the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) stated this so well during the debate this afternoon-that if the family is to be put at risk we should forget this legislation. If opportunities are going to be created and if women are to be suitably employed in suitable occupations well and good.

Some honourable members opposite-and I hate to use this word-are so totally hypocritical. I do not refer to all of them because there are some nice blokes on the other side of the chamber. I am referring to the people who make the decisions. They sacked Dame Leonie Kramer. All Australians know that she was not only a national figure who demanded the focus of respect throughout this nation but also a person who was internationally respected. What did they do? They appointed a deputy chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation whose name was Wendy. I am too much of a gentleman to expose again to the Committee this lady's most infamous claim to fame. Let us forget that because I am too much of a gentleman. However, I say to you, Mr Deputy Chairman, to honourable members and to the people of the nation that this country is continuing to slide to the status of a banana republic. If we examine the operations of this Government we will see how standards are being destroyed. The one big danger in all of this is that the attraction for people to abandon the family will be so great that women will lose their God-given gift-that is to be a feminine person, to be lovable and to take their place in the home and not be a chattel. Honourable members opposite will play that up. They will ask: `What does Katter want? He wants a woman in the house to be a chattel'. Regrettably I lost my first wife and I married again. My wives have been anything but chattels. They have been pretty good captains of the ship most of the time. Let me reiterate: Whatever the motives of this Bill may be, and they are quite hypocritical, they infringe on two things, as does the Bill of Rights. They infringe upon free enterprise, they upset the whole basic balance of business and they could destroy the family. Destroy the family and the nation is destroyed. Honourable members should think about that. That is what occupies the minds and hearts of my Party the National Party, and the Liberal Party. We constantly think of the basic security of the nation, which is based on the family.

After all, 50 per cent of the members of the work force are women. I wonder how this great necessity for change has come about. This Bill is purely hypocritical. It is purely an attempt to exploit another section of the community. The Aboriginal issue was used until there was nothing left; as one former member said, there was not a vote left in the bastards. The pensioners were then exploited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That comment came from a former Leader of the House.
—Order! The honourable member is fast losing relevance. I remind him that we are talking about the specific question of the short title of the Bill.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, if I am losing relevance I think I have said all that I have to say. I respect the Chair and I conclude on that note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Millar, as you rightly pointed out, we are tending to get away from the substance of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. I believe it is important to come back to what I think is one of the central points, and that is that the affirmative action program is to be based on merit, not on quotas or targets handed down by regulatory bodies. It is rather important that that point be looked at in a great deal of detail because, quite frankly, the notion of merit, which is, as I said, central to the Bill, encourages a reappraisal of how that merit should be addressed in terms of job suitability.

SPEECH.PARA: If one talks to many of the women who are participating in the work force at present and to many of those who would like to do so, one finds that they are vitally concerned with how job suitability is considered and how, when they go for jobs, they are examined in terms of suitability. Let us take the case of women who for one reason or another leave the work force, be it to have children or whatever, and come back to work. Often very little consideration is given to how effective those women have been in their other lives and to the training they may have picked up during their time away from a specific job category.

It has often been said-I think some people during this debate have also said it-that even a home environment offers a learning experience and certain qualities and characteristics can be brought back to a specific employment area because of that time away from that area. Indeed, many women take the opportunity when they are out of the specific work force to improve qualifications and to go on to higher learning. Many have taken the opportunity to enter universities as mature-age students.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the university at Wollongong.

—At the University of Wollongong, as my colleague the honourable member for Throsby indicates. They go to improve their qualifications, not because they are somehow inferior but because they want to be treated as equals. They want to be seen by their peers as having particular relevance to the life-style that they wish to embrace. There is no competition with males. We have long gone past that. What we are talking about in this case is affirmative action to ensure that women are given a fair go. I know that that is an appropriate term, given that the Government is publicising this matter widely. This legislation will give them a fair go. Dr Peter Wilenski has commented on a number of question associated with merit. He has been quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Merit has become an important tool of those in power for maintaining the status quo.
He has gone on to say:
Standards of merit, either deliberately or unconsciously, often were based on the values, style and priorities of the dominant male groups in the organisation.
Sadly, that is true. The point was made very succinctly by Hester Eisenstein, Assistant Director of Equal Opportunity in Public Employment in New South Wales, when she said employers must:
. . . cease the practice of discounting women's achievements, or of thinking (and saying) `but a woman couldn't stand the pressure' or `but a woman wouldn't fit in with this group of employees'.
Quite frankly, that practice is absolute nonsense. Prior to becoming a member of parliament, as I have said on a number of occasions, I was working in the New South Wales Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —A distinguished career.

—A distinguished career, indeed, over nine long years. The person to whom I reported directly in the organisational structure of the Public Service was a woman. I did not regard her with any form of animosity, nor did I think that she was in any way superior. She was an equal and she treated me in the same way. It just so happened that in the structure she had a position that required her to have supervisory capacities, and she performed her tasks with great aplomb. I am pleased to say that the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning is probably one of the greatest adherers to the concept of equal employment opportunity in the whole of the New South Wales Public Service; at least it certainly was in the nine years when I was working for that organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that, while women are still more likely than men to leave the work force for a few years, on re-entering the work place they are often penalised for gaps in their employment and no credit is given for the skills acquired by them during that time. Employer prejudice is evident in statements such as that women employees are more committed to their families than to their jobs, that they will leave when they marry or when they have children and that there is a higher staff turnover with women. That any of those claims are accurate is likely to be a reflection of the poor conditions and prospects experienced by women in the work place. How true it is that for so long in so many organisations, women have not been able to progress through organisations and seek the levels that they more properly should attain. On talking to many of these women one finds that all they are seeking is to be treated with equality. They are looking for the opportunity to be judged on merit. If they go for positions in the work force, they wish to be examined by selection panels and judged on merit. They do not want simply to get a couple of extra brownie points because they are women or, conversely, to get marked down some brownie points because they are women. They are looking, in fact, for equality. This Bill will go a great deal of the way towards ensuring that this will happen.

This Government is also concerned-this was pointed out in a number of speeches from honourable members on this side of the House this afternoon, not least of which was the contribution from the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous)-about the supply side of the equation and it is actively promoting the education of women for jobs in non-traditional areas. I think that is rather important, because for too long we have tended to categories women as being appropriate for certain jobs. Whilst they have eminent qualifications for those jobs they have not been given opportunities in other areas. The Commonwealth Schools Commission, to its credit, aims to develop a number of educational measures, such as a national policy on the education of girls, the Girls into Engineering project, an equal distribution of traineeships, the reduction of occupational sex segregation in traineeships and, finally, the collection of data on the outcome of girls' education.

The existing participation and equity program has already gone some of the way along this road. Of course, the community employment program has also given women training for a broad range of non-traditional jobs. Very recently, I had the opportunity to tour around my electorate looking at some of these CEP projects which, I am sure, are near and dear to the hearts of those who sit on the National Party benches. It was with a great deal of pleasure that I had the opportunity to talk to a number of people in jobs provided under CEP projects. It was quite surprising to see the number of women who were participating in non-traditional roles. A number of women were employed on the construction of a cycle way in Camden, which the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is coming to open next week. While I was talking to them they said they absolutely loved the job because it gave them the opportunity to be outside and to participate in something somewhat different from the traditional role. Yet these people were just normal, everyday women with families who, unfortunately, were at the wrong end of the employment scale. They were getting a great deal of benefit from the opportunities presented to them.

In conclusion, this Bill before us does not so much dictate what must be done by companies; rather, it says that they must consider the issue, set targets which they deem suitable and appropriate and then report to the Government annually on how they are going in relation to those targets. I see absolutely nothing wrong with that. To use the argument of efficiency, at least this approach can only maximise the use of the talent available for all given positions rather than subconsciously restricting the pool of suitable applicants by defining `suitable' in terms of what has been done before. I think that is a very important point.

Too often people going for positions in the work force, particularly women, are assessed on what happened before. There is no going beyond that to look at other skills that might be brought into an organisation. I believe that this legislation goes part of the way towards repairing that position. I believe that the whole question of merit is central to this issue and is one that should not be glossed over or treated glibly, or indeed criticised because it is seen as being something which it is not. I certainly commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Opposition's amendment, which seeks to change the name of this Bill to the Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill. I think this matter of changing the name of the Bill is important. By changing the name, instead of having a description which, as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) pointed out, is grossly misleading, the Bill will have an honest description. Some time ago the Government spoke about the need for so-called affirmative action programs, and I refer particularly to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan), who made it perfectly clear that her understanding of affirmative action and what the Government was about was to introduce a system of quotas and a system of positive discrimination. As a result of a great deal of pressure from the Opposition, from the business community, and indeed from all over Australia, the Government has had to make an ignominious retreat from its original intentions. In other words, the Government has caved in to the pressure of the Opposition in terms of its original and quite unconstructive proposals. Those proposals of affirmative action, of quotas and positive discrimination, would have been patronising to women and would have reduced rather than enhanced their standing.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the fact that the Government has abandoned the original proposals put forward by Senator Ryan, but I think it ought to be honest about this matter and ensure that the name of this Bill reflects what it is really about, namely, equality of opportunity. Of course, in general terms-this can be raised later-regardless of the costs this Bill imposes on the business community and so on, the whole concept of equality of opportunity is a vastly important concept. As a member of the Australian Liberal Party, it would be wrong of me to make any suggestion that I did not support very fundamentally that concept of equality of opportunity. I believe in the importance of the individual and, to be consistent, I must also believe in equality of opportunity.

I also recognise that in Australia, over the past one-and-a-half centuries, women have not always had the equality of opportunity which, in my view, they obviously deserved. There has been a very strong case over the past few years for employers to be encouraged to ensure that equality of opportunity exists in the work place. That has been in progress and schemes have been developed. In particular, I refer to the scheme developed by the Business Council of Australia, which is designed to enhance the equality of employment opportunities in the business community. I would have to say that I still get the feeling that there is a need in the community to change some attitudes towards women, and that does not apply solely to employers. Those attitudes also need to be changed in the councils of the trade union movement, that body so beloved by those on the other side. Those attitudes do have to be changed, but they must be changed in a persuasive, constructive and progressive way. They do not have to be changed continually by big brother government imposing more and more regulation on the community.

I, along with most members of this House, recognise that over the past decade or so Australia has undergone enormous social change and, whether one likes it or not, the stereotype view of women is a view that is really no longer applicable to the real world. One has only to look at statistics to see precisely how that social change in Australia has happened and the full impact of that change. An advertising firm called Clemenger produced a very interesting report in 1984 which was based on surveys conducted in relation to women in Sydney and Melbourne. That survey produced some very interesting results. It showed that only 36 per cent of all women over the age of 18 years are, if you like, traditional housewives; 39 per cent of women work; and the balance of 22 per cent are over 60 years of age and are therefore, by broad definition, retired.

It is also interesting to note that 53.4 per cent of married women work, so there is obviously a very high proportion of married women, many of whom have children, who are out in the work place. Of those who do not work, it is important to understand that many of them want to do so. Indeed, approximately half the women who are not in the work force but are of an age to work would like to be in the work force. In other words, the Clemenger study, which I believe was a very important study and which should be examined by all honourable members of this House, showed that only 26 per cent, that is, around one-quarter, of all women wanted to stay at home; 74 per cent of women, that is, three-quarters, either wanted to work or in fact do work.

Some honourable members may think that women who are out in the work place feel guilty about being in the work place. The survey showed that only one woman in ten felt any sense of remorse or guilt about being in the work place. To deny choice to women, to step back from providing equality of opportunity, is in my view to spurn the desires of 74 per cent of the women of Australia. Make no mistake about it: According to this survey and certainly according to the anecdotal evidence I have, the careers pursued by these women are enormously important to them. Some 68 per cent of women, or nearly 70 per cent, said in that survey that a career was as important to them as it was to a man. In other words, women believe very passionately in equality of opportunity and they deserve to have that equality of opportunity brought home to them.

It is also interesting to look at the attitudes of women towards their total lives and to compare the attitudes of women who stay at home with the attitudes of women who are out in the work place. It is sad to report that, in general terms-of course, no two women are the same; they all have different views about this-the survey showed that women in the work force were more satisfied with their lives than women who stay at home, and women in the work force were shown overwhelmingly by this survey to be people who had a much greater sense of freedom than those who stayed at home and a much greater confidence in terms of their social standing.

When trying to understand the problems of our society in a mature way, I think it is important to understand what the real desires, in terms of employment opportunities for women, really are. It is my contention that this attitudinal change of women is an attitudinal change which is likely to expand in the years ahead. There is all sorts of evidence that suggests that that is the case. For example, looking at the sort of women who are going out and pursuing a career, those women tend to be very much younger and they are women who, I might also say, tend to have tertiary education. So if we take the view that there should be more education in our society and that the younger generation is more oriented towards employment, then clearly this trend towards female participation in the work force, and indeed towards ensuring greater equality of opportunity, is something that is going to go ahead. If we look at the women who do not want to work, in response to this survey it was interesting to see that 67 per cent of those women were over the age of 50 years. So that also suggests that the change is one that will continue.

In the couple of minutes left to me, I want to make three brief points about the way I think society needs to adapt to these changing circumstances in our community. Firstly, as is the theme of my speech, we do need to ensure that women have greater opportunities in the work force. There is no doubt that, at the present time, women are predominantly in lower white collar jobs as opposed to upper white collar jobs. That is certainly the case in comparison to men. That seems to suggest, although it is not conclusive evidence, that women are not getting the equality of opportunity that they really deserve. The figures for upper white collar jobs, at managerial professional level, show that 5 per cent of the work force are women and 21 per cent are men. Certainly there is a very disproportionate bias in favour of men. In terms of promotions the same thing can be said. Expectations of women for promotion are very much lower than the expectation of men. So there is a very strong case for a change in attitudes.

Women need to be given more opportunities also when they have children. I do not think there is any doubt that married women with children are hampered by the very great lack of child care facilities in this country. At the moment governments are finding child care centres too expensive to fund. So we must look at things such as tax deductibility and more private sector child care centres to cope with that problem. Finally, we need many more opportunities for women in the area of permanent part time work. Awards need to be adjusted to make that possible. We must give women a chance by creating more opportunities for them and ensuring that they have much greater freedom of choice than they currently have today. I think all members of parliament need to understand that times are changing. We must move with those times. We must ensure that women do have the opportunities that society should make available to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to some of the comments that have been made so far in the wide-ranging debate that has taken place in relation to this clause. I must say I was somewhat surprised by the comments of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), because it appeared to me that there was no particular reason why he should be supporting the amendment. It would appear to me from his comments that he ought to be supporting the legislation. He talked at great length about the need for attitudinal changes. He said some of those changes had taken place, but he said there was a need for further additional changes. He also said there was clearly a need for more to be done. In that case, why is he opposed to the concept of affirmative action which is embedded in the legislation? I must say I was very surprised by those comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I was less surprised by the comments of some of the previous speakers, especially speakers from the National Party of Australia, who seemed to persist with the idea that somehow all one has to do is maintain the existing processes, the existing situation, and things will improve for women. All one needs to do, according to their view, is to take out all of the aspects of this legislation as proposed in the various amendments which refer to the concept of affirmative action, and put in some vague clause about equal opportunity. They hope in that way to get around the central issue, which is that affirmative action is necessary because women have been oppressed for a long period and it is necessary to do something to support that group in the community. A generalised equal opportunity clause would simply mean that it would be ignored and it would be directed to its goal, which is the promotion of women so that they can achieve the kind of positive goals which they have missed out on in the past.

Let me give some facts which underline what I am saying. Even in the Australian Public Service-as was noted on the Four Corners program of 17 February this year-which already has some affirmative action programs, the picture is bleak. Women fill half the positions in the lowly Fourth Division, but only a quarter of the public servants who make it to the Third Division are women, and a pathetic five per cent make it to the Second Division. As for the First Division, there has only been one female permanent head since Federation. So that is the sort of bleak picture which we are facing.

Let us consider the private sector. The 10 top Australian companies interviewed by Four Corners were asked how many of their managers were women. The AMP Society has 419 managers of whom 63 are women. Ansett Airlines of Australia has 1,600 supervisors of whom 343 are women. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd has 2,500 managers of whom 54 are women. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has 180 senior managers of whom 7 are women. Caltex Australia Ltd senior management, 35 strong, is all male. Esso Australia Ltd, supposedly a leader in affirmative action, has 140 women amongst its 1,100 executives. IBM Australia Ltd numbers 47 women amongst 960 managers. Qantas Airways Ltd senior executives total 707 of whom 33 are women. The Westpac Banking Corporation has 3,250 branch managers and only 45 of them are women. This is a dreadful situation and obviously one which needs to be changed. The universities do not fare much better when one considers that only 2 per cent of all professors are women. So the picture is clearly quite bleak. The other factor that needs to be emphasised is that often we have the sex typing of occupations. In other words, there are particular occupations which are overwhelmingly dominated by women and there are other occupations which are overwhelmingly dominated by men. This situation must be changed.

In the final part of my comments I want to refer to some earlier comments by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who got virtually everything wrong in his comments. Let me refer to one thing that he got wrong. He said that the affirmative action program was nothing more than a quota program. That is wrong because there are various ways in which one can promote affirmative action other than simply by way of quota program. But the other thing that he said was that female workers and trade unionists in employment in factories would not be advantaged by this legislation. He got that wrong as well. The fact is that it is possible for an employer, as part of the affirmative action program, to implement the program to assist women in disadvantaged positions in factories, especially, for example, migrant women.

Let me say something about the migrant situation. Part of a program that can be put forward by an employer in saying `We want to do something about discrimination and we want to do something to promote women', is to help the migrant women factory workers in that factory through programs to assist in the teaching of English. It is possible for an employer by way of the affirmative action legislation actually to put forward as part of that program English courses and courses to assist those people to promote themselves in the community generally through the promotion of English. So let us not hear any more of this nonsense from the honourable member for Gippsland, who got it completely wrong, who said that it is just a matter of quotas. There are many and varied ways in which one can promote women through the affirmative action program.

I particularly urge employers who have an unskilled work force, especially a migrant work force, to adopt these sorts of strategies because one of the major problems in the promotion of women of migrant background has been the lack of knowledge of English. If employers can meet their obligations to the program through the promotion of English, that will be of very great assistance and will assist those people to be promoted in employment during the rest of their lives. So let us adopt the positive aspects of this legislation. It is clearly an affirmative action program. It is not merely some vague equal opportunity Bill. It is directed towards the promotion of women who have been oppressed and disadvantaged in this community. Therefore, we reject the amendment and we support the original legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment. Perhaps it would be putting it too strongly to say that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who has just resumed his seat, is calling black white, but I point out that the essence of the Opposition's objection is precisely that this is not an affirmative action Bill but a Bill for equality of opportunity for women in employment. That is the purpose of the Opposition's amendment. I indicate that there is a good deal of common ground in relation to this legislation. It has been alleged that there is disagreement to the legislation-and there has been disagreement here today-but certainly there is also a good deal of common ground.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 10 or 20 years women have made considerable strides in the work place-although it should not be wrongly deduced that nothing further needs to be done-have made considerable strides in terms of the participation rate of women and, in an anecdotal way, one can point to the very fact that the Speaker in this place is a woman. Notwithstanding that, members of the Opposition recognise every bit as strongly as do Government members that significant discriminatory practices, traditions, attitudes, conventions, and even legislation, operate against equal employment opportunity for women. I submit that is virtually common ground. Most honourable members on this side of the chamber would also recognise, without in any way downgrading a woman's key role as mother and homemaker, that together with concern for that role women today increasingly also value a job and a career in the same way, one could say to the same extent, as men do. So, I underline the fact that honourable members on this side of the chamber are every bit as concerned as Government members to foster greater equality of opportunity for women in employment.

However, one can go about that in various ways. There are two broad ways: One can legislate for a prescriptive mandatory approach, which is what the Government is attempting to adopt with this Bill, but still not going so far as to implement a program of affirmative action, to which I will refer in a moment. The other way, which would be the Opposition's preferred option, is to allow for a voluntary approach to be taken. I believe that the possibility of such an approach achieving meaningful and effective action has, in fact, been demonstrated. I take this opportunity to make clear to the honourable member for Calwell-and the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), in the light of some of the remarks that he made earlier in the debate-the essence of the Opposition's position on this matter, namely, that we are strongly committed to equality of opportunity for women in employment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of you are.
—I would say that most members on this side would be so strongly committed.
—Don't include the National Party.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne has already contributed to this debate. It is now the turn of the honourable member for Berowra.

—The Opposition is strongly committed to greater equality of opportunity for women in employment. We recognise it as an issue of major social change. The Government has opted for a mandatory approach to this matter. While we have many reservations about that approach-and we will seek to amend the legislation in a number of ways-nevertheless, because of our strong commitment to the objective of equality of opportunity for women in employment, we have indicated that we will not vote against the Bill. But for my part, and I think I speak for many members of the Opposition, I would prefer to see a voluntary approach taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the argument at this precise moment, however, is not the distinction between a mandatory or a voluntary approach-though there are elements of clobber in the approach adopted by the Government we could not support, which one would expect because that is what the Australian Council of Trade Unions would want. With this ACTU-ALP coalition Government one would expect the Government to move in that direction. Yet the legislation is about achieving equality of opportunity for women and not affirmative action in the strong sense or in the sense that it is used in the United States for instance. That is the important distinction that must be made, and that is why the Opposition wants to change the title. To some extent the point has been reflected in criticism made by some of the Government's supporters, some of those who pressured the Government to go ahead with this measure. For example, activist women's groups and the ACTU say that it is `weak' and `toothless', that it does not provide for compulsory, often court backed, quotas for the employment of women, which system is prevalent in the United States. It does not provide for gender preference in employment, which we would not support. The Opposition would not be prepared to let the Bill go through if it did so provide.

Again the principle of selection and promotion on the basis of merit in employment is asserted explicitly in the Bill, and that is its thrust. Certainly, it does refer to quantitative measures in the form of forward estimates, but those are not employment quotas to be met, as occurs in the case of the United States.

As I said many honourable members on this side of the chamber would prefer a voluntary approach to be taken in this area, and it is certainly my belief that a voluntary and self-managed approach for the private sector is a practical and viable alternative. In closing, I draw to the attention of the Committee the efforts of those firms that participated in the pilot program, which efforts were subsequently supported by the Business Council of Australia, towards the implementation of a voluntary program. A considerable amount has been done in that area. In fact, in September last year a decision was taken to establish a private sector Council for Equal Employment Opportunity as a positive self-regulation initiative with the objective of fostering the continuing goodwill of business and the securing of a genuine commitment in the private sector to equality of opportunity programs. That Council comprises a board, and there is to be a small but highly qualified staff headed by an executive director. The general purpose of the Council will be to establish a registrar of participating companies, to provide manuals to assist companies and to actively promote equal opportunity programs and attitudes. That Council is up and running.

In my judgment, as I have said, such a private sector self-managed and voluntary approach has a great deal to offer in achieving effective and meaningful change towards greater equality of opportunity for women. I would strongly urge that the procedures and pace of the implementation of the present legislation take cognisance of the progress and efficacy of that private sector Council for Equal Employment Opportunity in employment. In any case the voluntary program will certainly assist companies to meet their obligations as they are imposed under this legislation, and the more successful it is the less expensive action in accordance with this Bill will be to the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hold serious reservations about the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill because in my opinion the title is not descriptive of what is included in the Bill. Hence I support the amendment moved by the Opposition. I note at the outset that opposition in whole or in part to measures of this kind of deceitfully entitled legislation usually invokes a somewhat patronising response from certain quarters. At best this sort of critic is shallowly judged either to have failed to grasp the subtle complexities of the concept of affirmative action as developed in Australia or to have failed fully to appreciate the pragmatic way in which the legislation has been drafted only after claimed and so-called extensive consultations, discussion papers, interim reports, voluntary pilot projects, working parties and the like. At worst it seems to me to be assumed that any critic has an outmoded, if not overtly reactionary, attitude to the role of women in society.

SPEECH.PARA: However, my views on this amendment are arrived at only after giving a great deal of thought: Firstly, to the title of the Bill; secondly, to the substance of the Government's proposal; thirdly, to the report of the working party on affirmative action legislation; fourthly, to the available evidence, at home and abroad, as to the practical effects; and, fifthly, to the considered opinions of distinguished experts in the field. Finally, my views are arrived at after having thought not merely about the immediate legislative implications of this inappropriately entitled Bill but also about the longer term effects, with particular attention to Australia's increasingly assertive judiciary.

I am aware that a number of other important amendments are proposed by the Opposition in an attempt to render this Bill more coherent and to secure better protection and fairer treatment for affected employers. I particularly commend proposals suggested by and pursuant to this amendment to do the following: To remove reference to any reliance on the external affairs powers; to impose a five-year sunset clause; to limit ministerial direction; to limit the powers of the Director of Affirmative Action by ensuring that any guidelines issued by the Director are subject to parliamentary scrutiny and, if necessary, to disapproval by this Parliament; to limit the appointment of consultants to those with ministerial approval; to remove from clause 10 (1) (e) the capacity of the Director to conduct `other programs'; to remove the requirement for so-called consultation by employers with trade unions; to prevent sub-contractors being classified as employees; to ensure that material in confidential reports by companies does not appear in public reports; and to increase the penalty for improper release of confidential information. After careful consideration, I must say that the proposed amendments to which I have referred do not go far enough in meeting my concerns about this Bill. My reservations about this Bill go to the heart of both the Government's practical and its philosophical arguments for affirmative action. It will be recalled that the Government defined affirmative action in its 1984 Green Paper entitled `Affirmative Action for Women' as:

As systematic means, determined by the employer in consultation with senior management, employees and unions of achieving equal employment opportunity . . . for women. Affirmative action is compatible with appointment and promotion on the basis of the principle of merit, skills and qualifications.
This has direct relevance to the amendment to the title of the Bill. It has more in common, at least at this initial stage-
