DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Paper Industry-Great Barrier Reef-Rural Australia-Medical Services-Company Takeovers-Mr John Wiseman-Interest Rates-Home Heating Oil Prices-Motor Accident Victims

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian paper manufacturers are heavily protected by a tariff which makes it impossible for Australian printers to purchase certain better quality papers from overseas at a much cheaper price. Australian printers have the expertise to produce magazines of high quality but this quality is dependent, to a large degree, on the quality of paper used. To achieve the desired results for colour reproduction a paper of high stability characteristic and surface is needed to ensure precise print registration. Unfortunately, our papers do not yet compare favourably with the imported products to which I refer. The Australian printer, who must meet stringent quality specifications, is placed at a disadvantage because of the 20 per cent tariff on the imported paper. If a magazine is printed overseas it may be imported into Australia without incurring any duty. The book bounty for magazines is inadequate for competition. The paper manufacturers get support but the printing industry which employs so many more people does not. It is a great pity that the excellent publication Australian Geographic which was published in December by Dick Smith was printed overseas. Dick Smith should not be accused of being unpatriotic. I must agree with his response to criticism, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a global village and I believe every person has the same right to the world's resources.

He then cited the fact that a large percentage of motor vehicles on the road are of Japanese manufacture. It should be noted that the conception, layout, typesetting and make-up for the Australian Geographic is performed in Australia but that the colour scanning, printing and binding are not. The Printing and Allied Trades Employers Federation of Australia and the Printing and Kindred Industries Union are both concerned at the escalating preference of publishers to place orders overseas, even though problems may be encountered in communications and prompt deliveries. The 20 per cent advantage is seen as the factor which is the determinant in placing orders.

It would seem advisable for the tariff on the papers, so necessary for competition by price and quality, to be removed and an adequate bounty paid to the Australian paper makers. The Australian printing industry, from medium to large companies, has been faced with enormous capital investment in recent years occasioned by changing technology. The speed of change has made it difficult to recoup the investment within a reasonable period and before further changes have to be introduced. The printing industry is in an area of expensive on-going modernisation. This is not unique to Australia but at a time when more and more large publishing orders are being lost the situation is of great concern.

I am also concerned for the employees in this industry. The Printing Employers Federation and the union have displayed a degree of responsibility in these periods of change. The union has recognised the inevitable changes to its craft and the new skills and operations which have emerged. Many of the demarcations have been eliminated. That has been of great help to the industry in general. Employers too have endeavoured to retain employees in excess of requirements during these operational changes. I urge this Government to initiate an investigation into the effect of policies which place the printers of quality colour productions in Australia at a disadvantage and to endeavour to support the campaign of Australian printers to keep printing in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Great Barrier Reef is the largest of the world's reef complexes and is recognised internationally by its inscription on the World Heritage List. It rims the north-east of the Australian continent and comprises a vast chain of separate coral reef platforms, each made up of limestone rock covered by a veneer of living corals and algae. The massive-type corals can grow as individuals for a thousand years or more, forming huge domes as big as a suburban house. Research by scientists at the Australian Institute of Marine Science in Townsville has revealed that the huge coral colonies on the Great Barrier Reef are veritable storehouses of historical information about past climates. A team led by Dr Peter Isdale has developed a unique and successful technology for unlocking the environmental secrets held by the corals. Long cores are drilled from living colonies of corals, using a specifically devised underwater pneumatic drilling rig. The success of this rig is a testament to the innovative technical expertise available to researchers at the Australian Institute of Marine Science. The designer, Mr Ted Daniel, recently won an award for his ingenuity and workmanship. The coral cores contain the life histories of the colonies in the form of skeletal bands-much as tree rings do-and the chemical compounds caught up in the skeletons as they were deposited. Using newly developed analytical techniques, these histories can be unravelled to reconstruct the conditions the corals have grown up in over the centuries.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Isdale's discovery in 1984 of fluorescent bands in inshore growing coral, which was published that year in the prestigious international journal Nature, has led to collaborative research with other Institute scientists such as Dr Kevin Boto. His expertise in analytical chemistry led to another paper being published in Nature the following year identifying the land-derived compound which forms the glowing bands in the coral cores. Drs David Barnes and Bruce Chalker provided the inspiration and effort leading to the pioneering techniques which showed how density changes in the coral skeleton reflect climatic patterns such as drought through the centuries. The discovery revealed that substances derived from land plants-which flow from rivers to the ocean-are incorporated in the skeletons of certain corals. The pattern build-up, viewed under ultraviolet light, can show river run-offs and resulting rainfall patterns with an accuracy of less than a month through the life of the coral, which could be 1,000 years. By using gamma rays and X-rays to determine the density of coral, a record of drought in past years and a picture of future drought patterns can be established.

The corals can also tell when there were devastating El Nino events halfway around the globe, periods of drought, what the temperature of the water was at any given time, what the vegetation along the banks of rivers was and of devastating cyclones in certain areas that many may never have known about. For example, in 1958 the Burdekin River flowed in February, not in March and then again in April. The corresponding double band can be seen, with the naked eye, in the coral. The scientists believe that it will soon be possible to reconstruct the history of major rivers, using the startlingly faithful fluorescent indicators of freshwater input to coastal regions contained in the huge corals. Since these coral species are the most widespread on earth, these reconstructions will be available to countries throughout the world's tropical regions. It will be possible to view the history of a nation's weather on at least a monthly basis for many hundreds of years past. The world-wide distribution of the corals ensures that the timing and intensity of such extreme events as the El Nino phenomenon have been faithfully recorded for at least the last 1,000 years.

Much of the world's weather is driven from the tropics, and knowledge of its history will lead to a better understanding of the most important natural process on the earth's surface-the weather. The potential uses of this knowledge in agricultural, engineering and economic planning are almost incalculable, leading as they do to a better understanding of the likelihood of future environmental changes. An accurate knowledge of past coastal weather patterns would be of great value to anyone who needs to know what the weather may be like at a given period in the future. Eventually, it will enable the production of an historical map of the climate of tropical Australia, and an even longer goal is to compile similar maps for other tropical countries. The task of interpreting all the data stored in the corals will involve significant scientific studies over several years, both within Australia and overseas. The international application of this discovery is particularly important to Australia's relationship with countries in South East Asia and the Pacific region and to all tropical countries where corals are found. The Australian Institute of Marine Science has given a service to mankind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past few days we have witnessed a series of demonstrations here in Canberra by farmers who have been rallying outside Parliament House and in a number of locations throughout the city. The reason they are here is to demonstrate to the Government here in Canberra that what is going on out there in the Australian rural landscape represents a scene of disaster. The farmers are trying to get their message across so that on 15 April the Government will bring out a package which will be of real benefit to the industry in which these people work. We have been told that these people have acted in an irresponsible fashion, and I have heard many comments to this effect over the past couple of days. I say that these people have not acted irresponsibly; they have acted in a most reasonable way. They have obtained plenty of publicity for their cause, they have done so without causing too much disruption to the normal goings on here in Canberra and they should be commended for the way in which they have carried out their demonstrations.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason they are here-and I am sure they will be back again-is that they are dissatisfied with the attitude of this Government to the problems that prevail within their industry. We are frequently told by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and, indeed, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the problems of agriculture in this country are the fault of overseas countries and organisations. We are told that the problems of agriculture are all the fault of the European Economic Community and the United States farm Bill and this is why our farmers are in strife. When he is pressed further, the Minister for Primary Industry says that it is also the fault of the previous Fraser-Anthony Government.

There is some truth in the first point-problems have been created for our agricultural industries by overseas actions-but the point that the Minister and the Prime Minister continue to deny is that a great number of the problems of Australian agriculture today are internally generated by this Government. The farmers have been demonstrating here for the past few days because they are concerned about matters such as the high interest rates which prevail in this country, interest rates that are as high as we have ever seen in the history of this nation. These interest rates are crippling ordinary Australian men and women who are trying to get on and make a decent living for themselves.

Tonight I wish to take the opportunity to talk about one such person who lives within the electorate of Gilmore, near my home town. I come from Young in south-western New South Wales. The person I refer to is a farmer by the name of Mr Chris Beck. He lives on a property, owned jointly by himself and his father, called Santa Maria. Last season he produced some 1,600 tonnes of wheat and one might say that that is quite a lot of wheat. It certainly is. Mr Beck is one of the better farmers in the Young district. He is a very hard worker, is in his mid-30s and is one of those people who should be getting ahead in the world. Mr Beck received a total of $208,000 for the sale of that 1,600 tonnes of wheat. After paying dockage, handling charges and other fees, he was left with about half the value of his crop. Most of the remaining money was needed to cover the fixed costs in running the property and very little was left over to meet the normal living expenses of his family.

About three years ago, Mr Beck, like any other red-blooded young Australian trying to create some prosperity for his family and his country, purchased some additional land. When he purchased that land the interest rate he had to pay on the money he had borrowed was 13 per cent. Today the interest rate is 21 per cent and as a consequence he is paying an extra $120,000 in interest. Mr Beck and other farmers like him in this country are going broke not because they have to pay $120,000 more in interest resulting from external factors. Mr Beck is not paying $120,000 more in his interest bill because of the Fraser-Anthony Government. He has to pay that amount of money because of the policies of this Government which are crippling people like him-decent, honest, hard-working Australians who are trying to get ahead. These policies are crippling people throughout our rural industries, and that is why those people have been here for the past few days and will come back again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this House the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) tabled three documents as well as making statements, all of which had some reference to me. The matter raised was in relation to a claim by two Newcastle doctors that they had been offered involvement in a 24-hour medical service. The document consisted of a transcript of an interview of Dr Court and Dr Parker by two members of the staff of the Health Insurance Commission and statutory declarations by Dr David Parker and Dr Ian Walker. In the transcript of interview, Dr David Parker refers to a meeting that took place between himself, Dr Ian Walker and me on the evening of 7 March. The discussion was long and complex but one that I believed at the time was constructive and fruitful.

SPEECH.PARA: In the interests of an accurate public record it is imperative that I outline what took place before, during and after that meeting. At about lunch time on Friday, 7 March I had a telephone call from Michael Belcher, a member of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation staff in Newcastle. He advised me that he had been contacted by Dr Ian Walker of the Hunter Medical Association, the regional branch of the Australian Medical Association. Dr Walker outlined to him a series of events involving Dr David Parker, including contact he had had with some Sydney doctors and businessmen, a brick being thrown through his window, and his fears for his own and his family's safety. In discussion with Dr Walker, Mr Belcher had suggested that they should contact me. This apparently was in the context of Dr Walker indicating that he was considering taking up the matter with the Federal Opposition. Apparently Dr Walker was not responsive to the advice that they should contact me and the purpose of the call by Mr Belcher was to seek advice as to the most appropriate course of action.

We discussed the matter and its implications, and finally I suggested that he should advise Dr Walker that he or somebody else should contact the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), who chairs the Public Accounts Committee inquiry into medical fraud. I understand that a call was made that afternoon by Mr Belcher to the honourable member for Canberra; however, the honourable member was out of the electorate that day. In the meantime, Dr Walker had rung my office and made an appointment. I finally spoke with him and Dr Parker at about six o'clock that evening. The discussion we had was long and complex. I suggested that if we were all seriously concerned about the underlying implications of the events outlined, the worst way to raise it would be for a politician, from any party, to make a speech on it. The effect of such an action would be immediately to make it a political issue and the matters of concern would be obscured.

Dr Parker made it clear that he had no hard evidence to substantiate his perceptions, but he was apprehensive for his and his family's well-being. It is important to realise that between making the appointment to see me and actually speaking with me, they had spoken to Mr Gavin Gilchrist of the ABC. This interview was subsequently broadcast on Monday morning on AM. I advised the doctors that in my view the matter would best be dealt with by the Public Accounts Committee, which consists of members of all parties from both Houses. It could be dealt with in camera and its capacity to take evidence and call witnesses was excellent. Perhaps more importantly, the Committee, because of its ongoing inquiries, may well have information that related to these allegations, which we all acknowledged in themselves lacked substantiation. I also pointed out that medical fraud had been occurring and was being investigated by the PAC long before the advent of Medicare.

The conclusion of this aspect of the discussion was that they agreed to request Gavin Gilchrist to hold back his broadcast for a few days and I promised to speak to the honourable member for Canberra on my return to Canberra on the following Monday. I believe that an approach was made to Gavin Gilchrist following this meeting, but he declined to hold back the broadcast. I approached the honourable member for Canberra and a member of the PAC secretariat contacted Dr Walker on Monday, 10 March. I have been advised that he was invited to make an initial written submission to the PAC. To date, a month later, this has not been done. The fears I expressed about the politicisation of the matter have now been proven to be well founded. Dr Parker and Dr Walker are able to write substantial statutory declarations, but cannot be bothered writing to the PAC. During the discussion the question of Edelsten-type clinics was raised. Dr Walker suggested that the Government was turning a blind eye to these clinics. I denied that. Whilst it may look attractive to him on the surface, it was fundamentally nonsense.

It is quite clear that the way I have acted in this matter has been both proper and sound. The advice I gave was good advice; unfortunately, it was not followed fully. The fact that the Opposition has attempted, in cahoots with Dr Walker and Dr Parker, to make political capital of this issue does it no credit. It denigrates the issue and imputes actions and motives where none exist. The imputations and references were fallacious and absurd and I reject them out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you do not deny the contents.
—I do, as I have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Trade Practices Amendment Bill was debated in this House on 20 March, I was quite outspoken in calling for an inquiry into the bid being made for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd by Bell Resources Ltd, headed by Mr Robert Holmes a Court. The Government refused to accept my call to hold an inquiry into that takeover bid, but all members of this House would agree that subsequent events have merely reinforced the need for an inquiry to be held. The latest disclosure at Question Time today-exposed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey)-that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) has a pecuniary interest which was not declared to the Cabinet sub-committee, merely reinforces the need for an inquiry to be held. The honourable member for O'Connor was correct in disclosing that a decision had been made by the Cabinet sub-committee to recommend to its Caucus colleagues not to hold an inquiry into the takeover bid by Mr Robert Holmes a Court. That decision was made behind closed doors. The reason it was made was never disclosed to the Government Caucus or to the Parliament, yet we have had the astounding revelation today hat a key figure in that decision had a pecuniary interest to hide.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go on further to outline the reasons why an inquiry should be held. We have only to look at the ruling brought down by Mr Justice Marks on 26 March. Honourable members will bear in mind that legislation was passed in this House on 20 March. Subsequent to that legislation being passed, Mr Robert Holmes a Court withdrew the bid he had on offer for BHP shares. On 26 March, Mr Justice Marks in his ruling made these comments:

Although the hearing before me has been cut short, it was quite well advanced. It was cut short by a Bell capitulation following hard on the heels of a refusal by the Court to set aside a subpoena calling on documents disclosing details of the $2 billion loan facility itself preceded by strong prima facie evidence pointing to their importance and other possible breaches of the requirements of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) (Victoria) Code.
Mr Justice Marks further said:

The Court is driven to the inescapable conclusion that the Bell interests have always been and are still bent on keeping the loan facility arrangement secret. That secrecy in the circumstances of the take-over scheme is impossible.

Honourable members will recall that during the debate on the Bill the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) pointed out that the loans were being raised from South African sources, yet Mr Justice Marks said in his ruling that Mr Holmes a Court had gone to extreme lengths to cover up the source of those loans. Mr Justice Marks went on to say:

This conduct has been compounded recently by the highly misleading, if not deceptive, statements of the chairman, one Holmes a Court, to the effect that the present offers have been withdrawn merely because of the length of the court hearing with overtones that this was connected with the length of the B.H.P. case.

The resistance in these proceedings to the disclosure is significant enough, but the secrecy is particularly ominous against the backdrop of statements of Holmes a Court to which I have referred.It is against that type of secrecy, which Mr Justice Marks tried to expose; against the disclosures of the honourable member for Denison; against the proceedings that are now going on for a new offer; and against the Minister for Trade not disclosing his pecuniary interests in this business, that I repeat tonight the call for an inquiry by the Trade Practices Commission into the takeover proceedings for BHP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 October 1985, I made a speech in the adjournment debate regarding a gentleman called John Wiseman of Flat 11/9 Findon Street, Hawthorn, Victoria.
—Is he a member of the Labor Party?

—No. He was not. He recently died and I thought I would talk about Mr Wiseman here tonight. On that occasion I talked about a dispute that Mr Wiseman was having with the Department of Transport and the Department of Communications. The former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was also involved in this case. It was a case that had been going on since 1976. Mr Wiseman, unfortunately, recently passed away. I level blame for his death at the bureaucracy that runs those departments. That bureaucracy was one of the major reasons for Mr Wiseman's recent heart attack. Mr Wiseman, I believe, was persecuted by both these departments. He was found to be correct in his claims. In 1976 he refused to go to sea on a vessel called the Silver Harrier because he believed that the wireless aerials on that vessel were unsafe. He was dismissed from his position as a wireless operator.

SPEECH.PARA: He engaged in a fight against the bureaucracy under the freedom of information legislation and it was proven beyond doubt that he was correct and that he was wrongfully dismissed. All the gentleman wanted was for the departments to concede that so he could get work in his profession. He had been denied continuous employment over many years. He was victimised by the bureaucracy, by the ship owners and, unfortunately, by the people within the work force. This is best summed up in a footnote to a letter dated 9 January 1985 from the Acting Deputy Commonwealth Ombudsman to Mr Wiseman. A handwritten note on the bottom of the letter reads:

Mr Wiseman is probably on sound technical ground and we may have `missed the boat' in our earlier investigation, understandably because the insulator resistance seawater conducting question was never satisfactorily explained to us.

In fact, the truth is that documents were withheld concerning the Wiseman case. I am sure that the honourable member for Kooyong would support me in saying that this is a tragedy. This man was persecuted and his health suffered. He became obsessed to the point where his health suffered greatly. He visited my office on many occasions. He was a man of huge build, of incredible intelligence, and was able single-handedly to demolish the arguments put forward by representatives of the Department of Communications and the Department of Transport. As I said, he was highly intelligent. I believe that he was driven to an early grave by the treatment he received. All he wanted was justice in terms of people conceding that the arguments he put forward were correct. The ironic part about this matter is that his claims, some years later, were found to be correct. The aerials on the ships were replaced because the salt did have an effect on these types of aerials. Mr Wiseman made a valuable contribution to the shipping industry, and the price he paid was an early death.

In Safety at Sea, August 1985, which is published in England, there is an article attributed to Mr Wiseman which is headed `Rest Assured, your Government is looking into the matter (Don't Hold your Breath)'. I guess I should conclude by repeating the comments I made in my last speech: What about giving Mr Wiseman a fair go? Mr Wiseman did not get a fair go. Mr Wiseman died. His workmates who have contacted me believe that one of the things that contributed, if not the thing that contributed, to his early death was the way in which he had been persecuted and ignored when all he asked for was justice and for people to admit that they had made a wrong decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to alert Government members to the desperate plight that farmers and small businesses now find themselves in. Of all the extra costs that this Government has imposed on these people, the high interest rates have been particularly devastating. It was only as early as the beginning of last year that a farmer or a small businessman could go to a bank and take out a loan at 14 per cent interest. Now such people find that they are paying 21 per cent, before one starts to add on bank charges. If a person has taken out a loan of, say, $100,000, that means that the payments that he is up for now are $150 a week above what he would have budgeted for-I repeat-as early as the beginning of last year. No business in the bush is profitable enough to service an interest rate that high.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial position in country New South Wales has deteriorated markedly, even in the last couple of weeks, and especially in the towns of Nyngan, Peak Hill and Tullamore and in the Gilgandra district. The situation in Nyngan has become desperate for many, with a number of farmers having their credit cut off completely in recent days. They do not even get $10 a week with which to buy corn flakes. I suppose that they can go out of their back doors and kill a sheep to eat. But already we have had to arrange food parcels for some of these farmers. This has been of tremendous assistance and has lifted their morale to a certain extent; but we have cases of some people even sharing their grandparents' pension cheques.

In the old days when the banks foreclosed on people, they used to draw the bottom line, sell the person up, clear the debts, and if there was anything left at the end of the day the person would be given a cheque. Nowadays the bank cuts off their credit, allows them to stay on their properties but do not give them any cash; so they cannot put in a wheat crop. If they cannot put in a wheat crop, that does not give them the wherewithal to get a cash flow to service the interest rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —People have to have that cash.

—They do. Every three months, of course, they have the interest rate ticking away. In some cases it is $2,000, $3,000 or $4,000 a week. What happens is that these people's equity, every three months, is going downwards, dropping all the time. Some people have rung me and said: `We would be prepared to go now with nothing. If we could just put the keys on the desk of the bank and go, and would go; but we are terrified that we will be going with a debt of $100,000 or $200,000 around our neck that will saddle us for the rest of our lives'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, while they are on the property they cannot do anything except run the few livestock that they have. If the property is not being worked, how will they sell it? Even if a prospective buyer came along, because they are not working their property and putting in a wheat crop, that makes it so much harder to sell. Of course, the banks know that no properties are selling. Possibly, at the most, there would be one or two sales in a district. But if people are forced to sell over and above that, the values of properties would be more than halved.

On 15 April these sorts of people will be looking to the Government for some sort of assistance. I guess that they do not expect that the general macroeconomic circumstances will exist to correct things such as flexibilities in wages and tariff reductions, but they are particularly looking for some sort of short term carry-on finance that will give them the ability to get their wheat crops in for this year, and particularly next year if the drought hits hard this year. I guess that people will look upon this as a handout for farmers. But if he can get the wheat crop in, the average farmer in these sorts of districts would be earning $100,000 in export income for Australia. The people themselves might be living on $50 per week, but they are earning $100,000 in export income for Australia. So we should look at this matter in terms of this being a great investment for the taxpayers.

If the Government does not assist, it will not be a matter of these people moving out of their properties and someone else moving into them and working them; it will be a case of these fellows staying on but earning nothing for Australia and getting into a very depressing situation. The situation is already putting tremendous stress on their families as well as themselves. These fellows might not be paying direct tax, but they are paying enormous amounts in indirect tax. Only the other day I was talking to one average farmer who said that he paid $12,000 last year in fuel tax alone. These fellows are contributing to Australia in every way. I ask the Government even though it may not be favourably disposed towards them, to give some consideration to these farmers in the package it announces next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight with a sense of deja vu because I too want to talk about the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Holmes a Court situation. Whilst the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) had some good things to say-and I must pay tribute to the position taken by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman)-I think he completely undermined his argument by his scurrilous attack on the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins). I know the Minister well and I know that there is absolutely no substance to what the honourable member said. Honourable members opposite know that. They are simply muck raking in the belief that something will stick. Perhaps now I can get on with what I want to say.

SPEECH.PARA: The bid for BHP has implications whose impact extends far beyond the day to day activities of the Australian stock market. BHP is Australia's largest company, employing some 60,000 persons directly and tens of thousands more indirectly. This company is now the subject of a takeover offer by one man who proposes to control its assets and resources. The national issue-that have been raised are a result of the prominence of this company in the Australian economy and the methods by which it is possible for one man to gain control of such a corporation. The control of BHP by one man, Mr Robert Holmes a Court, concerns me and many Australians as it appears that the control of this monopoly will be achieved without any inquiry, under the grossly false pretences of protecting the right of the Australian stock market to operate in a free and unfettered manner. For the record, I have never felt any obligation whatsoever to protect the right of the stock exchange and would have thought accountability was the overriding requirement. BHP represents 10 per cent of the capitalisation of the Australian stock market. In the United States of America this is the equivalent of the following seven companies. IBM, Exxon, General Electric, General Motors, A T and T, Dupont and Sears and Robuck. In both the United States and the United Kingdom, regulatory bodies exist whereby acquisition of control of major national monopolies is reviewed in an unprejudiced manner. It is extraordinary that we are prepared to allow one man to control the equivalent of the seven companies without an unprejudiced, formal inquiry. In fact, the lengths to which we have gone to ensure than an inquiry is not held brings into question our impartiality on this issue. An argument has been advanced that if the Government were to interfere foreign investors would be reluctant to invest in Australia as it would be seen as an example of government interference, in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Japan, our major investor nations, the governments would not stand by and allow such an event to take place. I might add that that would apply also to West Germany. Furthermore, we have in Australia the Trade Practices Commission, which used to have the power to hold an inquiry. The current shareholders of BHP were aware of the existence of this power and were happy to buy and hold their investment with full knowledge of the possibility that, in the event of a takeover bid, the free market would not be able to decide the final outcome.

I would like to make a few remarks about Mr Holmes a Court. This is a matter about which I am most concerned. For all BHP's faults, that company has never owned or had any interest in the media. This is not the case with Mr Holmes a Court, who owns the Western Mail in Western Australia and also controls Channel Seven. I believe that Mr Holmes a Court has used the financial pages of his paper unmercifully to run shares. The writer of that paper's financial column, Mr Tim Threadgold, at Mr Holmes a Court's beck and call, has either plugged or dammed shares, according to whether Mr Holmes a Court wanted to buy or sell. The effect of this is that little people in the market have been hurt. Little people operate largely in a vacuum of ignorance and they get frightened out very easily.

I go back to the time when a company called DTX Australia Ltd was listed on the second board in Western Australia. I was very interested in this company. I declare my interest by informing the House that I bought some shares in this company because I thought it had tremendous potential, a potential which I believe it has since demonstrated. When it was listed somebody shortsold about $1m of shares. I do not know who that was. The Western Mail immediately started to bag the company. It made all sorts of allegations about the propriety of that company, all of which were unfounded. It forced the company to two Trade Practices Commission inquiries, both of which found that the company had nothing to explain. As I say, I do not know who was responsible for that shortselling. However, the only man I know who has $1m to spare and a newspaper is, of course, Mr Holmes a Court. His attacks on DTX have not ceased. He was reported in the paper the other day as saying that this company has debts. This company is expanding very rapidly and for a short time it did have substantial debts. Then, of course, so has Bell Resources Ltd. We do not see Mr Holmes a Court launching into print and denouncing Bell Resources for having debts. Any company which is growing quickly will have substantial debts. The position with DTX has been rectified. I believe the management of that company is excellent. It is a shame that small investors have been shaken out of a very profitable investment by the actions of this company. I have a lot more to say on Mr Holmes a Court, but I am going to run out of time. I will speak about this matter at a later opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I saw the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) on television talking about home heating oil. She really repeated what I had said a couple of nights ago in the adjournment debate.
—Everything you said.

—She mentioned something about the price of oil. I do not mind Canberra. The people in Canberra have been pretty good to me. They are just ordinary, decent people. It is quite cold in Canberra, as it is in Hobart. The honourable member for Canberra said that the people of Canberra were being disadvantaged because of the price of home heating oil. Of course, in my normal, calculating way, I just happened to telephone a dealer. I said to the dealer: `What is the price of home heating oil in Canberra?' I was told. I said: `Are you sure? If you delivered this home heating oil to me, what would be the price?' I was told 43.5c per litre.
—How much?

—I was told 43.5c a litre. So I rang the distributor in Hobart just to check my sums to make certain that I was absolutely right. I was staggered. It is 54.5c a litre in Hobart. I think the people of Canberra will agree that Hobart is a little bit colder and the winter is a little bit longer and, therefore, the poor ordinary pensioners, the poor ordinary people who depend on home heating oil are being taken to the cleaners once again by the oil companies. My attack is against the oil companies because the Prices Surveillance Authority does not fix a maximum price for home heating oil. Nobody has jurisdiction over the price at all. The oil companies can charge whatever they like. I am afraid that instead of the price of heating oil going down in Tasmania it has gone up because we are going into the peak of winter.
—Shameful!

—It is absolutely shameful as the honourable member for Denison said. I believe that it should be the subject of an inquiry. I have already written to the responsible Minister, as I mentioned the other night. I just want to let the honourable member for Canberra know that the people in Canberra are not being disadvantaged as much as my people and the people of the honourable member for Denison in Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) who is sitting at the table will be interested in this matter. I went down to the Royal Hobart Hospital. We all know that the motor vehicle is a necessity, but we all know that the motor vehicle and the motor cycle cause undue problems to many people in Australia. Every day 10 people die as a result of motor accidents. One of those people invariably is a young motor cyclist under the age of 25 years. A lady rang me and said: `Bruce, would you come down to the Royal, ward 1C, to have a look at my son?' I went down. There were five other young people there. It was tragic. They had been involved in either a motor cycle accident, a motor car accident or had been injured as a pedestrian. One young lady was injured as a result of being kicked by a horse. They were all suffering from brain damage and were all completely incapacitated. The parents were mindful of the fact that they were needed there nearly every day. I wondered what would happen if they did not have parents. They are the forgotten statistic of which we all need to be aware. The parents mentioned to me that the physiotherapists and the doctors are doing all they can but they cling to that little bit of life. They want their children to have the best of care. They want to see that they have a chance to survive in this world. I think that governments need to do a little bit more about it. It hurts me. The honourable member for Denison may correct me, but we have a very good Douglas Parker Rehabilitation Centre that is underutilised. There is a bit of red tape there. Some people do not like to get their carpet dirty or their hands dirty with some of these poor unfortunate young people. Some of the bureaucrats who run it need a bit of straightening out. They need to know that they have to work and look after these young people. That is what the honourable member for Denison and I need to do when we go back.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Leader of the Opposition.

—The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) understands what I am talking about, as does the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). He understands exactly what I am talking about. If we are going to keep these young people alive we have to make absolutely certain that they get the best of care and attention and are not hidden away as a statistic just to die and to be forgotten. But there is a place in Hobart that is being underutilised--
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Leisuremail

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a Canberra based firm trading as `Leisuremail', involved in the interstate sale and promotion of pornographic videos and books through the mail on an unsolicited basis?
(2) What action can be taken to prevent this practice?

(3) Is it illegal to publish brochures promoting videos with titles such as Tied, Tormented and Loving It, Husbands Anal Revenge and Flesh and the Priest and in turn to send such material unsolicited through Australia Post; if so, what penalties apply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following consultation with the Minister for Communications, and based partly on advice provided by the Australian Postal Commission, the answers to the honour- able member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of firms based in the Australian Capital Territory, including the firm trading as `Leisuremail', are currently under investigation by the Australian Federal Police to ascertain whether any breaches of the law have occurred in relation to the advertising, selling, hiring or distribution of videotapes and associated literature.

(2) It is an offence under the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 to advertise, sell, hire or distribute an objectionable publication or a prescribed publication. If it can be established that an offence has been committed the penalties, in the case of a body corporate, are a fine not exceeding $5,000 for an objectionable publication and a fine not exceeding $10,000 for a prescribed publication. It is also an offence to advertise, sell or otherwise publish a Category 1 or Category 2 publication or an `R' or `X' film otherwise than in accordance with the conditions applicable to that material. If it can be established that an offence has been committed the penalty, in the case of a body corporate, is a fine not exceeding $2,500.

(3) Whether the publishing of brochures promoting particular videos contravenes the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 would depend on the content of the brochures concerned. In relation to sending promotional brochures of the type referred to through the post, Postal Services Regulation 53 makes it an offence to send knowingly by post an article consisting of or containing unsolicited material which advises, notifies or advertises the existence or availability of matter of an indecent, obscene or offensive nature. If it can be established that an offence has been committed, the penalty is $200 or 6 months imprisonment or both.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax Exemptions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has taken place in the 1983 election proposal to exempt from sales tax the additional freight costs of goods purchased by country people.
(2) Will this proposal be carried out if a broadly based retail tax is introduced; if not, what other proposals does the Government have to offset this additional cost burden for country people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Sales tax is not payable on freight as such but on the value for which goods are sold by wholesale. If the wholesale selling price of goods reflects a freight component, then tax is payable on that component. This treatment, however, is no different from that accorded any other costs incurred by wholesalers and taken into account in setting their selling prices. Costs such as rent, insurance, power and other overheads would be reflected in the wholesale selling price on which tax is calculated.

In the ordinary course of events, sales tax falls on the cost of transporting goods from city to country areas only when the wholesale sales occur in those country areas. In the great majority of cases, country retailers purchase their goods from city manufacturers or wholesalers on free-on-board (f.o.b) or free-on-rail (f.o.r) terms under which wholesale sales occur in the cities. Sales tax is not then payable on freight costs incurred in transporting the goods to the country retailers' premises.

This treatment of freight costs for the purposes of the wholesale sales tax is not peculiar to sales to country traders but applies to sales by all wholesalers who incur freight and other costs in purchasing and handling goods for sale. Wholesalers located in the cities would also have to take into consideration inward freight costs in determining their selling prices whether they purchase such goods from wholesalers or manufacturers in other cities or from manufacturers located in their own city.

The possibility of attempting to remove the freight cost element from the sale value of all goods is a matter which has been raised by various interested persons and organisations over the years. That matter has been examined exhaustively, not only by various Governments but also by the Taxation Review Committee under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Asprey. The Committee's view was that equity could not be achieved in the matter of freight charges without sacrificing simplicity and certainty and without unduly increasing compliance costs and the costs of collection of the tax. The Committee recommended that no change be made to the law in this respect.

The tax system, by virtue of the income tax zone rebates, already contains an instrument to provide compensation to persons in remote areas for their higher cost of living. The Government considers the income zone rebates to be basically an equitable, practical and effective instrument for this purpose and in the 1984-85 Budget chose to increase the basic amounts of income tax zone rebates by 25 per cent, with effect from 1 November 1984. As a result of this increase, the full-year basic zone rebates are $270 in respect of Zone A, $45 in respect of Zone B and $938 in respect of the Special Zone Areas. These basic rebates are supplemented by special dependant rebates.

(2) The 1985 review of the tax system will consider a broad range of measures aimed at creating a tax system that is simpler, fairer and more conducive to economic growth. So far as any detriments associated with the transition to a reformed tax system are concerned, the Government will be seeking to address these through both the design of individual measures, especially the nature of implementation arrangements, and by means of a `package' approach whereby the distributional effects of individual measures for particular groups may be offset by other elements of the package. It would be premature to address issues relating to the possible detriment for one particular group from one possible reform measure at this stage of the Government's consideration of tax reform.
